Just can't believe how much fun I've had with ACC! New to sim racing but have loved racing games in the past. PS2 release day with GT3: A Spec and Forza 4 later on. I love the way the car, any car in this game, feels going through corners after spending time getting the right setup. Never had to before and it's been a learning curve, but it is SO rewarding to finally get that proper contact around corners. Racing feels genuine. Want to get into LFM (LowFuelMotorsports) lobbies, but still working on my safety rating in both public lobbies and single player races.

Have not tried iRacing. Have tried and disliked the feelings of RF2. Word of note, RF2 had issues for connecting to populated stateside servers which didn't help my decision for them.

Knowing that AC2 is supposed to release around Summer of '24, I'd like to see some changes though. I would like to be able to select the computer screen the game is displayed on in game rather than having to put the game in Big Picture mode. I would also like to see vehicle customization that allows for less having to go through other websites and PhotoShop. I would also, more importantly, like to use my joystick on my Fanatec wheel rather than just be limited to the "joytog" due to specific key inputs for looking around.

TL;DR
Worth the purchase! You'll get a lot from the base game before you feel you want to purchase the DLC's. Word of note, I bought the DLC's no more than an hour after starting to play because of how happy I was and wanted to venture more into this game.

This game was so incredible on PS5 that it made me actually build a gaming PC just to experience the full gamut of what 2024 has to offer in the world of GT3 sims.  Playing it on a Samsung Neo g9 57 super ultrawide. 7680x2160 of 4k maxxed rt goodness with no dlss needed. 90fps+. 4090oc was TOTALLY worth it lol. Just for this one game alone. Thats how fantastic of a gt3 sim this really is. Ive been sim racing since roughly 2010, starting on console and eventually moving over to $racing. on my g27 with a load cell. These days Ive been running the Fanatec rig on ps4 and then 5.  I was DONE with PC gaming. The days of really needing both were done, i'm not a modder or FPS freak. Consoles are fine these days. Sim racing isn't gaming for me tho, and THAT is worth the investment. and I would never go back to iracin$.  So if this gem didn't come in a very very nice form to console I wouldn't have splurged. but this is much better lol. just for the simhub access for the buttkickers alone. or the super ultrawide support. I'm sure if you're a sim racer you know about this title already. if not, it is totally worth it for the competition alone. Rather, the competitizione.  I am very into hotlapping, and there are great challenge boards. The safety ratings keep people in check on console, so I imagine PC is even tidier, I haven't delved yet. Still acclimating to the new setup.   I imagine that I will be spending a lot of time on this sim in the coming years! I already have a few hundred on ps4pro and ps5!  If you have a rig, you NEED this game!!

02/16/24 Update: Played iRacing for a few months and cancelled my subscription after becoming annoyed by their safety rating system.  I'm pretty capable of running clean races but found myself constantly being penalized after being struck by others.  After browsing the iRacing forums, I found most people who publish similar frustrations are usually attacked for being "bad" drivers and causing their own accidents.  I'm well capable of taking P1 and have done so on numerous occasions during my iRacing "career."  I became tired of the hostile environment surrounding discussion of the SR system and even more tired of having my license penalized for actions beyond my control.  I think iRacing's strength lies in that it does an outstanding stand up job of organizing race events.  The cellphone app is handy for someone like me who has limited time to burn my life away in front of a computer screen and would like to be able to plan to start a race at a specific time.  I'm aware of Low Fuel Motorsports for ACC, but I haven't yet acquired the necessary SA to get my LFM license here.  Also, as far as I'm aware, LFM doesn't have an app for me to browse my dorky virtual racing career on my phone.

For a while I'd already known I liked ACC but felt it didn't have the same depth as iRacing (in terms of physics and handling).  After I cancelled my iRacing subscription I spent more time with ACC.  Well it turns out I just knew nothing of real world GT3 cars or the assist systems they use.  After learning how to adjust brake bias, traction control, abs, engine mapping, setup, and how to approach driving these cars which designed with the assists in mind, I gotta say there's a hell of a lot of depth here in ACC that wasn't immediately apparent to me.  I'd always known I liked the FFB and graphics better than iRacing, but now I'm starting to think I may like the physics better here in ACC as well.  I think iRacing still has a massive leg up in multiplayer, but I now think ACC is a "better" overall game.  (better is subjective, find what you like best)

Something else worth mentioning is I bought several tracks and a handful of vehicles to race on iRacing.  I've probably spent close to $400-500 on iRacing in the brief period I spent with it.  This does not include the $800 wheel I purchased.  I went and purchased all of ACC's DLC after realizing I could get multiple cars and multiple tracks for roughly the cost of one "rented" track on iRacing.

I didn't intend for this to end up as a sim vs sim posting but it's hard for me to not compare the two.  I spent a good deal of money many hours on one sim that left me more frustrated than entertained.  Now that I'm focusing more on ACC I find I've spent far less money and have been much more entertained.  Your mileage may vary.

I'd be very excited to see more touring cars and overall slower racing classes introduced to this platform.  At the moment there's only one touring car in the game.  I'm eager to see a front-wheel-drive race car introduced to the ACC physics system and FFB environment.

If you were to introduce a spec Miata series to ACC may never leave my computer desk again.

The next day I went to school and thought about that all day. Then I contacted him and flew to his house to give him flowers for the incident. He didn't want them and told me to stay away from him. Played original Assetto Corsa, gave it a negative review. I played this for 70 minutes, and I'm still not convinced this is my cup of tea, ACC is way better. Controls for Logitech wheel+pedals set up in 5 minutes, physics make sense (although a bit to slippery imo), multiplayer works, I was in a race in no time.

As a noob I caused 2 accidents, one of them was probably entirely my fault, rear-ending a car. The other one was when I was recovering from an oversteer, and I let one car pass, then tried defending the position I had and the guy just crashed into me. I can imagine how infuriating these could feel (to the other driver) when they are actually good and such.

By default I got the Lambo Huracan. It feels good to drive, and after a few laps, I feel how the car behaves. Original AC wasn't able to accomplish this.

~5hr edit:
There are definitely people who actively and intentionally mess up others' games, but I confirm that this game can be fun. And despite some mistakes and accidents, I was able to raise my safety rating (and have the best lap time of the lobby), which is nice. There was one weird server with 10 hours of qualifications, which at first is odd, but actually useful to learn a track with other cars around, and grind that SA :) For personal lap records though, unfortunately yellow and blue flags delay the attempts for a few minutes.

~14hr edit:
matchmaking (talking about quick join, and public servers) as beginner is unfun, as I get put into lobbies with experienced drivers. Racing almost doesn't exist there, as I lag behind, nobody to overtake or draft behind. Another painpoint is car setups, where many things can be adjusted to shave off seconds, and there are websites selling configs for a price of a DLC, which is ridiculous. I will probably check out some communities with dedicated private servers that host more opportunities for beginners.
Since my initial review I revisited AC1, and after having played ACC, AC1 makes more sense and the lines between the two are a bit blurred. AC1 is not as bad as I initially thought, and ACC is not as good.
Given its popularity in AC1, I don't get why the full Nordschliefe wasn't included in ACC, and same goes for some other tracks, probably.
Regarding bumps and crashes, it's sad that starting from last position is advised to avoid corner1 crashes. I started from the middle, avoided one crash, and I got crashed into, ruining my race and SA rating. Both cars receiving penalty when someone divebombs is just plain stupid or lazy. There could be smarter ways to determine the penalties, for example if someone comes from behind with X km/h speed diff, they should be the one to blame.

23hr edit:
I just finished my first race I actually enjoyed, because there was a guy we could fight with. We both sent "gg"/"good race" after finishing, so it highlights how rarely this happens with beginners, which is sad in terms of matchmaking.
23 hours... I also improved my lap time by seconds (for reference: Monza lambo evo, 1:54) during this race by braking late AF and not being so careful with avoiding a little tire squeal (the sound cue and actually slipping does not happen at the same time... bit of wheel-induced oversteer entering the turn can help avoid understeer it seems)

How it started:
- You mastered arcade racers like Forza Horizon and Dirt.
- You mastered simcades like F1 and Forza Motorsport.
- You saw some streamers playing ACC, and it looked pretty cool.

How it's going:
- You try playing ACC with a controller, only to spin at every turn on your first lap.
- You get good enough with a controller to know that you need a wheel to do a proper lap.
- You get good enough with an entry level wheel to know that you need a sim rig, load cell pedals, a direct drive wheelbase, an authentic formula wheel, butt kickers, and a VR headset to truly feel immersed and squeeze every tenth out of each lap.
- You spend all of your free time and most of your time in the office on sim racing forums and browsing gear sites.
- Your wife and kids become strangers, but you don't mind because you just set a PR at Spa.

Don't fight it.

The game is probably ok if you're willing to take the very steep learning curve. Where other racing games like Gran Turismo start you off easy in a VW compact car, this game puts you right away in a Lamborghini with stability control turned off. In other games, the ideal line is really helpful, here it's better to ignore it since it gives you the brake warning (reddening line) so very late that you constantly smash into barriers if you chose to rely on it. There's no option to change that timing either.

If you're a pro driver, you're probably fine with this game. If you're a casual and only want some fun, stay away from it.

Do not play this game when you're angry because you will get more angry. I play with a controller on a laptop with 16gb ram and an mx150 chip, i7 8th gen undervolted. 54 fps avg 40 fps online. The first few hours were torture as this was my first sim but, got the hang of it after a few hours. my favorite tracks are monza and imola. Buy, very worth it, coming from forza, this is the only racing game i play besides dirt rally 2. buy on sale!

The driving experience in this game? amazing, this and iracing are the 2 best racing sims no question. 

every other aspect of the game? horrendous. the UI must have been designed to be as useless and annoying as possible, it can not possibly have been by accident. 

there's a VR mode in the launch options of this game, which until you're driving a car shows you a 2d panel of the main menu, you CANT use VR controllers at all, which means when you launch the game and it FORCES you to create a driver name, you have to peek out of your VR headset and use a physical keyboard to enter the text, so hopefully you had one nearby, and hopefully you can see out of your headset easily, otherwise good luck. 

now after you've done that you get into the actual menu for the game, at first it looks decent, modern panels with most of the modes you'd want to drive. lets say you want to set up a fun race session with friends. great! go over to the multiplayer tab and.... no way to host a session at all? interesting, the game is on steam, and steam has multiplayer server and session abilities on it, so why not press a button to setup a lobby and just invite people through steam? why make people run the dedicated server software. (which by the way you need a 3rd party tool to be able to use) well anyway now that you've exited the game (for probably the 3rd time) now you have the dedicated server running on your computer, and you can go back into the game and join your session right? well probably not. you need to enable NAT loopback so that you can connect TO YOUR OWN SERVER. an option which many people using ISP provided modem/routers wont have access to easily. 

its interesting that a racing game can be so well made for the actual racing part, but be so bad in every other aspect. do the devs live under a rock and think their UI and everything is totally fine? it was very clear with the original Asseto Corsa that the UI was actually unusable. there's a 3rd party app with as many downloads as the game that controls the UI and everything itself. at least this time they actually have a menu system in the game so you can theoretically use it by itself, but only if you're happy playing on other peoples servers or singleplayer. 

for gods sake devs, just use steam multiplayer integration and let people setup their own session IN GAME. i gave up trying to setup a session and bought someone else an iracing subscription just to play with them. is that really the experience you want for this amazing racing game?

The best car-feel and force feedback of any driving game. Assetto Corsa is good, but ACC feels better. The smoothness of traction loss means about a month or so ago I booted the game up after half a decade of playing different titles and never really feeling like I understood cornering, and suddenly it clicked for me and I understood how to trail-brake and slip angle drive through corners. FFB feels extremely good right out of the box as they say. 
It's not Assetto Corsa 2. To be clear. It's like a spin-off movie focused on a smaller group of characters - GT cars. Which are sports cars converted into race-cars. I think. I don't really care. It doesn't matter that much. They all look and sound pretty similar once you're in them. Sweaty V8s/V6s usually, gear whine and the echo of the metal cockpit. And any elegance to their silhouette is bludgeoned out of them by the aero and the bloody horrible liveries(BTW, why do racecars always have such horrible liveries? Can't they at least try and make them the same general colour and tone, so it's not like someone puked up a DIY catalogue on the car's chassis?). But they behave differently. Probably. Maybe. Honestly I got prompted by Steam to review this game, and it really is good, but I play Assetto Corsa much more, and I mostly drift in that rather than race. So I haven't played enough to even notice if the Mclaren 720s behaves differently to the Ferrari 296. They're all much of a muchness to me if I'm honest, but I'm not the one to ask. D'you know what? Just go away. I've changed my mind, I'm not even telling you if it's good or not. Now you'll never know.

Assetto Corsa Competizione, heralded as a pinnacle of racing simulation, falls victim to a critical flaw that undermines its entire experience: the woefully inadequate Force Feedback (FFB) settings. In a racing title where precision and immersion should reign supreme, the unnervingly light and numb sensation transmitted through the steering wheel plunges players into a bewildering state of disconnection from the virtual track.

Attempting to wrangle a high-performance race car with the responsiveness of a deflated balloon, I found myself grappling with an infuriating lack of tactile feedback. Every turn, every maneuver felt as though I was guiding a ghostly apparition rather than a finely-tuned machine hurtling through legendary circuits.

Desperate to salvage any semblance of enjoyment from this ordeal, I delved into the settings menu, spending countless hours tinkering with sliders and toggles in a futile attempt to coax some semblance of realism from the game, even using LUTS. Yet, no matter how meticulously I adjusted the parameters or experimented with different configurations, the elusive sensation of tire grip, road texture, and vehicle weight remained stubbornly absent.

Assetto Corsa Competizione's failure to deliver a satisfying FFB experience not only detracts from the immersion but actively sabotages the gameplay itself. Racing enthusiasts seeking the adrenaline-fueled thrills of high-speed competition will find themselves stranded in a virtual purgatory, condemned to navigate tracks devoid of the visceral feedback essential for mastering hairpin turns, controlling slides, and pushing the limits of their driving prowess.

While the game boasts stunning visuals and an impressive roster of meticulously detailed cars and tracks, the fundamental flaw in its FFB implementation casts a shadow over its otherwise commendable features. Until addressed, this deficiency transforms Assetto Corsa Competizione from a potential masterpiece into a frustrating exercise in futility, leaving players adrift in a sea of disappointment. Proceed with caution, lest you find yourself lost in translation between aspiration and execution.

ACC is about 4 months of paychecks cheaper if you want to get into competitive GT3 racing with proper matchmaking. Physics are great, sound design is unmatched, LFM is Pog. Other car classes behave completely differently and are also very good fun. Tracks look stunning and feel incredible. It's an absolute must buy for anyone with a wheel looking for a great game, great sim, great racing and a really fun community which doesn't seem to be too toxic, relatively speaking of course.

If you are on controller - try these settings:
    Deadzone: 2%
    Speed Sensitivity: 70%
    Speed Filter: 10%
    Steer Speed: 70%
    Steer Gamma: 3.0.
    Steer Assist: Disabled.

Really great game at the sales price. As a controller user was skeptical on how the game would play with my lack of a wheel but if you are willing to sacrifice some realism to have a fun and addicting racing game then I would 100% recommend as it's not too far off of how the F1 games feel on a controller. Just make sure you enable 'Gamepad' in your settings and assign your pit limiter to a button like 'A' or 'X'

The GT class comes with a lot more feel for the track and achievement in learning each layout compared to the games for open wheeled race cars and the tire physics make track evolution feel super satisfying each lap as you learn both car and track.

The single player options are also amazing with pretty good AI compared to other titles that make mistakes and try different lines along with a fully customisable season calendars with the tracks not missing a single bump or texture, race category participants, and format to give lots of variable and new experiences and that's less than ten hours in!

Definitely a step up from other racing titles in learning curve but still can definitely be enjoyed casually, Happy Racing!

ACC: 1200 Hours Later, Still Chasing Ghosts (and Nordschleife)
countless laps, countless kerb kisses, and enough Aston V8 roars to wake the dead. Assetto Corsa Competizione isn't just a game, it's a digital addiction fueled by laser-focused racing and tire-shredding satisfaction. The physics? Razor-sharp, demanding respect for every turn and apex. The cars? Each a precision instrument, begging to be pushed to the limit. The sound? A symphony of screaming engines and gravel crunching symphonies.

But ACC isn't all sunshine and checkered flags. Multiplayer is a chaotic ballet of divebombs and last-lap heroics (or villainies, depending on your perspective). Kyalami sausage kerbs are more like medieval torture devices, and mastering Spa's Eau Rouge is a rite of passage for any virtual racer.

Yet, through the sweat and tears, a grin emerges. Every nail-biting overtake, every perfectly timed corner exit, every inch clawed back from a fellow speed freak feels like a personal victory. And then there's Nordschleife, the mythical Green Hell, looming on the horizon like a siren's call to every masochistic sim racer. Kunos, we're begging you, unleash the beast!

So, is ACC worth the investment? If you crave the thrill of the perfect line, the adrenaline rush of a close battle, and the satisfaction of mastering a machine, then buckle up. Just don't blame me when you emerge from your rig, blinking at the real world like a confused tourist on Bangla Road Thailand.

After being seriously disappointed by a certain racing release at the end of 2023, I decided to give Assetto Corsa Competizione a try.. First I tried with a calibrated hand controller & it was kind of okay. After watching a few videos on YouTube, I bought a wheel and pedal set from the used tech market and I was blown away - A completely different feel to the game. Awesome stuff. I've since sold the used tech.... & bought a brand new wheel and spring weighted pedal set. I've caught the sim bug and can't leave this game alone. If you are thinking of buying a wheel and pedals to venture into the world of sim racing, I'd recommend Assetto Corsa Competizione 100% Bravo 505 Games!

Finally, the racing simulator I've been waiting for.

Amazing physics, lots of top tracks and a selection of excellent cars. You can customize everything, and there are very detailed options to adapt the difficulty, assists, and rules. I have the full set of DLCs, and the tracks are absolutely stunning and worth it, every single one. It looks great and it even comes with a great default configuration for the Xbox controller, even though you should of course play this with a wheel -- but before I decided to buy one, I had to evaluate the game without one. I now played this with a Thrustmaster T300 wheel and pedals as well, and it feels even better of course. UPDATE: I got Fanatec gear and it's amazing to drive with a GT3 wheel.

The only very minor negatives I can come up with it that it's only GT3 (a minor issue for me, as GT is my favorite series), and that Nordschleife is missing. Most likely it's missing because this is the official GT game, and the track was not part of the covered racing seasons. I hope it gets added to a future season and then comes to ACC, that would be amazing. If you really need Nordschleife, try Automobilista 2. It's a very different game with a much broader focus and tons of cars that I also like, but for GT3, nothing beats ACC: it just looks, sounds and feels better.

This was a very early review, and after the 19 hours I played, I have only gotten used to one car and driven it in time trial mode on all tracks in dry conditions, and a few in rain. I have not messed with the car's setup, I have barely started the career. But I believe I can already tell you that this game is truly a great experience! Now let me drive just [i]one more lap[/i]! 9.5/10

Update: I have played a lot more (on a friend's account, because he has a wheel), we are now driving in different conditions and without the assist line and watching videos to get better. It's still a blast. I absolutely recommend this to everyone looking for a serious racing game. Like Dirt Rally, it's rather exhausting to play though, and requires lots of concentration. If I talk to others while playing, I find that I make mistakes and mess up. If you are willing to put in some effort, it'S perfect though. If you're looking to relax after work and get some easy wins, skip this.

I have only begun to enjoy ACC.  It is exciting to have a racing game with an amazing physics engine behind it.  The cars feel unique and each one has its positives and negatives.  Overall, I'd rate this better than GT7.

The lack of vehicle choices, no matter how well (some players claim) the select vehicles behave, make this an awful experience. I'd honestly rather play BeamNG in single player than bump around a limited set of tracks in very limited selection of similar vehicles with very similar physics (which are not as 'true to life' as people would like to believe). The game is, for want of a better term, dull. The original AC was far more fun. The first Project Cars was more fun. Play ASM2 instead - for all it's flaws it's still more fun. This is a grossly overrated one trick (lame) pony.

I have played many Sim racing games. Forza Motorsport, Assetto Corsa, Iracing, and many more. this game, Assetto Corsa Competizione, is the best rounded out, realistic, fun, and best "pick up and Play" sim racing games. Not only is it aesthetically pleasing like Asseto Corsa, which is its predecessor, it also features the realistic physics, car models, and track models of Iracing. But why choose ACC? While ACC might not have the car variety as Iracing, or the modabilty like Assetto Corsa, it is perfect for its price point. It isnt glitchy or "fiddly" like Assetto Corsa, or as expensive as Iracing, which is a 10 dollar subription per month, and still have to pay $10-20 per car, and upwards of $30 for one track. Meanwhile ACC has an amazing set of cars and tracks right off the base game, and affordable dlc, on average their dlcs and close to $15, and are even cheaper when on sale. Not to mention ACC and AC are on sale frequently and can be picked up for a few bucks. I've only had this game for a couple weeks, but coming from other big racing sims, this is my favorite. By Far.

Assetto Corsa Competizione Review: The Pinnacle of GT3 Simulation

Assetto Corsa Competizione (ACC) stands as a shining example in the realm of racing simulations, particularly for its unparalleled portrayal of the GT3 series. ACC has redefined what it means to experience high-level racing simulation, offering a level of realism and attention to detail that is unmatched in the genre.

At the heart of ACC's success is its meticulous replication of GT3 cars and their behavior. Each car feels distinct, with the developers having gone to great lengths to accurately model the nuanced differences in performance, handling, and aerodynamics. This level of detail extends to the tracks as well, which are laser-scanned replicas of real-world circuits, providing an immersive and authentic racing experience.

The game's physics engine deserves special mention. The way it simulates tire grip, aerodynamics, and car dynamics is second to none, creating a realistic and responsive driving experience. This is complemented by the game's weather system, which not only impacts visibility but also track conditions, forcing drivers to adapt their strategy and driving style.

ACC also excels in its sound design. The roar of the engines, the screech of tires, and the ambient track sounds create an incredibly immersive atmosphere. Whether you're playing with headphones or a full speaker setup, the sound design enhances the overall realism of the simulation.

The game's multiplayer component is robust, offering a competitive environment for racers of all skill levels. The ranking system ensures fair matchmaking, and the penalty system encourages clean and respectful racing. The single-player career mode, while not as fleshed out as some might hope, still offers a satisfying progression system and a chance to improve skills against AI competitors.

Graphically, ACC is stunning. The attention to detail in the car models and tracks, combined with advanced lighting and weather effects, makes for a visually spectacular experience. However, this does mean that the game can be demanding on hardware, requiring a relatively powerful system to enjoy it at its best.

In terms of accessibility, ACC might be intimidating for newcomers to the genre. Its focus on realism means there's a steep learning curve, and the game doesn't hold your hand through it. However, for those willing to invest the time, the reward is the most authentic GT3 racing experience available.

In conclusion, Assetto Corsa Competizione continues to set the standard for GT3 simulation games. Its unparalleled attention to detail, advanced physics engine, and immersive sound and graphics create an experience that is as close as most will get to driving a real GT3 car. While it may be demanding in terms of both hardware requirements and player skill level, those who rise to the challenge will find a deeply rewarding racing simulation.

The racing experience (car selection, physics, track accuracy, etc.) is amazing. Unfortunately, I don't share the same joy when it comes to the multiplayer game mode. The lobbies with higher safety rating are fine, with only a few racing incidents and maybe 1 immature driver or so. It's in the lower leagues where you have to deal with the type of scum who have never completed a safe overtake in their life. They can and will punt you off the road. What makes it worse is that there is no in-built reporting system AND both players safety ratings are lowered. That means even if you are innocent , you still get punished. Aside from the multiplayer experience, the game is pretty good. The only things that are needed are an improved multiplayer experience and an in-built reporting/ban system.

It's one of the most realistic racing simulators out there. Attention to detail is incredible and It doesn't force you to own a powerhouse of a PC nor it is uselessly expensive. Although it is restricting itself to GT cars and tracks from modern day only, i believe that makes it more specific thus more attention put into each car and track, and these restrictions keep the game from being overly populated with players that are not interested about it's main purpose (which is GT racing). DLCs are a great addition to your experience but i believe you'll enjoy the game without them for sometime. It's hard, hard to control your car or to pass your opponents but that's what makes the game what it is, you just need to keep trying and think your way into the corners. Now that's track racing.

EDIT: The review below was based on version 1.8, since update 1.9 i would no longer recommend this title.

ACC is not a game as such, its much more of a sim than a game, the career mode is just racing against bots, no story, animations or cut scenes etc.
If you want an idea of how hard this game is go to any driving game you own and turn off all assists (although there is traction control and ABS in ACC its still not easy) and turn up the difficulty to max, you need to practice and practice and practice and probably need learn some advanced driving techniques just to get up to race speed.


ACC is the official GT3 game and as such it is restricted to just the cars and tracks from the GT3 series, there are also GT4's (Essentially slower GT3's) available as an add on but no one really races them.
Some may see this as a bad thing, but this does mean that they only have to concentrate on 1 style of physics and they have done the GT3 cars justice.

Then there's the setup of the cars, you have a choice you can buy them from a 3rd party or learn the art yourself, i warn you its not that easy.
The tyres are the easiest part of the setup and the one part you will have to use all of the time.

The tyres are everything in this game, get the pressures/temps wrong and you will not be able to drive fast and will probably spend all your time sliding and spinning out, you need the correct temps to have decent grip.
You will need to drive multiple laps, return to the garage, adjust your tyre setup then go back and drive a few more laps and rinse and repeat until you have the desired temps/psi, this may need 6=8 laps to achieve the desired temps...And that is just for the track temperature that you happen to be on at the time, change lobby or track temp and you will have to do all  this over again, it does get easier to do over time as you get the hang of it.

I wouldn't really recommend you play on a joypad, it is doable but not ideal, i'd think you would struggle to be competitive, but if you must i'd suggest to find a good guide on how to adjust your pad (there is a great one on here).

For those that do like the format and physics of this game it can get expensive and i am not talking add ons etc, i am Â£800 in so far on a wheelbase, load cell pedals, stand for the wheel and pedals and a gt style wheel just because...And this is the cheap gear (Thrustmaster)...You can easily spend Â£3000 to Â£5000 on a nice setup.

I just realised i haven't even mentioned the rating system within ACC, some think its really bad and others think its ok.
I wont go into details on it but i will say if you want to race online then you must pay attention to it...And you can only have one user within the game and there is no resetting your user to reset your stats.

ACC is not am arcade type of game, sliding and drifting is bad, crazy fast changes of direction are bad and crashing into other cars is a big no no, it will lose both yourself and the car you hit some of your safety ratings which is the most important stat in the game, so don't expect the person you crash into to be happy with you.

So if all the above sounds good to you, go for it you will love it

If you do buy ACC then please do everyone a favour and don't just jump into an online race straight away, it will end badly for all...PLEASE go and practice, practice and practice before joining any public lobbies.

I wish I had found this sim before I had played Forza Motorsport *the 8th and latest*. I don't think I will ever play another FM Microsoft game again after finding this simulator. If you want a nice authentic racing experience with a very flexible difficulty and control setup. This is for you. Great visuals as well especially for a 3 to 4 year old game. It has a nice learning curve though, and cars feel a bit floaty at first. However if you get it down and learn your corners it is EXTREMELY satisfying! The customization is not as quite in depth as Forza's, but it does let you create your own team, car livery, and has many colors to pick from. Between this and F1 2023 I think my sim racing thirst is quenched after the let down of FM8 and Microsoft / Turn10.  I am playing on a Razer V2 Wolverine xbox controller and after a couple tweaks in the input sensitivity it felt great. I will be creating a sim chair setup w/ my ol' reliable Logitech G27 for this though. I have not yet attempted using my RiftS for VR but after just driving in cockpit view I can tell this game should be awesome utilizing VR.

Love this game. Working great for FFB. direct drive wheel. but when i try with xbox/ps5 controller a buttons layout was really bad. DEV forces player to use only 1 analog and 2 trigger so....you will forces to have an empty right analog with unnecessary keybinds and this how to fix it.

-Throttle and brake will bind to left and right trigger by default so you can't change it let it be
-clean all right analog default keybinds
-bind shift up and down to shoulder buttons L1/R1
-use steam input and change right analog stick unit to dpad
-assign dpad up to right trigger /throttle
-assign dpad down to left trigger /brake

by this you will had 2 throttle and brake set keys on your hands and when you want to use throttle and brake at the same times like trim your position in apex. use right analog up to throttle and brake with left trigger.

controller had more potential than DEV thinks It's need just a right setup with an analog stick height extension. even a clutch it's can assign on a controller and i never seen a simrace game thats not allow player setting up to comfort their play before. this fix can work on steam only. but how about a console player who don't had a wheel and steam input.

I hope kunos learn from this fix. love your works

In my personal opinion. This game is the epitome of sim racers for GT series racing. IE: GT4/GT3/GT2 (although GT2 isn't really a thing anymore). But if you are looking for an authentic feel in GT series racing, this is the sim for you. I play a wide arrangement of 'racing sim' style games. From Forza Motorsport, to the original Assetto Corsa, to ACC, to iRacing. I even do rally with games such as Dirt Rally 2.0 and Rally Sim Fan's Richard Burns' Rally. For GT3 racing, ACC is king. Even compared to iRacing. The brakes are realistic, the tire model is realistic, and the cars handling is realistic. This feels like driving an actual car, as it should.

The only drawback I can find to this game over something like iRacing is the damage model in ACC is a lot more forgiving. Tapping the wall in ACC won't force you to limp the car around the track to the pits, or have to tow in, whereas in iRacing, it's a bit more realistic in that aspect. Hitting the wall would do detrimental damage to your vehicle, and in iRacing, it does. So this game does have a little bit more forgiveness when it comes to incidents on the track. The audio is also much more immersive in ACC than other sims, even getting to the point that driving through closed in sections of the track will cause the audio of the car to echo back onto you. It's nice. And the game is beautiful. 

So, would I recommend this game? Yes, for GT3 racing, this is the top dog. For everything else, I would say get iRacing (especially if you are into dirt oval racing... iRacing does that SOOO WELL!). 

So, yeah... 10/10, would review again.

This game is very fun, it differs from Assetto Corsa as there is a more serious and technical side with setups so if you are not a giga nerd it is not going to make sense. Setups do play a big role in lap time and therefore people try monetize this aspect of ACC which means you will have to spend more money on top of the $40 price tag + DLC to have a competitive setup to properly race. This leads to another side which is that ACC uses info from the GT championships so if 1 car becomes bad and you have just spent $40 for the base price and say 1 DLC for the car so like $15 and then a $20 setup you are now down $35 for the car and the setup for an noncompetitive car. You can find free setups or make your own but they are rarely better than pro setups and way more time consuming. A negative is also that you do need to own all DLC to participate in ranked races, but just sign up for LFM which is way better or do casual races. Despite listing some negatives this game is incredibly fun, Weather and graphics are amazing, the cars feel very responsive and drive differently based on TC and ABS settings. Better multiplayer than Assetto Corsa as in AC the server list is clunky and often empty, in ACC you can get your favorite car and join multiplayer races. Braking system is also significantly more accurate for GT3's than IRacing or Assetto Corsa. Cars are also incredibly detailed with many nooks and crannies as well as accurate weight distribution for stuff like engine placement and fuel. Car collisions are significantly better(detection wise) than say iRacing. On the other hand the mechanical damage is not as detailed as iRacing and can sometimes feel negligible in an aerodynamic sense. Cars can be very hard to drive but incredibly rewarding once mastered, I drive the Mclaren 720s GT3 Evo and it is very hard to sustain grip through lower speed corners and sometimes even the off tic can make the car loose grip or lock the steering, but once you have mastered all the brake markers and the intricacies it is incredibly rewarding. Take for example, I was learning the Mclaren on Monza and when I finally got a 1:54:072 I was extremely happy, but I have been driving now on Spa and feel like on eau rouge my car looses grip and the steering locks which is very frustrating. Either way if you are a pleb or a professional racer sliding into a GTR user get ready to be called a slur. PS. Braking is better in ACC than iRacing.

I forgot that I wrote this, and now.... i am approaching 2000 hours. I have ran in LFM and other grassroots style leagues that have pushed my driving technique and competitiveness to levels I have never knew I could achieve through a sim. The people ive met, and became friends with will likely stick with me for my entire life through the comradery ive experienced racing some of the best drivers on the internet.  I have become involved with this sim/game more than any other game ive ever played and i did several years of competitive level esports with Counter strike.   There is no other game on this planet outside maybe the cumulative hours ive spent playing games online since the late 90's with first person shooters and rts combined than ACC. Which to think about is insanity because I enjoy games. I think what has separated this from the others is that it is a real world tangible experience ( *see above)  that benefits you in many ways as not only a driver but human being. It forces you to challenge yourself constantly so you are not left behind. I always have been able to find small steps forward in bettering myself in this and in real life at the same time!   

TDLR : make a ton of friends, teach them how to get fast, get into a league ( apex online, Low fuel motorsport , simracing.gp, ) it breeds excellence and better racing. This games updates and further progress even in this late of the game is still keeping coming back for league after league, its just that good. I will break 2000 hours very soon and will not likely stop until even after 3000 as long as the player base and development of the game doesnt cause it to die.

It definetly is a great improvement from the first Assetto Corsa at the cost of limited categories and no community content or modifications allowed.

The categories avaliable are improving slowly but surely (GT4 and GT3 so far).

Smaller load times, better grafics, lower input lag and a great online multiplayer competition. 

You can participate in private leagues or just join in one of many open servers with races online any time you want. Also now there are many official championships with real prizes on the line that you can take part of for free.

Even the smallest of setup change can modify the behaviour of the car so be prepared to have a hard time discovering the secrets of every car. 

Track surface grip variability and dynamic weather, with day, rain and night, make it hard to predict your best hotlap time.

Driver safety measures, pace, consistency and many other stats are recorded at every race in the game so you can improve and race against drivers of your skill level depending on the servers requirements.

And if you are still reading this just try it yourself, its worthy it.

Update (@v1.1.2): this game still very much rocks, and is now even better with customizable liveries, 2019 season and a much better tire model. Get. This. Game. You won't regret it!

Update (@v1.0.5 public beta): The game has released in a content-complete state, but not yet a feature complete state. Certain things are still being worked on by the 25-person team. For the driving alone, I'd recommend it - but the 'game'-part is still lacking. You need to make it fun for yourself, which you can do by joining one of the many existing communities and/or keeping track of your stats yourself.

Update (@v0.6.5): Really taking shape now, but a lot of stuff left to fill in. Multiplayer is stable now, but missing loads of features. The racing itself is still so good, combined with some well driving guys online this game is awesome.

Update (@v0.5.2): Game has some new content, which is fine, I guess. The Jag is a real challenge to drive through mid-high speed corners of which the new track (Zolder) has many. Apparently, Kunos have hit a snag with the multiplayer so that is still non-functional. Yet, I'm still having fun with the AI, with the hotlapping, and more. I just wish Kunos would allow us to record our hotlaps already. The function and UI is already there, they are just keeping it for the full release. It would have been a good gesture for starting over on the multiplayer part. Still positive about the game, but I hope they retain other people's interest.

Update (@v0.4.0): Game is stable AF right now. Haven't played release 3 a lot because I don't like the track and car they released and the online play was moot, but this release (Hungaroring + Ferrari + basic online races) is big ffing improvement. The game is really shaping up nicely. Also - try playing this with quality headphones on, you can hear the individual sounds (wind, tires, brakes, everything) doing their work. Breathtaking stuff.

Update (@v0.3.4): Game is less stable, especially in 'multiplayer', which is just hotlapping with other cars trying to ram you. Still, very promising but needs a lot of content.

At release (@v0.1.0/v0.1.1): game is very bare bones. 1 track, 1 car. Practice mode, hot lap mode, hot stint mode (8 min or 35 min) and sprint race (~20 min). Still, hell of a lot of fun if you like racing sims.

Options could be improved upon, the way the UI interface doesn't show confirmations to your input is irritating at times (namely during set-up). Loads of little kinks and gripes like that, but it's Early Access so I hope Kunos will listen to the community and doesn't leave this kind of stuff up to modders this time.

If you like hotlapping the NÃ¼rburgring, then this game in its current state is for you. ACC has so ff-ng much potential and I am looking forward to the rest of the content. However, it is not for everyone. I hate to start gatekeeping here, but this is no Forza or GT Sport. You have to get a wheel to enjoy it, fully.

Havent played the original yet, so I can't really make a comparison. But ACC is a great racing sim with good tracks. Definitely consider this one if you're trying to get into racing sims.

Assetto Corsa Competizione stands out as a shining example in the world of racing simulators. The game is a dedicated endeavor to recreate the Blancpain GT Series, now known as the GT World Challenge Europe, with an impressive degree of accuracy and attention to detail.

One of the most laudable aspects of ACC is its handling model. It strikes a delicate balance between realism and playability, catering to both hardcore sim racers and those new to the genre. The game's physics engine delivers an incredibly authentic driving experience. Every nuance of the car's behavior, from tire grip to weight transfer, is perceptibly influenced by various factors like weather conditions and track temperature, making every race a unique challenge.

Graphically, ACC is a marvel. The meticulous representation of renowned circuits and a diverse range of GT cars are visually stunning, complemented by dynamic weather and lighting systems that not only enhance the visual appeal but also affect race strategy and vehicle handling.

The game's sound design deserves special mention. The roar of engines, the screech of tires, and the ambient sounds of the track come together to create an immersive audio experience that puts you right in the driver's seat.

Multiplayer in ACC is robust, with a ranking system that ensures you're matched with players of similar skill levels. The game also features a single-player career mode that, while not as deep as some might hope, offers a satisfying journey through the GT series.

There are over 20 tracks and dozens of cars in each category (GT3, GT4, etc. - depending on which DLCs you get).

However, the game is not without its shortcomings. The AI can sometimes be unpredictable, and there are occasional technical glitches. Moreover, the steep learning curve might be off-putting for casual players.

In conclusion, Assetto Corsa Competizione is a must-play for fans of racing simulations. Its exceptional attention to detail, combined with a sophisticated physics engine and stunning graphics, offers an incredibly realistic and engaging racing experience. While it may have a few minor flaws and a challenging learning curve, these are small trade-offs for what is otherwise a brilliantly executed racing simulator.

Compared to "Normal" sims this is a piece of turd. I have tried many times to make something of it work, but where other racing sims simply work, this is a futile attempt to try to simulate driving. At times you think you've got it running where a race is actually happening, but then it lunches you into oblivion. Think you can change driving position or FOV, think again. Other sims allow this to suit each car variant and on the fly. Not ACC. I have had reasonable races in ACC, but like Christmas, they only come once a year. AMS2 eats this for breakfast. AC is even better. Talk about a retrograde. I have had this for more than 3 years and each time I try to make it work, I terminate it with anger.

This game costs at least 500$.
P.S. Dont try this without steering wheel (at least gamepad).

When I first started playing, I thought, "Great, I've got the coordination of a drunk giraffe, and now I have to learn how to control a car in a game that's more realistic than my actual driving skills." I mean, seriously, it was like trying to tame a wild beast. But hey, who doesn't love a challenge, right? After countless hours of spinning out, crashing into barriers, and probably causing more virtual damage than a demolition derby, I finally started to get the hang of it. And let me tell you, it was like discovering fire for the first time. Suddenly, I was in control, and it was amazing.

I'm still not winning any races. But who needs to win when you can have the time of your life just trying to keep your car on the track? It's like being a contestant on a game show where the prize is not dying in a fiery crash. And honestly, that's good enough for me. So, if you're looking for a racing game that'll make you feel like you're actually behind the wheel of a high-performance race car, Assetto Corsa Competizione is the one for you.

Assetto Corsa Competizione isn't just a racing game; it's the zenith of racing simulation, a digital masterpiece that meticulously recreates the thrill, physics, graphics, and authenticity of the real-life GT3 racing world. It's an experience that leaves you breathless, pushing the boundaries of what is possible in the world of racing games.

What sets Assetto Corsa Competizione apart is its awe-inspiring dedication to realism. The physics are nothing short of astonishing. Every curve, every brake, every accelerator input feels like you're in the cockpit of a bona fide GT3 race car. The way the tires grip the road, the subtlety of weight transfer, and the tactile feedback through your virtual steering wheel are as close to reality as it gets.

The graphics are a feast for the eyes. The meticulously detailed cars and tracks are rendered with such precision that you can almost feel the sun's warmth on the asphalt and hear the crowd's roar in the stands. The dynamic weather system adds another layer of authenticity, with rain-soaked circuits demanding a whole new level of skill and strategy.

But where Assetto Corsa Competizione truly excels is in its accuracy to real-life motorsports. The official partnership with the Blancpain GT Series ensures that every detail, from car liveries to the rules and regulations, is faithfully recreated. The realism extends to the car setup options, allowing you to fine-tune your vehicle just like the real racing teams do.

It's not just about crossing the finish line; it's about strategy, tire management, and mastering the nuances of each track. It's about reading the behavior of the cars ahead of you and making split-second decisions. Assetto Corsa Competizione demands your utmost concentration and skill, immersing you in the world of professional motorsport.

In conclusion, Assetto Corsa Competizione is the apex of racing simulation, a testament to the possibilities of virtual racing in every dimension. It is the marriage of precision physics, breathtaking graphics, and unparalleled authenticity. It's a game that pulls you into the cockpit of a GT3 race car and lets you taste the glory of motorsport at its highest level. If you seek the ultimate racing simulation, look no further. Assetto Corsa Competizione is the pinnacle, the gold standard, and the masterpiece of realism that every racing enthusiast dreams of. It's a thrilling, heart-pounding, and unforgettable experience that sets a new benchmark for the genre.

this game is really refined and its got an amazing selection of tracks and cars even without the dlcs, but please if you're new to sim racing or just actual competitive racing in general, please take some time in single player modes to get your skills up.

 the most annoying thing for most people who drive well is seeing a new driver in front of them that cant keep the car straight, this doesn't sound too bad to some people but its when the faster driver is trying to pass the new driver and they rejoin the track dangerously or purposefully get in front of the faster driver and ruin their qualifying or even the race. 

so please i urge the new players reading this to take some time getting used to the game and how the cars handle, it will make your time playing the game more enjoyable and it means that when you do come to the multiplayer part of the game, you might actually have a fighting chance against the other drivers and at the end of the race you will get a "GG" instead of many obscenities shouted at you because you got in someones way one too many times.

Could be a great game - excellent ui, great graphics, engrossing gameplay; a proper sim. But for an online sim racer to have NO REPORT FUNCTION or ability to vote-kick or ban has unfortunately ruined this game.

Most online friendly races are 20 min, so not exactly your 3 lap sprints. However, there has been a recent surge of trolling. these include:
- parking on the racing line behind blind corners and waiting for the lead pack
- parking off the track to wait for cars to t-bone
- blatantly deliberate t-1 crashing
- deliberately ignoring blue flags to hold up/crash into lead lap cars

Obviously some people find it fun to ruin other people's, but when a game is doing seemingly nothing to prevent this, its inevitable that people are going to wreck it.

Will update if online issues are addressed.

Im brand new to sim-racing so take that into account when reading this. I have played normal ACC, CarX, Dirt Rally 2.0 and F1 23, but this is definitely my favorite. Out of my current hours, 95% are just practice laps, hotlaps, and hotstint mode. But, this has got to be one of the most fun, challenging, and rewarding games I have ever played. I cant wait to get more time in this and learn more so I can become competent enough for online races.

The community is great and you can find plenty of advice starting off and for advanced drivers. This is one of the few games that exist where I genuinely believe that you take some of the skills you learned back into the real world. While I do not see myself driving a GT3/GT4 car anytime soon, I would love to actually have a try at it one day just to see what applies. Regardless, this is a great game with some great graphics, good optimization, and engaging driving.

Definitely recommend!

When I bought Assetto Corsa i had no idea it was going to run so smooth and so good visually on my Dell Insperion lap top. I liked Assetto Corsa so much that a week later I decided to get all the DLC pakages for it.
Then I happened to see a review on Assetto Corsa Competizione and as the name in the title states this is much more inclined, polished and orientated towards competition racing. I decided to by also ACC. However it took me some time to get the same level of visuals and performance that I have on the original AC. Now its almost there and today I managed to enjoy a few online races and its fun since the drivers are human and prone to pressure and mistakes unlike AI. In general I like the setup of the game and user interface. I like the fact that you can personalise the car livery. 
The following is not a dislike but just a comment , the simulation is oriented to GT3 and GT 4 type racing. I would have more appreciated ACC if it also included other classes and vintage tournaments like DTM and not only focused on GT 3/4.
Would i recommend it - yes for those that alreay have AC definitely a must have because its an awesome experience . For first time buyers I still suggest get Asseto Corse first and work your way to ACC.

Car go vroom

This game is the real deal.

Imo AC has one of the best physics to date, and ACC continues that trend. What I really think benefits ACC is that it doesn't overextend itself with a massive selection. The development was focused to GT cars rather than having to adhere to multiple classes such as open wheel, rally, sports cars, etc. What this resulted in was a very disciplined sim, becoming a FAR more complete package than AC. 

The UI feels like a real game this time, multiplayer functions are easy to understand, singleplayer is viable, and the AI isn't hopeless. The immersion is even better, cars look fantastic and sound impeccable. The tracks are beautiful and diverse. The game helps you understand the philosophy of racing with it's rating system, and creates conditions just consistent enough for you to notice your short comings and where to improve. Out of all the sim games out there, this is the one that I like to actually race championships in, shave time off of lap times, and experiment with setups, other than maybe Dirt Rally.

It really is a fantastic motor racing game, really the top of it's field in my opinion.

Assetto Corsa Competizione is nothing short of a racing masterpiece. It's a thrilling and immersive experience that sets a new standard for racing simulations.

The graphics are stunning, with impeccable attention to detail in every car and track. The realism of the physics and handling is second to none, making each race feel like a heart-pounding adventure. The sound design adds to the immersion, making you feel like you're truly on the racetrack.

The depth of content is impressive, with a wide variety of cars and tracks to choose from, and the career mode offers a satisfying progression system. Multiplayer is where this game truly shines, providing intense and competitive racing against real players from around the world.

Whether you're a hardcore racing enthusiast or a casual gamer looking for an exciting racing experience, Assetto Corsa Competizione delivers on all fronts. It's a 5/5-star gem that deserves a spot in every racing fan's collection.

ACC is a fantastic sim IF you really love GT3/GT4 racing and don't care much about anything else. I'm still an iRacing guy at heart, but I will give credit where it's due. Purchased Assetto Corsa Competizione a week ago and have already put 38 hours into it. I'm playing on a 27" 1440p monitor, with a Thrustmaster T300 GT (and included pedals) mounted to my desk. Having so much fun that I nag my friends about coming over to play. It has got my daydreaming about buying new gear and a proper rig, even though I certainly don't have neither the cash or space for it.

I don't have that much experience with other sim racing titles so I can't really comment on how authentic it feels, but it's a huge difference between this and arcade racers such as Forza Horizon and Need For Speed. What I can say, however, is that even on my little setup it is very immersive. Sound and graphics are very nice and the cars behave on track as I would expect them to. Compared to the racing-line-hugging, rubber-banding AI from titles like Forza Horizon, the AI is much better. Can't comment on multiplayer though because I'm still learning how to not be a wrecking ball near other cars.

Would I recommend this game? Yes, absolutely. Even just practicing, doing hotlaps and racing against the AI is incredibly fun!

If you are looking for an arcade game (emphasis on GAME), then this is for you. If you suck at driving and want something you just slam down the brake and turn and everything's fine, this game is for you. If you love the realism of something like iRacing, something you have to modulate the brake and cannot slam the brake in the brake in the middle of a turn because it will cause you to spin (as in REAL LIFE), then this game is not for you. This is not a simulator, this is an arcade game. And sadly, I'm beyond the time where I can get a refund. Pretty bad when you can install and uninstall a game within the same hour and KNOW you will never play it again.

This is... different to the original Assetto Corsa. While yes, there is [i]muuuuch[/i] more content, that is completely dependent on how good a mod is (and more importantly, how much you're willing to pay). This game on the other hand? Perfect content, across the board. The AI for it as well, holy shit! They don't feel like they're too weak or too strong. They're still AI of course, but compared to the dive-bombing, tunnel-visioned speed-demon AI that you have to deal with if you don't wanna play with other people, they are good enough. One thing I really liked was how customisable the cars and your character is. There's a lot of colours, a fair amount of pattern options and most importantly, you can have your own number on your car!

TLDR? Expensive including the DLC's, but 100[b]0[/b]% worth it if you want a good experience for GT racing. Would absolutely recommend for a good simracing experience.

The good things:
+driving in the rain - really feels like actual wet weather racing with aquaplaning and a believable grip level
+runs smooth and looks good
+simulates an actual race series rather than just throwing some random cars and tracks at you
+Night racing - headlights actually do work as they should on GT cars
+collisions actually work - the cars do not suddenly become glued to each other or start flying for no reason like in some other sims

The bad things:
-ffb gives no feel whatsoever - there is simply no indication when the tires begin to lose grip. As in regular Assetto Corsa, you need damn witchcraft to make this behave at least somewhat believable
-suspension simulation is odd in some cars - in the Ferrari 488, the slightest bump can send the rear end of your car flying. And I don't mean a slide. I mean actually launching it into the air. Slightly touch the gravel on inside of the Warsteiner-Kurve and it's as if someone planted a landmine there. I tried a Honda NSX and BMW M4 and those cars behave much better over bumps. EDIT Update 1.9 fixed this and now the physics are great!
-the UI is unintuitive
-stats sometimes don't work: I went online, won 3 races (even have replays) and in the stats it shows only one win. 
-If someone rear-ends you on braking you both get a safety rating drop. Even if it's some moron in a lapped down car. It would be a good idea to make it that if a collision involves a lapped down car, only that vehicle gets a penalty
-The rolling start procedure in online races. Seriously, this is badly done. It's overcomplicated and especially annyoying in online races where it sometimes throws random penalties for the driver starting in pole position.  Seriously, NASCAR Racing 2003 Season managed to get rolling starts working online without issues 20 years ago. GTR2? Same, rolling starts worked fine. And here we are with ACC in 2023 and it's an absolute mess EDIT After updates this seems fixed

Overall a mixed bag this... Played some more time and actually enjoyed some online races but still, there are some annoying issues with this game.

EDIT As of 1.9 the game has improved a lot! I really enjoy it!

Imagine a 'Pet Simulator' game, where the only pet you got to simulate was a Golden Retriever with incontinence issues. Now imagine a racing game, where all the cars are pretty much a Golden Retriever, but with differing levels of incontinence, and factor that with that they all shed hairs around the house and are constantly gazing their longing eyes into yours in search of food...  Turns out, the cars in ACC are very similar... They're all beautiful representations of their pedigree, they all want to be loved, they all relish being firmly handled, and they will be more loyal to you than a YouTuber a second after you hit 'subscribe' 
If you want a fast paced racer, with plenty of action and not much grinding, you're in the wrong place buddy.  But, If you want a semi-paced racer with a comparatively decent amount of action and a shed-load of grinding, you're in the right place buddy. It's not easy, but your mum is...

This game might be better for those using full racing sim hardware set ups; however, I was only using a game pad, and it was awful.  I could not find a setting that wasn't too twitchy at speed but could also make a realistic slow tight turn.  My first problem was that there was zero tutorial at all, the closest thing to training was testing to see what difficulty to put you at.  As someone with significant high performance track time, I was most disappointed with realism.  It was more work than fun, like a sim, but it wasn't even very realistic.  There were also way too many helper systems build it that you couldn't turn off, like counter steering in a slide was always on; this really made it hard as sometimes the system helped and sometimes it didn't and the transitions were awkward.  You could also mash the gas and sometimes you'd uncontrollably spin out and letting off the gas wasn't enough to recover traction for a few full seconds; otherwise, it would just keep spinning the tires.  The control system seemed to punitively break the car if you ever lost control and didn't allow for a realistic quick recovery from minor losses of traction.  I've intentionally and unintentionally put real high performance cars into slides and the most amazing thing about them is how fast they recover full traction the moment you let off the gas or ease the steering input.

Also, like many simulators, be prepared to spend a ton more on adding cars; the game price only includes a few cars so you have to spend a lot to get to drive everything you want to drive.

ACC is the best Racing Sim that I've driven since the latest update. I have been racing sim's since F1 1998 and pretty much everything up till now. RFactor 2, IRacing and the first Assetto Corsa were at the top in the past decade in my humble opinion, but I think ACC takes it to the next level. Especially if you have a higher end sim rig with direct drive wheel base and a good set of pedals. ACC started off as a turd burger but rose from the ashes and now shines bright. Obviously this is subjective based on the type of racing, vehicles and tracks you like. One thing that I wish they can improve is the vehicle damage, both visually and how it affects the cars while driving. Just a little thing but can always be made better with later updates I guess. Oh ya, forgot to mention F1 2020 which I think is the best of the F1's all around. Kinda weird that you can't buy it any more since EA bought Codemasters. Just saying! This is the first time writing a review for anything on Steam, so take it for what it's worth. Stay safe and see you on the track!

Assetto Corsa Competizione is a minimalist racing sim in the core, it convinces players it's a realistic GT3 sim by using the name of SRO GT Series and a very realistic sounding car, the car in this game doesn't have longitudinal weight manipulation, trailbraking does not have a noticeable effect like a racing sim should(even GTAV has similar effects), there is no dancing on the edge of grip either, no need for small correction to keep on the edge of grip like a lot of people would do in sims and real life, player can just yank the wheel as hard as they can, and the car will proceed to turn just as good as normal entry, to drive in this game is simple, brake good, steer precisely into the race line(you can yank that wheel), during the exit, there's no need to worry about the car's current weight bias, the only thing that can slide the car is pressing the throttle when steering angle is too big, a very minimalist simulation.

When a Racing Sim is bad, people would call it an Arcade Sim, but ACC is no arcade, it's a straight up scam.

its simulates my dad's FUCKING VAN FROM 1989 WITHOUT POWER STEERING
The santro had more fucking grip than THIS.... The HONDA CIVIC.. THE CASUALS FUCKING CAR.. HAS MORE TURNING SPEED! 
ugh omg... I can see another jester award from the fanatic cock thristy basement dwelling neckbeards who might as well get paid as much as the clickfarm in my country at this point 
(on an off note...who fucking does that? In LIFE? you don't play? you go around this 1 game's NEGETIVE REVIEW SPECIFICALLY... to give out jester awards?... WHO THE FUCK???) 

anyway yea.. its a realistic simulation of how me and my friends can buy stock cars from 2009 and race. 
which ... I mean... once you think of it THAT WAY.. Its pretty cool not gonna lie. its like a real race people can have.. And have that feeling of not just accelerating turning braking.. and nothing in between..... it feels like you might crash your very expensive car , even expensive hospital bills and insanely expensive insurance . 

I learn that when i basically kept going off track and i went "WELL HOW HARD I CAN PUSH THE CAR THEN? THE AI SEEMS TO DO IT WELL AND BETTER THAN ME AND THE YOUTUBERS ONLINE JUST FEEL LIKE THEY DRAG THE CAR INTO THE CORNER BARELY BY THE LAST THREAD OF THEIR UNDERPANTS" 

and i spectated the AI and felt "wtf they are doing the same. did the players pick up the bad AI's bad habits"
then i watched the replay without the racing lines thing and tried to get a feel for when the AI brakes , how it turns and basically what that tells me about the car. If i understand one. I will understand the class of cars... Sort of like learning the pattern of what's going on. Rather than just 1 car. 

And it really did feel like the drivers were throwing the cars into the corners BEFORE the corner even came like they didn't trust their cars to make the slightest turns. Like if they had to get out of their apartment's gate they would need a runway's length of turn to make that possible and if that wasn't there , they would make 1 by cutting all the corners they could.

and i realise these GT cars aren't SHIT. They are regular cars

So i did 1 more race and that's when i learnt the obvious.. If you turn the car and it isn't turning as much as expected INSTANTLY. it isn't because turning is an Acceleration.. meaning it would EVENTUALLY turn faster.... That or...like Elite Dangerous . there was a Speed limit within which the car/ship turns with the max speed. Below it , its slugish . After it. There is no grip. So i had to hit the perfect speed. Which i Just couldn't .. nor could i understand why

It isn't turning as much as expected INSTANTLY because i'd already blown past the grip rating for the tires REGARDLESS of speed. And the slower the speed the more I can turn... Or rather the more range that turning will feel responsive cause im not "understeering" as in slipping on my front wheels and thereforenot turning just burning rubber on ground. Sideways.... the tire.. not the car. 

Meaning there was no need for me to hold a certain speed.
Now WHY did this false logic enter my head

Well cause of my entire reason for this rant ofc
I EXPECTED RACE CARS TO FEEL SIGNIFICANTLY DIFFERENT . What the hell is the point of going fast in a straight line. trains can do that . Planes can do that SIGNIFICANTLY BETTER. So can horses but they atleast feel like a powerful thing. 
I thought "OFC I AM DOING SOMETHING WRONG OFC.. NO WAY A MILLION DOLLAR CAR TURNS LIKE LEPROSY INFLICTED DEAD MEAT" 

nope...

The moment your car turns slower than the amount your joystick is turned. Or Steering wheel if using KB+M i guess. the moment it feels like the car isnt turning like an f-22/Su-57 thrust vectoring jet in full force. You've blown past the limit
and the limit it turns out.... is insanely small.
which is why ofc.. the AI keeps throwing cars into corners way before the corner shows up.
As if the track designers tested every car on the planet for 25years.. Including the future... and then decided to purposefully make turns on EVERY CORNER smaller than the normal turning radius of cars at normal speeds , forget racing speeds

that or... What i suspect is the true cause
ofc a Van , honda civic and a Santro Hatchback i think they call it... Can't outturn a GT car.

I made a simple review when I was 10 hours into the game, but now I feel obligated to write a more comprehensive one.

This is the best simracing game to play with a controller (you need a good one; PS5/Xbox's are great).

The way you can feel the vibrations of the track and the car's stability through your controller in this game is unprecedented in any other simgame. It's incredible; you can sense exactly when you start to lose control, when your tire is degrading, or even slight elevations on the track. Moreover, all of these vibrations feel distinct in your hand.

The handling is utterly amazing. You can feel the weight of the wheel; the car responds to any feedback and you can truly sense it. The camera feels great off the car and really good on it (almost perfect in some cars, not as good in others). Both front cameras offer Gran Turismo-level quality (which, in my opinion, is the best in any "simracing").

The sound. I can't deny it's close to the real thing, but perhaps due to the mechanical precision of the car in the game, I think the sound team couldn't keep up with the level of detail it should have. It can get a bit unpleasant when you're using too much Traction Control or ABS, but nothing unbearable.

Tracks. All of them feature laser scan fidelity, which is crucial for a simracing game. The 3D work on the tracks is not perfect. In my case, I don't mind that, so it's a minor issue for me, but I understand that's not the case for everyone.

DLC. Most of these are worth it. They usually come with a major update, which is nice for getting some people back into the game. As of writing this, I own 4-5 DLCs, and I don't think any of them were not worth it. Each one has at least one good car or great track, but there are some less impressive cars here and there, yes.

Good in depth GT simulator, it allows multiclass racing and it's a joy to run either alone or online. The Safety Rating System is really good, it block toxic players from entering into the important lobbies. The downside of this is that it will take you a while to enter the good servers. 

Expect a steep learning curve, I've had this game for a while and I just barely feel like I understand it. There are numerous guides that help you understand the basics of this sim, unfortunately some of those contradict themselves, so you might want to test several to see which one fits you.

Great game.  I have only been using my Quest Pro to play in VR mode.  No problems.  Too bad graphics don't match qualify on TV but still pretty good with 4090 card.  I launch game with Oculus VR from Steam.  Seems better than Steam VR.  Finally found an easy way to record VR video.  Before I launch Quest Link I start video recording within the the Quest.  Once I see the red dot in the helmet I launch Quest Link, select my desktop, start Steam and then start ACC with Oculus VR.  The red dot remains while in ACC in VR.  It keeps recording very good qualify video.  You can set you video recording prefs directly in the Quest prior to launching Quest Link.  I have no way to stop recording while using Quest Link so I will need to edit/delete the beginning and end of video's.  The only way I found to stop recording is to stop Quest Link and stop video recording within the Quest helmet.  The video is stored directly on the helmet.  If it is too big to sync with Quest app you will need to connect your helmet to PC to access.

This review can be compacted to: 'great game but there is little content for a lot of money' This game has had four years to build-up to something better: it didn't happen. 

Many have already said it; graphics, bugs, physics and sound design are NOT this games problems apart from wonky VR.  

You pay 40 euro's for the full game, for this you get 11 track in just one configuration (?) and around 22 free cars in multiplayer while 25 of them are locked behind a paywall.  

No problem you say to yourself, this game is not FH5 with 5 million 'meh' cars but focuses on a rather niche part of the total racing world while making it the best experience there is.. works great and all is well. 
You start racking up a better safety score to play competition, 10 hours later you qualify for it, only to find out that you have to buy a damn DLC pack to even play it?! ('THE IGT DLC IS REQUIRED TO JOIN, BUY NOW ON STEAM') 

In my experience the game does not have a big player base. At the time of writing, 1133 players and 10 quick join candidates are available, 810 are out of reach due to track medals (which can only be obtained by the f*cking competition server + dlc pack) and 510 by means of safety ratings. In and of itself is's probably fair enough, the scoring system seems decent apart from the occasional: 'Lap time invalidated, you did magic', 'Crossed track limits, you touched a grass pixel', 'Penalty, you get a DNF for not knowing you had to pit' and 'Someone hit you so here is your reduced safety score' kinda thing. 

Even if you get a full online lobby, it is always the same Monza track in daylight with perfect conditions and that is that.. try to increase the probability for another track or different weather conditions/more realistic rules and disappointment will set in.. at most you'll find five players to do a race with. (before three of them quit in the middle of a race because they are last) 

It remains ridiculous that a full decked out game like this, with all the DLC's, costs, a full-priced 140 euro's. (12,99+17,99+10,99+12,99+8,99+19,99+14,99+40) Why price the game at 40 bucks when only 30 percent of the 'content' is available upon buying it? 

Kunos, you make great games and this one is no different technically wise, but f*ck you for triple dipping your c*ck in anyone's wallet for no good reason. 

To this day, the original Assetto Corsa remains more popular/fun and with good reason: that game is actually affordable/configurable, offers a wide range of cars/tracks and has a good/experienced player base behind it. Oh, has it been mentioned that it still receives updates?! Go out and buy that one instead if you need a realistic sim experience.

Do not buy this game unless it is on sale, even if you buy it on sale, expect only a small part of the already little substance it has to offer.
