In Assetto Corsa Competizione, the driver Alexander Finklesmith is, to put it bluntly, a complete disaster on the track. His racing skills are an absolute travesty, and it's a wonder how he even manages to stay on the circuit. With a complete lack of finesse and control, Finklesmith's driving style can only be described as a chaotic mess. He seems to have a knack for colliding with other cars, taking corners at impossible angles, and causing mayhem wherever he goes. It's baffling how someone can consistently perform so poorly in a game that already embraces its own flaws. While Assetto Corsa Competizione may have its own charm, Finklesmith's presence on the track is an unfortunate reminder of just how frustrating and disastrous a driver can be.

I'm a pretty casual racing game player; I don't own a wheel, but I do enjoy playing all kinds of racing games with my controller, ranging from arcade titles like NFS to more serious titles like Forza Motorsport. Having that said, I've never seriously dabbled into a real sim like ACC, mostly because I don't own a wheel, but since it's on sale today I figured why not. I'm happy to report that it's very much playable with controller if you're just a casual driver. You might not be as fast as the fastest wheel drivers out there, especially if you use steer assist, but if you're just looking to have a good time, this game can be a lot of fun. I recommend getting the GT4 DLC if you're new to sim racing. GT4 cars are slower than their GT3 counterparts so you'll have an easier time learning the ropes with them, but they're also super fun to race with. Keep in mind that most people only race GT3 cars online, so you'll probably only get to use your GT4 cars in singleplayer.

These are my controller settings (found these somewhere on Reddit). I've found these to be really smooth. I play with stability assist off, and TC and ABS on. Increase your TC/ABS levels if you keep spinning out. Do a few test laps on your favorite track to get a feel for the cars, and be gentle on the steering if you're on controller.

Rumble Intensity 80%
Effects Type Enhanced

Deadzone 5%
Speed Sensitivity -75%
Steer Filter - 90%
Steer Speed - 100%
Steer Gamma - 1.5

Steer Assist - Enabled

Assetto Corsa Competizione is an absolute masterpiece that has raised the bar for racing simulations. From the moment I dove into the immersive world of GT3 racing, I was captivated by its stunning attention to detail and unparalleled realism.

The graphics in Assetto Corsa Competizione are simply breathtaking. The meticulously crafted tracks and beautifully rendered cars make every race feel like a true spectacle. Whether it's the gleaming sunlight reflecting off the sleek machines or the dynamic weather effects that challenge your driving skills, the visual fidelity is second to none.

But it's not just the visuals that shine in ACCâ€”the driving experience is where this game truly excels. The physics engine is so intricately designed that you can feel every nuance of the car's behavior. The way it grips the track, the weight transfer during braking and acceleration, and the subtle feedback through the force feedback steering wheelâ€”all of these elements combine to deliver an unparalleled sense of immersion.

ACC goes beyond just being a simulator; it captures the essence of GT3 racing. The attention to detail in the car models, the accurate sound design, and the comprehensive race weekend structure create an authentic racing experience. From practice sessions and qualifying rounds to heart-pounding multi-hour endurance races, the game offers a comprehensive and satisfying motorsport journey.

The multiplayer aspect of ACC is also a standout feature. The competitive online races, with their real-time weather and day/night cycles, bring an extra level of excitement and challenge. The matchmaking system ensures fair competition, and the active online community ensures that there's always someone to race against. Myself race a lot with LFM (Low Fuel Motorsports) and the competition there is absolutely amazing and fair. 

Moreover, the developers have demonstrated a commitment to improving the game over time. Regular updates and patches have addressed bugs, added new features, and expanded the content (I am racing with update 1.9 at the moment). The level of support and engagement from the development team is truly commendable.

In conclusion, Assetto Corsa Competizione is an exceptional racing game that sets new standards in the genre. Its breathtaking graphics, unrivaled physics engine, and authentic racing experience make it a must-have for any motorsport enthusiast. Whether you're a seasoned racer or a newcomer to the world of GT3 racing, this game will undoubtedly leave you in awe. Strap yourself in, hit the track, and prepare for an unforgettable racing experience!"

The good:
â€” Physics-wise, it's better than the first game.
â€” Graphics-wise, it's better than the first game.
â€” Sound-wise, it's better than the first game.
â€” I don't believe there's a better racing simulator (I haven't tried iRacing, rFactor 1/2 or Project Cars 1/2 yet).

The bad:
â€” Significantly smaller car selection, compared to the first game (all cars here are GT cars and I didn't find a single car with a manual transmission; and, oh boy, I really love using that manual gear shifter! (flappers don't count)).
â€” DLCs here are mostly licensed racetracks and are quite pricey.
â€” Mod-unfriendly (unlike the first game).
â€” The damage model is still a fÂ°kken joke. If a car doesn't break as a real car (at least approximately) would, this definitely has consequences about the way a person drives in this game (e.g. you don't care about your car in ReVolt, because it's basically invincible, so you drive like a madman; and that is precisely why ReVolt is not a simulator).


There exists a game that introduces this last really important part of reality, and it's called BeamNG.drive. So, my recommendation would be to get the old Assetto Corsa and BeamNG.drive and wait for Assetto Corsa 2.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/284160/BeamNGdrive/

Coming from the more "simcady" side of simracing (GT7, F12020) I struggled at first with ACC. Obviously the car handling is a lot more punishing than in GT7, but what surprised me the most was the absolute lack of assistance when it came to understanding how much fuel you need, or how you need to setup you car before a race. On top of that, all of the cars handle very differently, so it is important to try a few different ones in search for one (or a few) that you enjoy to drive. 

Now that I've gotten past those obstacles, I find playing ACC to be a very rewarding experience. The AI is excellent, and can be tuned both in skill and aggression. If you feel secure enough, you can join a league or try your luck in skillbased matchmaking. I strongly recommend downloading Crew Chief (its free) so that you get a proper race engineer and spotter to give you callouts during races.

The most disgusting game in the genre of racing simulators. Absolutely unrealistic incomprehensible physics with an absolutely absurd tire model and absolutely useless feedback and an empty center. A completely indifferent attitude to the balance of cars: one car can drive calmly for a whole second faster than all the cars in the game, and also lose a second in the opposite direction - and no one cares at all. Completely leaky car setups have absolutely nothing to do with physics. Just as disgusting as the standard settings - why do them according to real analogues if physics does not work at all in the same way as setups. I don't say anything about the brake at all - its easier to put it on the button and not think about what trail at all. I am also silent about the attitude of developers to their community: They change the balance of the machine - not words about it. They change the operation of springs - not words about it. SOME DUDE writes about all the changes on the forum (I don't know if he belongs to the developers).
If you want to improve in the field of racing simulators - go to iRacing

The best thing about the Competizione is that you can compete with others.   And it comes with every iconic race tracks such as the Francorchamp, Nurbering, Silverstone, etc.    The driving experience is much better than the non-competizone (Assetto Corsa) version.   

That is until the April 2023 upgrade.  The updated Competizone made the driving experience disappointing.  After over 300 hours spent on Competizone, the same driver (me), the same track, and the same car but my Nurbergring track time dropped over three seconds.  Three seconds!   I found myself spending less and less time by the day on the simulator.   I hope they will fix the problem on the next update.

Good points are that the wet track graphics are superb, it also has a drying line, and the tracks look nice and worn, the AI fights for places and defends fairly well. Also the GT cars are great and there are some major tracks in the game.

Bad points are there doesnt seem to be any AI mistakes or them getting mechanical damage that I have seen to date, so races can be a bit dull, the AI can ram you from behind if you get in their way. The rear view mirror is really laggy and pixellated - this is by far the worst thing about the game, I absolutely hate it.

It is a toss up whether this or AMS2 are the better racing game - AMS2 provides far more variety and exciting racing with better graphics and faster framerates, whereas this game has better AI generally, better GT cars, some really good tracks, plus really good wet track and rain graphics. I would recommend any racing fans buy both tbh as they complement each other really well.

Is this game for you?  Let's find out.  I love racing games both arcade and sim.  I have a love/hate relationship with this game due to the fact that it can be a ton of fun, but at the same time extremely unforgiving.  This game will take your lunch money, throw you in the mud and take your girl all in one afternoon.  It can also be very rewarding when you get it just right.  I am what I consider a slower pace racer, usually between 10th and 20th for qualifying, but I have also learned so much.  I watch racing, I enjoy racing, but I never got into the mechanics of it, like set ups, camber, tow, blah blah blah... This simulator makes you pay attention to all the little details that go into winning a race.  If you load in, don't bother with set ups then don't expect to beat anyone.  The top racers here are the best at what they are doing.  
A lot of people complain about the force feedback, but again, you have to adjust settings depending on what equipment you are running.  I have used several wheel and pedal combos and the set ups are all different.  You have to find your sweet spot and that takes time.  The games visuals are stunning, smooth frame rate, audio is amazing, (I love all the little creaks and squeaks of the car, engine, road...) and for the most part the community is amazing.  You will always have your crashers but some of that is just inexperience.  
If you enjoy GT class cars, this is THE simulator for you.  If you want to invest your time and really become a better racer, this will teach you.  You WILL struggle at first, don't give up, and when you get that first win, it feels amazing!!!  Now, get out there and have fun!  See you on the track.

No. This is trial by fire through negative reinforcement. You could be on your last lap of a 20 minute race and watch is all go down the drain with one wheel touching sand...

WARNING! 
ONly get this game if you like GT3/DTM class racing. otherwise there is NOTHING in this for you.

Outstanding sim experience --- it just feels right. If you race GT3s this is it. If you are coming from a simcade like Gran Turismo or Forza there is a world of difference in how you approach racing with Kunos and Assetto Corsa. There are some other excellent examples like AMS2 and iRacing, but out of the box ACC is the king. Turns out a focused approach on two race classes works best. The cost of entry is high unfortunately, as you'll need a rig setup to get the best experience and allow some time for tweaking your gear. I've been racing since Pole Position on Atari in the 80s, and remain amazed on how far we've come.

I have loved racing games since i stated playing them on PS2 with grand tarismo and burnout. I got this game because it allows you to play in vr. The vr performance is not great but i like the immersion. I use a controller to race because i dont have $300 to spend on a wheel/pedals and this game is particularly horrible with its default settings. the steering and breaking are too sensitive and often fuck u(you can change this but most people dont care too). Next: the piss poor set up tab. if you have any experiance in racing then set up is key but this game just does nothing to educate its community on how to use all of the settings and options. So if you dont have any experiance with that stuff then good luck. the basic setup it gives feels like your ass slides any time you really try to turn. 
AND now the beef that i have with the game...
The game it basically tag team racing where you have several drivers drive the same car and switch when you pit. I am running 40 min races. i play the WHOLE race and LEAD the WHOLE race cause the AI are slow as fuck on some tracks but are unbeatable on others(on 1 difficulty). I go into the last set of corners of the race and i spin and basically cut the next corner by going throught the grass during my spin so i just get on the track and continue thinking maybe i get a 5 sec penalty at max 10 right? WRONG. I get teleported to the pit lane and it says controls locked 2 min. so in the final 200 meters of the race i get fucked by the half assed rules in the game... i could wreck the entire field and get 0 penalty but i cut a corner 2 min time out and all that work gone.. my 1st place was taken by the bot that was 15 sec behind. 

the AI are follow the leader kind of racing AL very little passing or action its single file line racing but when you spin on track they dont move nothing they plow ur ass and dont give a fuck they will stick to that racing line like cocaine. what makes this worse is multiplayer is non existant i checked all race class lobbies and found a grand total of 17 people in online lobbies... truely heart breaking. 

i hope to find a good vr racing game with advanced AI and multiplayer lobbies

edit update: I have since purchased a logitech G29 then upgraded to a fanatec environment(CSL elite pedals, formula v2.5 wheel, and GT DD pro mounted on a playseat(fuck that company)) and have put several hundred hours across several titles and it has completely changed the genre for me. 

i still do not recommend this game to people who want to race casually, the F1 games are more forgiving, as most people i have raced with in multiplayer is about my pace maybe a little slower(i have top 5% time trial times on all tracks in F1 22 so im no slow boi) so these guys are FAST. the people who are significantly better are insane. they consistantly do 1-3sec better lap times than I can. Multiplayer is only really active on weekend days and usually on a hand full of tracks. After spending probably 40 hrs doing research on setups and all that I am starting to understand what to do and look for while driving but this is an advanced level driving skill beginners will be hard pressed to complete clean laps let alone consistantly drive at a pace to be able to detarmine what the car is doing. Just know you are as fast as the amount of time you put into understanding you car.

multipalyer: this game is one of 2 games that i will say that you RAREly see unsportsmanlike driving(like indentional crashes) and the other is iracing. I have only been wrecked on MAYBE 3-5 occcasions. People are usually very respectful of the space and leaving it for other drivers and when stuff does happen usually multiple players will speak up and tell the offending driver to get their act together. the only downside here is on week days the multiplayer can be unpopulated although they have daily compitention servers you need 80 safty rating to be able to praticipate which takes a long while to get when driving clean. the BEST part of ACC is the fact it is a GT racing game, only 1 class, therefore everyone playing only races GT and on a handful of tracks so most people know the braking points where to pass ect. It makes for racing that has much fewer incidences and more racing. you love to see it.

i have a friend that i am walking into sim racing i got him my G29 and we started iracing and regret it as it throws you into the thick of it. ACC guides you into the game and shows you a little about how to race and gives you the tools to be albe to improve with metrics and telemetry. I wish my friends sim racing learning experiance was in this setting and not the can be demo durby that is iracing

Assetto Corsa Competizione is what PES is compared to FIFA.

Amateurish garbage.Bought the game to play in VR. I doesn't support menu navigation with the quest controls. that's awful enough on its own, but i could live with it, "i'll just control it from the wheel" - I thought. Lol! It doesn't work either. It only controls from they keyboard and mouse, which is on the other fckn side of the room for me, incredibly inconvenient. "Ok, 'ill go there, map everything, launch a race and come back here". Lol, the menus do not show up on the flat screen while you're in VR. are you fkn kidding me? I ended up leaving the game and launching it in 2D mode to set it up. "Ok, i'll just enable the wheel, pick a profi--- where are the profiles?" THERE ARE NONE! YOU HAVE TO MANUALLY BIND EVERYTHING! Absolutely shitty considering i can't navigate menus with the wheel, so i have to go across the room for each fkn key i bind. Ok, done that, now i can navigate the menus with the wheel since i managed to map those controls on the wheel after a few minutes of pacing back and forth from the pc to the wheel. Now... a race. Finally. I sit down, reset my view, and get ready to go. Car doesn't move. I look at the driver's foot, and it's planted on both pedals... mine are not. Stupid game got the axis inverted. no, i'm done. refunding this garbage. Learn to make a proper finalized product, Kunos. It's been like 10+ years. it's well past time you stop delivering amateurish alpha garbage like this.

In general, graphics are great, menu/ui/ux is ok, optimisation is good. It's made with UE4.

I need to git gud to properly enjoy it but it's gonna take a lot of time. And I need to live with the fact that I'll never be as good as players with sim setups.

I can't comment on the career/single player mode, online experience etc cause I'm only practicing atm.

This is a first impression VR review on high end hardware. There is a metric ton of racing games available in VR right now, and since I can only race in VR (pancake racing might as well be an Atari 2600 game for its perceived immersion) my standards and expectations are high. I initially tried to VR this on a 2080ti and it was a slide show interrupted by bouts of 30-40 fps occasionally. I can max all settings on my 4090, and the game looks alright but not as great as most other VR offerings, and the racing is really just EH, so a hard pass with so many other epic VR options out there.

You have to develop real driving skills, and real knowledge of vehicle dynamics to get good at this. And I don't think the community will put up with the kind of dirty driving you see in lesser games.

After taking care of my control situation, I decided to tweak my black demon. They give you a HuracÃ n Super Trofeo that growls like a devil hissing for meat, demanding sacrifices in the temple of speed. The devs decision to start the career at Monza was just too right.

The dynamics are so beautiful and harmonical, so realistic, I could finally see why some pilots in history performed better during rainy weather, to experience that for the first time in my gaming life - ever. Guys like Ayrton Senna in the F1 category for example and so many others.

The fight is different during the rain in the real world, your worries are condensed and the car and the tires are sliced. Little to none beneficial things like cooler brakes and bad omens like thin layers of water under the tires. A driver in the rainy weather would prefer to use the best line to avoid that part of the track that still is wet, not just water puddles because it is more complex than that - the fight during rainy weather is different and this is simulated on where it should. ACC proved me Iâ€™m a rainy racer, having greater time results whenever Jupiter is angry.

That doesnâ€™t mean the casual should avoid it, but Iâ€™m afraid they would rather play something else, Competizione still can be tough even on easier modes. The setup isnâ€™t like Dirt Rally 2.0 for example, with bars to slide around even on advanced setups (youâ€™d see bars but itâ€™s different) you either know what youâ€™re doing or you do not. It is intuitive enough to keep you interested in it, experimenting, but you will need to know it anyway because there are not enough hints if youâ€™re out of place. There are only a couple of basic pre-settings, but very often theyâ€™re not enough, just a rough bet for the things youâ€™re going to face.

The hud seems overwhelming at first but you can remove things. I donâ€™t recommend that because the devs thought about everything, even swapping colors in the speed meter when you need to shift but got no time to look at it, meant to alert your peripheral vision.

[olist][*]The crowd people are what we call â€œcardboard audienceâ€ here where I live, very outdated. When the crowd is 3D (npcs from the pitstops for example) theyâ€™re badly animated. Weâ€™re not in 2006 anymore, so please.

[*]Rain sprites droplets are nasty, like most frames based graphics in this game are and it needs updating. It isnâ€™t better, not even in â€œepicâ€ settings. More particles are needed too.

[*]Not so rarely, impact sound effects are just repetitive even when youâ€™re performing something else not related to that. Youâ€™d hear some clanks and bumps when not clanking nor bumping, although minimal it is undermining the attention to details it already has.

[*]Artificial intelligence does suffer from the conditions of the track, but it could be better. Most super simulated games only think about you and your sweaty fights. AI needs to be prone to mistakes more often, maybe some sort of fear-factor and stress like humans do. I donâ€™t know how the hell they would do it, but it is awful to see that they don't do much.

[*]The game demands more identity, and the career mode is the way to do that. Youâ€™re welcomed by pilot Mirko Bortolotti himself trying to warn/prepare you for what is about to come, then not much is shown, game needs more style. Not just cosmetics but further expansion of career mode. I just think details arenâ€™t enough to rival other games right now.[/olist]

One word: Disappointed.

GT racing in AC, despite obvious physics limitations (one-point contact of the wheels), was very rewarding - you could feel whenever you made the corner right, each small setup change could be felt.
ACC lacks the above: GT4 are understeering all the time, even with extreme oversteer setups they just drive straight. GT3s feel just numb, despite using a DD wheel. The cars hover over the road, it almost feels like driving an arcade game.

ACC won't make you a better racing driver nor make you understand car setups better, it is just an overpriced disappointment...

While the game boasts impressive graphics, accurate physics, and an extensive range of cars and tracks, the damage model is a significant flaw.

In the game, the damage model is not as realistic as it could be, allowing toxic and idiotic racers to continue a race even after ruining everyone else's race. This can lead to frustrating game play experiences, especially in online races where reckless drivers can cause significant damage and ruin the fun for others.

One of the major issues with the damage model is that it does not accurately reflect the impact of collisions. Collisions that would cause significant damage in real life often result in only minor damage in the game, while minor collisions can cause substantial damage. This discrepancy can lead to frustration for players who expect a more realistic damage model.

Another problem is that the game does not always penalise drivers for reckless driving. While the game does have penalty systems in place, they are not always effective at discouraging reckless driving. As a result, some players continue to drive recklessly, causing damage to other players' cars and ruining the race for everyone involved.

Overall, Assetto Corsa Competizione is an excellent racing simulation game, but the damage model is a significant flaw. The game's developers should consider updating the damage model to make it more realistic and effective at discouraging reckless driving. Until then, players should be aware of the potential for toxic and idiotic racers and approach online races with caution.

yeh car sounds on 5.1 surround is amazing!, Focus is GT class only type tho you will find each car with subtle differences in brakes handling pitch etc every car n track is done to bring you the best simulation experience possible with teams data programmed in for each car n laser scanned tracks n great graphic it does an excellent job ..., with a very strong discord community n lfm , sgp . simgrid you can join leagues n compete on what level your at be it beginner or advanced . there is public lobby tho you can get jokers there on occasion so try find a league when your ready to race with others like yourself n you will love this ... you can play this at a basic level with standard pc old i7 2600 will be great with decent gpu gtx1060 series n above!., tho if you want to go VR or tripple montors n big grids your gonna be best with latest gens systems with Memory being the biggest factor in my experience. 

Also if your a beginner you need to learn about psi n basic car setup! tho saying that there are lots of video guides on youtube n the in game setups will get you up n running tho the tyres need to be adjusted to suit the conditions to get the best results. 

in short its a great simulation/game n a brilliant deal if you get it in the sales. 

also check out ArisDrives on youtube he is the physics developer who teaches you how to setup the car.

People here will say: Why would you want a H shifter, you would be alot slower?

TLDR: Small car selection but very detailed. Good selection of tracks with alot of favorites. Works great with quest 2 vr. Fantastic physics. Feels good on gamepad if you're on a budget like me. Small game (only 15 gigs). 100% recommend especially if you can get it on sale.

As a heads up ACC is focused purely on GT3 and GT4 ( gt4 added with gt4 dlc pack) so the car list is relatively small compared to other games in the space. With that said the cars that are in the game feel absolutely incredible with each one having a unique identity from one another and an insane level of detail in both visuals and how they drive. 

Visually itâ€™s what you can expect from a modern racing title: It looks gorgeous. As mentioned before the cars have been recreated in incredible detail and the same goes for the tracks youâ€™ll race on. From the weave of carbon fiber on the wings to the LEDâ€™s in the headlights no stone has been left unturned. 

As far as how the game feels it does a great job of communicating where the weight of the cars lie, as well as how hard you can push the cars on cold brakes and tires vs when their warmed up. The cars also have a good sense of weight to em so don't expect to take every turn at full speed or sideways like it's need for speed, though you will end up backwards if you're not careful. 

If you're looking for immersion past the monitor ACC has you covered with both wheel support and VR. I can't speak on how the force feed back feels as I use a controller, but as far as VR goes it's a great addition. I use a quest 2 via quest link ( connected to pc over wifi) and it was a very smooth experience that furthers the great sense of speed this game already has. 

I'd recommend a hefty pc if you're planning on using VR as I did have stuttering issues and had to lower my settings, but thankfully not enough where it would compromise immersion. Game starts at max in vr so if you're having stuttering issues I'd take a look at what you're settings are. 

All in all this is a fantastic sim to jump into especially if youâ€™re just getting into the scene. It might not be the best bang for your buck as itâ€™s limited to GT3 and GT4 however Iâ€™m not sure if youâ€™ll find a better representation of these cars anywhere else. There is a bit of a learning curve, but if you stick with it itâ€™s a ton of fun.

 As a final note if youâ€™re worried about being locked out of racing because of DLC, as of  the time of writing the only one thatâ€™s required is the intercontinental GT Pack (which imo is 100% worth it as itâ€™s composed of 4 fantastic tracks that are racing favorites) for competitive ranked racing. Otherwise the open multiplayer is usually racing on tracks that are already in the game so you wonâ€™t have issues there unless youâ€™re looking to race in GT4 cars. With that said Iâ€™d still recommend picking up the GT4 pack and Intercontinental GT pack especially if you can get them on sale.

This is the current STANDARD for GT3 based driving games.  This said after a LONG time ownership there are a few things to note.

The Force feedback is very sadly LACKING compared to other sims ( AMS2, rFactor 2. )  Mid corner fidelity is simply NON existent.  You also have NO warning when you over brake and go into a slide this will catch you out SO OFTEN.

The tire model though pretty good has such a tiny window for recovery from over driving once the tires break loose you basically just hold tight and wait for it to stop there is no degree of slip at all.

Don't get me wrong this can be a FUN sim to drive but you better be with people that understand it's limitations otherwise you will just have a crash fest and get VERY frustrated Very fast.

Pros: 
A pretty complete GT3 and GT4 experience.
Pretty good physics and adequate FFB. Update 1.8 added much but still somewhat inferior to Rfactor2.
Great reproduction of tracks. Standard of tracks and cars more uniform and often better than what's found in Rfactor2.
Pretty good telemetry support, works well with MOTEC. Some variables are missing by design, which detracts from the experience.  Setup is VERY important for on-track performance. Setup interface is more user friendly than RFactor2. Monthly challenges are motivational and great practice for online races (that demand proper setup, fuel management, tyre management and an eye to changing weather)

Cons:
Safety Rating system not very well developed, so cannot recommend online racing on public servers. Both players involved in contact get penalized for any accident, regardless of whose fault it is. This makes it hard to accumulate safety rating to get access to servers that actually race clean, and once you accumulate it you are wary to get docked.I will admit that the official competition servers which requires high safety rating races somewhat cleaner that the rubbish public servers.

Car control and consistency rating are nice learning tool, but discourages practice with new cars, tracks and setups if you care to maintain you overall rating. It drops rather quickly unless you drive perfect from the getgo. Then you have to grind your best track in your  main car to get it back up. Edit: Ratings can be suspended from options menu, which solves this problem. Edit2: Oh yes, turning of ratings disables recording of your fastest laptime. Why is that? How come active ratings are  a prerequisite for documenting fastest lap? I mean, the hotlap functionality is completely unrealistic, the car resetting damage, tyre wear, temperatures, minimal fuel load every lap. Show some consistency here, kunos.

Verdict: Great ambiance. Complete GT-package with cars and tracks. Physics and FFB much improved since launch, but still somewhat inferior to Rfactor 2. Fair competition servers. Godawful safety rating system.  Deplorable public servers.

Edit 2022: Changed recommendation from "NO" to "YES". Not perfect, but the most complete package for drivers interested in GT3. 

Edit 2022 v2.0 - Safetyrating system still broken. Changed  recommendatino to NO.

Edit 2022 v3.0 - Safetyrating stiill very much broken. Safety rating hovering in the mid-90, you get docked nearly 1 full point of safety rating per contact, regardless whose fault it is. Every single point may take several hours of "work" to recoup. Unacceptable, and very much a detriment to enjoying this otherwise good simulator.  The  REAL GT3 world challenge championship is awarding way less penalties for contact during real-world races.This along with superior physics makes Rfactor 2 a more attractive proposition for both sim-racer purists and  gentleman racers. When will Kunos learn?

Edit 2022 V4.0. Yep. Safety rating still broken. Now high 80s after a high watermark at mid 90s. I got replays showing me on the racing line, driving in predictable manner and being tapped by AI trying to overtake. Single contact results in multiple OBWPs further docking my rating through no fault of my own. Disgusting.

I admit it is a game that is difficult to get a grasp of. The on/off breaking feels a bit artificial at start, but they say it is realistic. I don't know, never driven a real GT3 car, but I can say that the car balance physics are very natural, or at least, make sense, jumping off the break will cause a completely different reaction to trail braking smoothly. 
The game allows for a fascinating degree of control over the car through playing with it's balance. It's hard to get, but once you start to feel it, the game opens up greatly and you discover more and more points where you can improve your lap times.

Assetto Corsa Competizione is an incredibly realistic and immersive racing simulator that offers an incredibly enjoyable experience for all levels of racers. The graphics, physics, and sound are all top-notch and the level of detail and customization that can be achieved is remarkable. The game also comes with a variety of tracks, cars, and options that can be adjusted to suit any style of racing. The AI is quite challenging and takes some getting used to, but it provides a satisfying experience as you progress and become a better driver. Overall, Assetto Corsa Competizione is an incredibly fun and realistic racing simulator that offers an incredible and realistic racing experience. Highly recommended!

I have had this game since launch. For the first 2-3 years of the game I did a lot of single player AI races, as well as the occasional open lobby. I had fun playing this way for a long time. However, I always felt like I was missing out. None of my friends were into simracing, so it was just me. Summer of 2021 I joined a North American community and realized I had not really played the game proper yet. Racing with a good community brought some SERIOUS competition, and I saw myself get faster and faster every season. Now I am around 101% alien if I really grind a track. Find a community that fits you, and jump in. For the most part, simracers are very friendly and want new people!

Of course now you have LowFuelMotorsports that does hourly races, as well as endurance racing. It is set up a lot like iRacing. This is a fantastic option for you to find people around your skill level and just jump into a race.

Like any other simracing game, this game has some issues here and there. From a physics perspective, I think this game is among the best. I would say the weakest part of ACC are the curb physics. It isn't game breaking, but curbs seem to be more deadly than in real life. And also there is no floor damage, so yeeting curbs doesn't give you damage. Kunos has been good about BOP'ing cars, and trying to keep them balanced.

If you are into simracing, this game is 100% worth your money. This game has done nothing but improve since released. It is one of the cheapest games for competitive simracing.

Not a game for Average Joe. The simulation is amazing and would be great fun, but good input for good simulation is only possible with dedicated hardware (e.g. steering wheel), otherwise it's like driving a real GT3 car with a GamePad, except gamepad support is not the greatest. This can be partially mitigate by using Steam Input, providing settings the game itself doesn't provide, but you cannot fully open up the game without a steering wheel. There are settings to tune steering input and after hours of painful tests you might finally find something that kind of works for you. Same for the gas, but it was even more painful for me and only Steam Input curve customization made it work in the end. Unless you are racing enthusiast with a steering wheel and are very committed to learn how to drive, steer clear of this game. Otherwise, this is an awesome game and you will have a lot of fun with it.

Just happily voted for this sim for the "Labor of Love" Award. The sim has limitations due to the Unreal Engine yet KS still managed to get a lot out of the engine. The graphics are good, the physics are good, tyre model is impressive, sound is solid, and the VR is "serviceable." I say serviceable because I can get a steady framerate with the openXR mod, circumventing SteamVR and several other tweaks. I have heard that the 4090 is the path to go that will bring this sim up to snuff with some other VR-Cockpit offerings. With all of that being said, KS managed to take a small component of motorsports and really flesh it out better than most of the "one size fits all" competition. Finally, the racing line seems more intuitive in this sim than any other sim I've ever played. No need for the visual indicator.

Assetto Corsa Competizione is the best sim racing title out there. The sim has the perfect combination of physics and graphics. Unlike many sim racing titles, ACC has great weather dynamics. All the DLCs so far have been high quality and AI behavior is mostly on point. The only downside I could really point out is the VR integration, since it is quite taxing, but still playable for the mid-range GPUs. For the controller racers, it is extremely challenging to race with a controller, so even though you maybe can pull it off, I would still suggest playing only on a steering wheel. Overall, if you are into GT racing or want to get into GT racing ACC is a must have.

just an awesome game

If you are looking for some GT car racing this is probably your best choice. You can choose between a gt3 car that is older gen and new gt cars from the latest era(2022 and onwards). As a matter of fact a new championship, the 2022 one, has been added with the latest update. There's also gt4 cars that you can race on, coming with dlcs, and more, such as the Ferrari 488 gt3 challenge evo, the bmw m2 cs racing version and the list goes on. 
The physics are very true to what real gt racing feels like and the devs are working very closely with the teams/brands to produce an as close as it can get 1:1 picture. 
There's a variety of tracks(with dlc you'll get a track from almost any continent). The attention to detail can be observed at those tracks. Such could be the draining rails on kyalami or the bumps and sausages on Zolder. 
Updates come and go and 90% of the time they are quite meaningful(having to do with gameplay/bugs/ui etc).
If you are looking into more serious racing there are also leagues that you can take part. Some of the daily ones can be found at the LowFuelMotorsport site and on the pitskill.io site. You can participate weekly on some leagues that you can find on SimGrid,SRO and lots of other sites.
All in all, acc gives you the experience of a polished gt car racing sim that is being refined at its next updates and taken seriously.

2022 Nov Update - 
I have been trying out other sims in last few months, I dont feeling the same about ACC anymore and updating the review.

Engineering Sim not Racing Sim - Tire temperature is a big deal in ACC, that's a barrier for me. You can't just hop in do a sprint, you have to do practice laps to get the setup right. You need to join a league to get quality races. It's fun to drive but too many hassles. There's no concept of fixed setup races. 

Setup Scam - There are paid setups from 3rd party, which is fine but ACC advertises them in-game with track side banners. You pay for the game, the game gives default setups and then markets paid setups by taking money from them, does ACC deliberately provide bad setups to make the paid setups better? 

Ugly - And the Graphics, I stopped playing it mainly because it looks grainy, out of focus, undersaturated and weird contrast. Modded AC1 looks better, it looked fine a year back, now it's all muddy.

The American DLC is another disappointment. 

AI is the worst among all Sims, they drive like they are following an Ambulance. 
The Career mode has not got updated Cars, you drive 2018 cars 4 years later. 


Old Review - 
Probably the best Sim Racing game out there. 
The handling is predictable, the sounds are great, the AI is professional. 
The Tracks are detailed, you feel the road like your do on a bicycle. 
You can even play it single player and save long endurance races to go poop. 
The rating system is well designed. too late to review already at 250 hours play time (which is actually on the lower side, should play it more).

Simply the best GT sim there is. In the absence of a lottery win I can't go racing for real. But this must be the next best thing. I bought ACC on launch day for the PS4. I gave up waiting on PS5 so went back onto PC after several years away. ACC was one of the main reasons.

I now prefer watching GT racing over all other motorsport. Made it to Oulton Park in 2020 when spectators were allowed. Oh and spent a week in the Ardennes on holiday in 2022...so I could watch the 24h of Spa... Now THERE'S a tangible marketing outcome!

Massive "THANKS" to everyone at Kunos, SRO, and anyone else responsible for developing ACC into the great package it is today. I appreciate AC2 will open the door to Prototypes, TCR, and the 'other' classic 24h tracks... Which I'm really looking forward to! But please consider having a skeleton crew keep the lights on at ACC until AC2 is in-service. I'm sure it would keep a lot of us happy :)

Titles like this make me wish there was a middle "Meh" button. The game seems fantastic, especially its multiplayer lobby. HOWEVER, as many VR users have stated in their reviews, the VR performance is unacceptable. I tried all of the possible tweaks to maximize performance and finally got it to a point where it ran mostly smoothly but looked like I was in a PS1 game, which is antithetical to the immersive experience you seek in virtual reality... For reference, VR runs flawlessly with my Quest 2 on my system with other VR-compatible racing titles.

Seeing as I don't have a big monitor or a triple-monitor setup, VR is my best option for optimal FOV and immersion, so since ACC can't accommodate that, I can't enjoy it in its current state.

That being said, for users with a wide, curved monitor or a triple-monitor setup, I think you'll have a lot of fun. The physics, handling, and multiplayer lobby are great. 

It just doesn't work as a VR title as its advertised. If they can fix this in the future, I'd gladly pick up a copy again and change my review to recommended.

ACC on console was my introduction to the hobby two years ago. In the interim I've upgraded to PC and bought a rig. Despite using and enjoying other sims (iRacing, AMB2, etc.), ACC remains the experience I consistently come back to. 

For my money, ACC is still the genre's gold standard: challenging but rewarding, deep but varied enough to be stimulating. 

There's an argument that Kunos has been too steadfastly focused on realism for its own good--I can think of a number of tweaks that would SIGNIFICANTLY enhance the experience--but they're also a relatively small developer, and they understand that lack of focus has killed companies far larger than them.

Assetto Corsa Competizione is the best racing simulator available on Steam right now. Kunos Simulazioni focused solely on GT World Challenge when developing this game, and they nailed it. This game immerses you in the sensation of driving GT3 cars on licensed tracks, and the physics, tyre performance, and sound design enhance this sensation.

Despite the fact that the regular version of the game is already outstanding, the DLCs are worth mentioning separately. Each DLC contains several new tracks or cars that I highly recommend checking out after you've gotten used to the basic cars and tracks. The game's balance allows you to win with basic cars, but there are several worthy tracks in add-ons, as well as a whole new class of GT 4 cars that are extremely fun to play with.

There is a large community surrounding the game, as well as public servers with high online, which offer great multiplayer opportunities. In this case, I would recommend learning about on-track behavior and focusing on consistency rather than speed on a single lap. Nobody ever wins a race on the first lap, especially in endurance racing. So grab your wheel, itâ€™s time to burn rubber!

If you are purely looking for GT3 racing and no other classes then this is awesome, the physics and feel seem spot on,  this is at the moment my go to sim for racing

The incredibly blurry image in VR is purely confounding. The only resolution for this issue (haha, a pun!) is to tweak the video settings via manually changing config files, along with getting a hold of open source DLL files. Even after all these changes, the picture quality barely makes it up to average.

Aside from not actually being iRacing for it's multiplayer, every other facet of this game is amazing. The way the cars interact with the road, the way the force feedback feels and the championship mode to introduce you to the GT3 racing format. Fantastic. Just a shame that the state of the VR has been left to languish like this for years.

This is not a promising outlook for an Assetto Corsa 2 release based on the lack of support being provided by the developer in this situation.

Edit: If you'd like to play ACC in VR, google "acc vr racedepartment" and go see the definitive VR Performance Guide.

I never really was into GT3, especially not in the original AC. However, I tested it during the free weekend and it just feels right ;-)

In the beginning, I missed the absence of achievements, but in a way, the ranking system are your achievments. The ranking system is a nice addition and it helps if you race online (since you can join servers with good safety ratings). Even if you're not the fastest, you can have some good battles in the mid-field (or behind). The AI seems good so far (no stupid crashes).

The Special Events are sometimes interesting. The career itself...mixed feelings. It's not bad, but in a way I miss season standings and stuff like that. It's all about earning medals and points. So most probably the normal championship may be the better solution once you finished the career.

Of course I'm still dreaming of something like an AC Legends as a sequel to Grand Prix Legends. If somebody could do it right, then Kunos. I know it will remain a dream though.

I play 100% in VR  with a HP reverb G2 on a 3080GPU @100% resolution in forced reprojection mode (game renders 45fps then VR fills in the gaps to create 90fps)

--VR UPDATE - same rig but using the latest 'Opencomposite' (OpenXR) to remove the need for SteamVR I can now get rock solid 90fps with a full grid - It's worth the effort of setting it up and tweaking to get there--

Yes, it's really badly optimized for VR, and the unreal engine probably will never address this. No, I wouldn't recommend it in VR for anyone with less than a 3070 GPU or equivalent. Yes, the original Assetto Corsa running Sol looks better in many ways and runs far smoother never missing a beat at 90fps and high/very high settings...

But tweaking the settings down a little, and reducing anti-aliasing gets me to a place where I get zero frame drops, even on a 20 car grid start and reprojection mode looks better in ACC than many other VR games I play.

Once you get to this reasonably happy place you can finally start having fun; the driving model, sound design and force feedback are amazingly immersive. It's the little things, like the noise of the brakes as you leave it late into turn 1 at Monza, the sound of the chassis and car floor as you cut over a kerb that you really should have avoided and the feeling of the back end trying to get away from you on overcooked tyres.

The longer you play, the more you see the skill and effort that's gone into it. I'm just glad I persisted to get to a graphics setting that worked so that I can now appreciate why ACC gets the praise it does.

IN the next few days DLSS gets added too - so those lucky enough to have an RTX card should find it even easier to get to graphics settings that do the game justice.

Disclaimer: This review is being made as a warning for anyone who is planning on playing this game in VR. Doubly so if you have an Oculus Quest 2. I fully intend on playing this game more in the future but based on my current experience with the game I would advise anyone playing on VR to steer clear of this game.

To recap my time with the game so far:
After 3+ hours of tuning the games graphics settings, watching multiple youtube tutorials, tuning my graphics card settings, tuning the oculus software settings, tuning my fan profiles, and overclocking my GPU the game is now just barely clear enough that I was able to complete the opening career assessment practice at Monza. Of course the very next part of the career mode had rain making everything a blurry unplayable mess again. Guess its back to tuning the graphics for me....

Silver lining though, the original assetto corsa, project cars 2, and dirt rally 2 (all of which had almost flawless performance right out the box btw) now look unbelievably gorgeous and I have a new found appreciation for a developers ability to properly optimize their game to run in VR.

ACC is one of the best racing sims available. Not much content compared to some other sims but a very refined game imo.

ACC is the official SRO GT racing game, it focuses mainly on GT3 cars and tracks from the SRO championships. The base game has 11 track locations, DLCs add another 11 locations as well as additional cars. Unlike AC1 ACC doesn't support mods, but the overall quality of the game makes up for the lack of mods imo, and if you get base game + all DLC there's enough replay value to keep you occupied for a long time.

My PC specs: i7 4790, 16GB RAM, GTX 1060 6GB, Windows 10 Pro. ACC looks really good at 1080p60fps but it can be demanding on hardware. I run with most settings on high and the game performs well with 30 cars on track. Sounds are also good. Controller support is really good (probably the best controller support out of all the racing sims I play), there's a few more options for customizing controls compared to AC1, I use my own custom controller settings and controls feel very responsive & smooth with my Xbox 360 controller, and controller vibration is very helpful to know when the car is losing traction or when I go too aggressive on the curbs. 

Handling of the cars is very consistent. Cars are challenging to drive on the limit but feel intuitive and predictable. Both safe & aggressive setup presets work well depending on car and track. All tracks in the game are laser-scanned and super accurate (track layout, elevation changes, curbs, trackside objects, etc). Since ACC is the official game of SRO GT racing it uses racing rules from that championship, meaning there's only timed races and no lap-based races, you have the option to have either 1 or 2 races per race weekend, and the option to enable mandatory pitstop. There's dynamic weather, full 24hr cycle, and track evolution. Career mode is very bare bones but there's custom championship. 
AI is good in terms of race pace but their racecraft is bad: they always block me in practice & qualifying during their outlap, and during races even with aggression on low setting I have to give them plenty of space otherwise they might hit me and push me off the track. Once you learn how to deal with them offline races against AI can be very challenging and fun.

Base game is short on content (especially tracks) but if you like GT racing you definitely should get the base game and at least all the track DLCs. The high quality of cars & tracks in the game makes this one definitely worth it imo.

I'm one of those sim racing dweebs. I play this game and other similar ones on a hardware setup that I've spent too much time and effort on, all so I can try and pretend I'm driving a real car, let's face it that's why we're all here.

We all want to be max Verstappen except GT3 cars are easier to drive so we grab our pretend steering wheels and flock to circuits like spa-francorchamps and only spa because we're simps like that. We destroy each other on T1 and argue about who was to blame, we look for another lobby to sign in to, get destroyed at T1 again, have another argument and we f#%$ing love it.

Sometimes you avoid the first lap chaos and participate in what is commonly reffered to as a motor race. These moments are special and it's during these moments you see how good this game really is.

We all like to pretend we know how a real race car feels to drive then use our self perceived knowledge to judge racing games on accuracy, but realistically only a very small amount of people who have played this will have had a real life comparison point. They say it's pretty good so I'll take their word for it.

This game feels amazing to drive, I don't think there's another game avaliable right now which translates detail in car behaviour as well as this one does.

The detail sent to your hands through the force feed back, the sounds of not just the engine, the sound of your car reacting to every bump, curb, corner or even pebble put together with the visual experience is in my opinion unparalleled.

I've tried every major racing simulator I can get my hands on and ACC does the best job at making me feel like I'm driving a real car. I just pray that I soon see other games come out representing other types of cars with this level of detail and quality.

It's been 4 years since the initial release of Assetto Corsa Competizione. I remember when Richard Burns Rally and GTR were new games. Back then it has been the norm to release well-polished product free of bugs and glitches, with all the content a user may want with no DLCs. That was then. Times have changed. Today the release of the new title brings the promise that the game will be finished in some vaguely defined timeframe. In most cases developers fail to meet the deadline and promises of incredibly immersive gaming experience never come true. Words are cheap. This is true with Assetto Corsa Competizione.

One may think that 4 years can be enough to hone and polish the game. Apparently, it's better to milk users by releasing car packs and track DLCs, than to make the game actually playable. It's just lazy attitude on Kunos part. The game is broken on a fundamental level and I am going to explain that in detail.

Broken physics.

ACC physics are worse than the original Assetto Corsa. Worse than RRRE, worse than BeamNG Drive, worse than original Simbin titles like GTR, GT Legends, Race and so on. rFactor 2 comparison is laughable.

Tires. Tire is the only physical object that connects the car to the road surface. The tire model has to be nailed 100%. Whole gameplay depends on that. You may have all the fancy gravity simulations, weight distribution and suspension kinematics, but with failed tire simulation all efforts in recreating real life physics are pointless. The grip is bad. While you can maintain some grip on a straight, keeping the car planted inside the turn is a gamble. To put it by Ermin Hamidovic's terms, it's like driving on calculations instead of the rubber. There's very vague distinction between rubber compounds (wet or dry). There's no feel of rubber whatsoever. No feel of contact points transferring your inputs, no feel of road surface, no feel of tire flex, nothing. You can't sense neither what front nor rear wheels are doing.

Cars in ACC have understeer problem and it feels like developers are not familiar with the concept of rotation. No matter what you do, you can't rotate the car inside the turn. Oversteer is present only in the form of severe grip loss. There's no "in between", it's either the battle to turn the car against all odds or 100% grip loss. 

Cars feel heavy. There's the distinction of weight distribution between front-engine, mid-engine and rear-engine cars â€” I give Kunos that, but the way the car reacts to steering input... The best analogy I can come across is Need For Speed. No kidding. In ACC you drive the same heavyweight refrigerators with wheels, but with added complexity on top.

The rating system.

Despite having single player career mode, ACC is meant to be 100% a multiplayer game, so Kunos developed complex safety rating system that collects the data from your inputs: trajectories, acceleration, braking, crashes, etc, on which the game builds up your profile for fair matchmaking. The track is divided in segments. Every segment gets the rating based on how clean was your driving throughout the section. Red, orange, yellow, green â€” the cleaner your driving is, the "greener" the segment will be. Ideal lap will have all the segments labeled green. The bad lap will have all the segments labeled red. You get the idea.

The problem with the system is that it punishes you for 1 wheel getting slightly off the track, by reducing overall score, but does nothing to punish you when you cut deliberately. For instance, in Zolder you can cut through 3 chicanes in a straight shot at 200 km/h. The game will give you "green" rating while displaying the message that the lap time will not count. In real life you'd get DSQ'd immediately for such bravery. In ACC I can cut through corners like nobody's business while gaining 10 seconds per lap. I can overtake the leader after flying into the gravel trap. All of the opponents may pass me by and I will still regain the lead later.

Kunos should stop embarrassing themselves by having a rating system effed like that. You can just compensate all the physics engine issues by ignoring to follow track limits. Easy-peasy: you will get 1st position at the finish line no matter what, just cut, cut, cut. Yes, your score will suffer, but hey, the 1st place is still the 1st place, who cares about those rules! Pity I can't turn NFS-style by flying into a wall @300 km/h.

By the way, no matter who's to blame in a crash event, both opponents receive the punishment. The game doesn't draw the line between light touch or the sheer ram fest. It doesn't matter if you're the victim of some toxic no-lifer behind the wheel or dumb AI, you will receive the punishment regardless. Which leads us to...

The dumbest AI ever.

Oh boy. These buggers don't recognize you on the track. They don't respect your trajectory and make no evasive maneuvers whatsoever. If you happen to be on their way, they will ram you hard. I can't remember AI in any gaming genre to be THAT stupid. Counter Strike 1.6 has bots more clever than that. With AI so dumb why bother with the career mode at all? When the AI car is in front of you, AI will deliberately slow down, so you have to smash the brake pedal. AI will deliberately send you into the barrier, AI will timewarp towards you if you happen to be too fast for the game. I'm getting strong Need For Speed vibes there. â€œCatch-upâ€. Sounds familiar.

Bugs.

You can drive through cars on pit lane, there will be no crash. The game sometimes has a will of its own: the game will push the gas and turn the steering wheel without you touching any controls. Gotta call my fellow exorcist to figure that out.

Missing functions.

The game doesn't give you the ability to assign the throttle and brake response (only brake power and bias can be altered in individual vehicles). I get that Kunos is proud of their simulation of real-life traction control system used in GT3 cars, but I want to fine-tune the throttle input the way I like, especially for the cars like Porsche 992, which has no TC. rFactor 2 and RRRE allow that. Also, hard-locked 3rd person camera is annoying as hell. Some free movement is a must for 3rd person view, because when the car loses traction, hard-locked camera may disorient the player trying to correct the slide. 80% of the time players use cockpit view, which Kunos nailed perfectly, but hey, it's still the game. Sometimes I want to get less claustrophobic gaming experience, because on the sim rig with only 1 monitor the peripheral view is limited and altering FOV to UWA messes up with the distance perception. I drive 50/50 cockpit/3rd person view. YMMV.

Internet security problem.

Recent DDOS attack on the server uncovers another area where Kunos cuts corners. Maybe they have this "we're just a small company" mentality, but when important race is being spoiled by DDOS attack, it's inexcusable.

This is a serious racer. It has a steep learning curve but it is hugely rewarding when you start to get good! 

For me this is a huge step up from the likes of Grid/Forza/Gran Turismo which I have spent many hours with before. 

It looks absolutely amazing and the handling and physics make a lot of other other racing titles feel poor in comparison.

Its good for single player vs AI/Hotlaps and online. It has a really good in game driver skill rating system to help you improve your driving skills. 

I have finally switched to cockpit mode since playing on bumper cam since the days of Ridge Racer on PS1 and its great.

Highly recommended.

Good sim. Terrible engine.

I am reviewing this game from a purely VR perspective. Currently I would not recommend it to anyone for VR. There are some workarounds to gain a couple of FPS but sadly the choice of engine has clearly made this game exclusively a pancake game.

If you play on a monitor/monitors I highly recommend this title. The level of detail in graphics/sounds/physics is top notch. Plus you get a ton of content for a one time purchase, plus you get affordable DLC content every now and then. The work Kunos are putting in this title is great. 

What isn't great is the choice of engine and VR optimisation (or the lack of it).

With updates the VR performance has gotten better but I fear with how the game is built, there is a kind of a performance ceiling in unreal engine and it's implementation (or Kunos implementation).

For example the original tracks all are ok to run in VR with a lot of tinkering in the settings (and outside the settings for all kinds of openfsr/openxr/nvidia control panel workarounds) but when new content is released it is painfully obvious the new tracks do not have that same amount of polish/optimisation as the original tracks which have been updated many times over. So then you have to wait for Kunos to "catch up" and start working on optimising the new content.

Overall I am just very sad this game doesn't (and might never) run in VR properly. For the record I did get it running at around 60 fps but you have to sacrifice SO MUCH visual quality in terms of graphics details/anti-aliasing/render resolution it is simply making me sad. Especially when I go back to iRacing and it actually looks better to me and runs at a higher resolution? I mean, that game is like a billion years old and it looks better than ACC with all the graphics settings maxed out? So sad...

Maybe when I get a triple screen setup or an ultra-wide monitor I will play more but for now I do not recommend it for VR.

Once upon a time there was a game called TOCA Race Driver 2 and whilst playing it I fell in love with Mount Panorama and the Bathurst Race. Well that game is long gone, this game is sixteen years younger and fortunately my steering wheel set-up is too, but I'm back on my favourite track (Bathurst and Laguna Seca were DLC, but worth it) and loving every moment. Sadly my reactions are sixteen years older than they were, but my times are getting quicker and when I am bored with Bathurst I have two other favourites to play with, Monza and Laguna Seca. This is a great game, easy to get into but as complicated as you want to make it, I ditched automatic gears and ideal racing line after five minutes, but still using an automatic  clutch, it is customisable to to a level where you are comfortable with it and has easy to navigate menus which makes finding the right mode , track and car very easy (not always the case with racing games). Graphically it is a pleasure to look at and the physics feel right, feed the power in too soon coming out of a bend and feel that rear get squirrelly, fail to catch it and  you are in the gravel pointing the wrong way. Seven hours in I have only scratched the surface, but I already know this will be a long time favourite. Oh, forgot to say, it lets you practice any track with any car, none of that having to unlock tracks as you progress through a career! I love it.

Ah ACC.

In the beginning I brought you with my refund money for Cooking Sim VR as something i play in a stop gap before buying Iracing, but in the past few weeks i've grown to love you...

In the beginning I thought it was nothing much, i jumped into a single player race, felt the AI were okay and then found the M4 GT3 at the height of its OP(ness) and jumped straight online! I didn't understand anything and then left for Iracing... But that wasn't the end..

I've been slowly getting back into this game in the last 2 weeks, picking a car and just driving...

At first, sit in Practice by yourself, learn yourself! How you drive, what you need to change to be quicker with the car of choice, Right, you feel you're half decent, now look at a quick lap. Don't cry in a corner start looking into the setups, CHANGE TO BRAKE PAD 1 FOR THE LOVE OF GOD! *ahem* Now see how the game makes the car faster round the track! Tire Pressures, Temps! aha, I have no clue... Now go ponder if you should buy a setup for a game you are really only just starting in... Bite the bullet and immediately love it!! Now you have some speed, now... Learn about Multiplayer...

See that SA is really important and then realise all public lobbies are death traps, along with all of them running Monza, T1 is genuinely the stuff of nightmares EVERY. GODDAMN. TIME... Somehow get to 80 SA and now start looking at orgs outside of ACC...

LFM, RCI...

When you get to this part...

You find the amazing drivers... Just be prepared to race the same track 15 times a day...

This is where I am in ACC, doing my first enduro soon, my experience has only just started... When are you starting yours?

ok so this game started out pretty bad. its gotten a LOT better since my initial review, so i should update that. smooth performance can still be an issue sometimes, even with a stout rig. vr performance still leaves a bit to be desired. thats realistically about the worst i can say about it at this point though. physics are vastly improved, plenty of content, a pretty solid tire model, and there are now groups dedicated to running an iracing-like rating and racing system. if gt3 is your thing, this one is hard to beat. my final point, the install base is still pretty low compared to iracing. those are basically your 2 best choices for gt3 these days. this one does some things better, iracing does other things better. what ACC does do, it does very well. im still not going to outright recommend the game though, as every update they break the physics in new and exciting ways. also. absolutely zero consequences for griefing. literally none. the single most pathetic thing i have ever seen. and i watched a thousand idiots storm the capitol.

+ by far, the best physics of any sim yet. Tyre model recently updated to new 2020 compound
+ cars respond to car setup changes really well
+ car behaviour is predictable and allows you to drive on the edge without unrealistic surprises. The fidelity of the physics through the FFB is very noticable.
+tyre model is outstanding. You can feel the slip angle of the tyre and the way it moves and behaves over kerbs and bumps on the track. 

+ Visually, looks fantastic with post-processing (especially at Dusk)
+ car sounds are excellent
+Dev support is decent. The last DLC package was Imola and both the 2020 Mercedes and Ferarri Evo for $8 AUD

Edit (13.07.2022):
After ~200 more hours on record I am really enjoying it now. ACC is not a game for quick fun. You have to bite through the first 50 hours, look up the regulations for GT3 racing, learn how to find a racing line, learn how to brake properly, getting the tyre pressures right, learn how to savely(!) overtake others (or let others pass), ...
But when everything comes together and you are finally able to do consistent lap times or drive through Raidillon in heavy rain at night without ending up in the wall, it is so much rewarding and  still puts a smile on my face.

*I have only played this game in VR so I have no experience playing outside of VR
I originally thought that I was going to get bored with this game very quick seeing as it was only the GT World Challenge cars. However, I was sorely mistaken. The game feels very immersive. Unlike its older brother Assetto Corsa, Assetto Corsa Competizione (ACC as I'll refer to it from now on) sounds absolutely amazing. You can hear the marbles going under you tires and through the wheel wells. You can hear every little bump and knock that the car takes throughout the whole drive of the circuit. In fact, the first lap I did in the game I genuinely thought that I had broke something on the car while taking a kerb, as one would through the turn 1 on Monza, because I had never heard such a sound in any other sim racing game that I have played (I've played Assetto Corsa, Rfactor 2, and Project Cars 2). You can hear the suspension creak and pop as you go over some of the rougher kerbs in the game as well as if you go in the grass. The cars also sound very good in ACC. The popping of the backfire, and the individual sounds of each car manufacture engine makes me feel like I'm genuinely on a track in a Mercedes AMG with a Lamborghini and a Ferrari on either side of me. The game not only sounds breathtaking, but the game is visually breathtaking as well. I'm lucky enough to have a 3070 Ti so of course that helps a lot, but the game runs very well in VR on medium settings for me. The game is super smooth whether it be while doing a night time race in the rain or on a nice sunny perfect day. The game is visually stunning. I feel like anyone could get a solid amount of time played with just the base game. I personally wanted some of the DLC and with only 4 out of the 6 DLC I still haven't gotten bored with the game yet. Yes, you can't race an LMP1 or Formula 1 car in ACC, but I feel like the game is good enough audio wise, visually and content wise that I never find myself saying, "Man I wish I could rip around in an F1 car right now on this game." After all that's why Assetto Corsa and other sim racers are available, to race any kind of car you want. This is its own sim racer and is an improvement on Assetto Corsa, just without the modding and variety of different types of cars. Physics wise I feel like the game has improved and so have the AI. The force feedback feels a little bit more immersive and the AI actually know how to properly block and pass and even can be forced into making mistakes. I believe that if you are an avid sim racer and are looking for something new, then I recommend giving ACC a go (especially if it's on sale). Even if you are new to sim racing you can't go wrong with ACC. It's a very good sim racer and is well worth it in this humble sim racer's opinion. If you have read this far, thank you for reading and if you have any further questions, feel free to ask me in the comments. I will do my best to answer any questions you all may have.

My main game before for sim driving was PC2, and I also regularly visit Automobilista 2, but ACC for me takes the crown. PC2 has major FFB and wheel issues with my G923, whereas AM2 and ACC work flawlessly out of the box. The level of  FFB quality in ACC for me however is far superior to the level in AM2, even though it supports trueforce.

ACC is thrilling to play in VR with a Valve Index and with a small amount of tweaking it runs beautifully. I am by no means hardcore into racing sims---I am a complete noob to GT racing but have been having so much fun racing trying not to place dead last in career mode. The AI is very challenging and aggressive and you have to watch out not to get too close to them. Luckily you have a team mate in your ear telling you when they are coming up behind you and on what side of the car they're on. It's up to you whether you want to listen to him or not. 

I recommend using the OpenFSR mod to increase performance in VR. I will include a link to my quick guide below. I was getting a lot of reprojection glitches at first but this eliminated that issue completely for me.

The GT cars are amazing. I've been racing with a McLaren. The graphics and sound quality are a step up from Assetto Corsa so that's a plus. Besides OpenFSR the sim doesn't need any freeware or paywalled mods unlike it's predecessor which is nice. There's a multiplayer option as well as a championship mode, career mode, and custom single player races.

I play with a Xbox controller and with some adjustments to the settings it makes it a lot more fun and easy to control. Below you'll find the settings I've found to work best with my controller.

Overall I recommend ACC despite it not being as popular as the OG Assetto Corsa and it can be more challenging. Whether you're a total noob like me who just wants to have fun racing in VR or on a flatscreen, or if you're a hardcare racing sim enthusiast, ACC will not disappoint. 

My easy OpenFSR mod guide for better FPS and more stable reprojection: 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2825040377

My video review and VR gameplay: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2827833450

Best controller settings I've found. Updated from the ones used in the video:

Speed sensitivity = 50%
Steering speed = 90%
Gamma = 1.7
Filter = 23%
Deadzone = 3%

I had game forever, but never could enjoy it, and i refused to play it on a flat screen. 
Got a 3080 TI and wow, just drove it properly in VR. It now drives really good and looks clean and flicker free in VR. Still probably could use more power, never understood why ACC is so poorly optimized. Just nice to finally be able to truly enjoy it. 

After more fiddling, got it running pretty awesome. 

Put on VR, turn up big speakers loud enough to rattle windows and tear it up. Sound is A+ Racing is A+. Too bad it took a wicked video card to be able to enjoy it, but it is pretty spectacular. And the summer sale has all the DLC at huge discounts. Really love the way this feels with my TS PC Racing Thrustmaster wheel.

Settings: 
Steam VR Render Resolution to 100% Global / 130% in ACC Game specific box - I swapped these around, it felt like I had a 1050 video card..settings are crucial.  Above 130 in game specific looked good, but definitely had some reprojection ( look at wings, you'll see a faint ghosting) However at 130 it all went away and sense of speed increased as well. Tried at 110, drove incredible, looked good, but nothing like 130.... this is where some fiddling comes in.

Using DLSS - think this is better than FSR, went back and forth. DLSS is a little cleaner with almost zero flicker
PIxel Density in Game of 170 makes it look amazing. So much in fact, you can lower most items to med or low and it will look better than high on a lower density.  I do keep Draw Distance and textures at High or Epic and Car LODs at 100.  

I can't believe how good this game is in VR after lots of fiddling and ading a 3080Ti.... still on 2017 mbd and processor, I7 8700 with 32gb ram. Using Game Booster in ASUS tools kills all external stuff and frees memory. Makes a great difference if using an Asus card.
Limited car choice, bit more "HW hungry", but it's a great choice, if You like GT3/4 cars and You PC can manage gameplay with acceptable average framerate.

Well.... huh.... Negative review? This.. is harder than I thought. I actually only have one negative reason.

Theres a lot of Positives about the game. The cockpit perspective is gorgoeus. The cars behave like cars. The sound is fine and I neither have any graphical issues in terms of framerate or speeds. The "Driver growth" is pretty nicely done, I really like the idea of that system. Shows details on what and where you can improve the most. Car setups can be personalized for everyone if you invest the time and... HEY! Stop! Stop! this is supposed to be negative!... Well ok.

The one thing that makes this game unplayable for me, even though I only driven 3 relativly clean laps... for a bad setup in that obviously tiny time window I've got recorded.... I am certain that It's specificly for me, unplayble. I use a controller. This game is made for wheels. But has controller support... Which is good!... but yeah. I need my speed control on the right analoque stick. It's impossible to change brakes (gamepad L2) and throttle (gamepad R2) to ANYTHING else. It's impossible to change in the options. Remapping neither helps or the stick turns into a on or off button aswell... which is very bad in the rain especially.  My brain is trimmed for more than 15 years occosionally driving in racing games to use either L1+L2 or R1+R2 to shift. I can alternate between that. I cannot take it that my right thumb is doing essentially not a single thing in the whole goshdang time. The stick is a lot more sensible in my opinion aswell. It's a lot easier to control the throttle for me. Also the R2 and L2 buttons VERY often malfunction after just a couple months lifetime of a controller.... which doesn't help the issue at hand at all. Please. I believe I am not the only one with that issue. Please give us old-time controller players the option to use the right stick as brake and throttle. Please. I'm begging you, Kunos, make that customizable.
