Love it Great sim

Although I like certain aspects of the game. Mainly the fast loading times and compatibility with wheels and peripheries. Some things are really bad since a very long time and I dont think they will fix the issues any time soon.
Problems:
- Driver Change: Sometimes it just plainly does not work. The second driver is selected and when its time for him to drive, he just sees an invisible car sitting in the pitlane with locked controls.
- Setting Pit Stop Strategy: You can only change pitstop settings while driving the car. That is really really stupid, they should orient themselves on iRacing and how they approached it.
- Connectivity problems: Disconnects happen often. Discord, Spotify, Streaming like OBS does not loose connection, but you're are loosing connection to the server.
- Track cutting: Cutting the track and gaining an advantage most of the time does the job pretty decently. Some tracks have the problem that even if you lift or brake you will still get a penalty.
- Tire selection and Setup: Why do I need to save a setup before I can load a setup from a teammate? Because the folder is not created until you yourself make a setup and generate the folder that way... Unnecessary. Also: Tire selection is way too vague. Sometimes we actually donÂ´t know if the change will work when we are in the garage. On track with a pitstop it works fine, but in the garage you dont know what tire was used and is currently fixed on the car. (Also effects the temperature when leaving the pits, bc your car is standing in the pitlane, forcing you to leave the pits sometimes with tires that are stonecold)
Performance: The game looks good. But you'll need a rocketship to get it to look that way. When your PC is <2000â‚¬. Don't even think about running the game consistently above 60 FPS on a triple screen on Low Settings.

Unfortunately those problems really suck when you are competing in an endurance championship and you're relying on the stability of the game over a period of 24h. So I cant recommend the game.
the best gt sim there is. a must have (u can get it really cheap on sale for like 9$)
best Gt Sim ever

The last SimRacer i played was GTR2, this was 15 years ago now. Being a simulator enthusiast and a bit tired of combat flight simming (still my passion, but you know... humans sometimes need a bit of variety) i thought about getting back into the racing genre for quite a while now. A friend of mine recently got himself a Fanatec steering wheel and pedals and since i tried these out, iÂ´m sold. I decided to get 2 or 3 simracers and a decent wheel/pedal combo and jump in. Since iÂ´ve always been a huge fan of GT racing, ACC was the first game on the list to get and i have to say it is a blast to drive. I have only played SP so far, as iÂ´m by far not good enough to participate in online races yet and i donÂ´t want to kill the game for others. Also i can only compare ACC to AMS2, as this is the only other racer i got for now.

The game does have some cons, but the pros outweight the cons by far. First thing i want to mention is the AI. My biggest gripe with it is that there is no AI in multiplayer possible. For online players, this isnÂ´t a large issue. But for me it was a bit of a disappointment to find out while me and my friend wanted to set up a dedicated server. Starting a private session with only 2 players and no AI is just no fun, so ACC sadly is useless for that. Unless you have like 15 friends owning ACC as well. If youÂ´re looking for private sessions with just a few friends, AMS2 will be the better choice even while its AI is at best annoying to race. The AI in ACC on the other hand, behaves great in SP so far i have seen. They fight for positions, respect the flags and keep the line (unlike AMS2, where they sometimes block the whole track when grouped, making it impossible to overtake). It does have some issues such as not making too much mistakes i.e., but racing them is realy fun and far from beeing as frustrating as it can be in AMS2. 

Graphics are nice and do realy offer some sweet eye-candy on a 4K screen setup, even while itÂ´s already a few years old and the pit crew animations are a bit.. letÂ´s say outdated. Especially having the AI glitching into their pit box. In VR the graphics are "only" good. AMS2 offers a significant sharper image in VR, hands down. VR performance however is good for me (definately better than with DCS, but thatÂ´s a different story), iÂ´m running the game on a 12900K, 64GB DDR5-6000 RAM, RTX 3090, installed on a PCIe 4.0 NVMe and have the very most options maxed out (havenÂ´t tweaked the settings yet, so might still be some overhead left), 35 AI opponents on the track, HP Reverb G2 with 100% Steam SS and iÂ´m getting constant 60FPS (locked) under all circumstances. Wich is absolutely acceptable. IÂ´m aware that this is not an average PC and that this may be different on crowded servers, but iÂ´m confident VR performace should still be acceptable with a weaker machine and still good in MP. Maybe sacrificing some eye candy, but the game will still look good then.  

Driving physics and force feedback are great. I never drove a real GT3 car, but as far as i can say the cars in ACC do feel very realistic to drive and way better than in AMS2 imho. Every car is different to drive and feels unique, you can easily feel the difference in front-.engine and mid-engine design in the corners or when your tires wear off (wich is also highly dependent to car, track, setup and weather-/ track conditions). The force feedback is also great in ACC. It is hard to describe, but curbs, bumps, over-/ understeering and tires / grip just feel perfectly simulated. Again, i can only compare to AMS2 and ACC realy excels here. Setting up FF, the wheel itself and the pedals is pretty easy (unlike AMS2) and takes only a few minutes. This is propably dependent on the type of wheel beeing used, but those having a direct drive FF wheel wonÂ´t be disappointed, thatÂ´s for sure. ACC also offers great sounds. The cars just sound amazing and you can easily hear if there is a Porsche, a Ferrari or a Aston Martin next to you.

Maybe the biggest downside of ACC (at least on par with the lack of AI in MP) is the damage model. While the mechanical damage is pretty accurate (as far as i can tell), there is only a very minor optical damage model. The car starts to look wrecked at some point, but there arenÂ´t any car parts flying around nor are there any dings in the chassis. Compared to what ACC offers overall, this is realy sad. ThatÂ´s not a deal breaker for me as iÂ´m playing ACC in VR only and therefore using exclusively the cockpit view, but for others this might be an issue.

The game also offers a lot of options to setup your car, even while iÂ´m missing a few (such as setting up the transmission of the separate gears). But i guess these are just not allowed in the GT3 class, due to Balance of Performance, but tbh i cannot realy say for sure if thatÂ´s the case. Also setting up the pit strategy is a bit marginal. You can set up the amount of fuel, type of tires and tire pressure for separate pit stops, but driver change (wich is mandatory in the champoinship) must be set up in the car via pit stop window. That is a bit annoying and can easily get you disqualified if you mess that up. Was a bit frustrating after giving away a 2 hour race just because of missing to change the driver during a mandatory pit stop. 

ACC does not offer different racing series like AMS2, but is focused on GT3 series (does offer GT4 as well, at least with the DLCs). But therefore offers a large number of GT3 and GT4 cars, also in different versions (i.e. 488 GT3 and 488 GT3 Evo). Might not be too important for some, but i like it. Beeing able to create your own car (team, paint) is also a nice feature to have. The track selection is bound to the SRO Blancpain GT3 license, so the included tracks are limited to those beeing part of the Blancpain GT3 series. However, there are quite a few and some iconic ones like Monza and NÃ¼rburgring. Also the DLCs offer some more wich also inlude a few gems like Kyalami, Suzuka, or Bathurst. The next DLC coming June 30 will also inlcude some amazing US tracks like Virginia and Watkins Glen. Realy looking forward to it. 

Overall a realy great simracer with good physics, awesome force feedback and only very few shortcomings. For those who love SP racing with touring cars particularly GT3 / GT4, this simulator is absolutely amazing.IÂ´ve read the online ranking system is not as good as it is with iracing or RaceRoom, but iÂ´m confident ACC is a blast racing online as well. IÂ´m absolutely happy with it and i canÂ´t wait getting good enough to try this online. Highly recommended!

It's quite immersive.
Sound is very good in my opinion. There is all kinds of things going on around you and it's audible and that adds to the experience.
The driving itself feels good and adjusting the setup of the cars is relatively easy for someone like me.
I have developed a preference for some cars by now.

Graphics are fine to me. They look crisp enough and it still runs smooth.
Driving online is my kind of thing and that can be very addictive and rewarding. Public server racers can wreck your first lap, so take care.

Overall a very nice and addictive sim that can immerse someone into being a racing driver.

One downside is the fact lagging on a server is not a rare thing. At first one might think it's a cpu/gpu thing but it is in fact something else.
I have run multiple sessions in row on 1 server and the lagging varies big time.

Another downside is the race director, he hates people. Whenever there is a collision between cars, everyone involved get penalized. Doesn't matter if you are not at fault.

This game is really amazing, if you're searching for a realistic simulation of modern GT3 / GT4 races. Graphics, Physics and Sounds are good IMHO.
The FFB has changed to the better and the overall feeling ist solid. But I really miss the option to swap to an Ai driver with a pit stop during long races. Other than that, this game doesn't explain anything. There are not even tool tips or anything similar. The base Setups are terrible for some cars. 

So, why did i change my opinion ? Well, because since release of this game, people wanted to race the 24 H of NÃ¼rburging or on Sebring. I do understand that this is  the  official GT3 game with lincenses and all, but it shouldn't be impossible for Kunos to bring some new, awesome tracks to this game, instead of creating new DLC's with a small number of cars (and mostly, these are just the EVO versions of the cars, that are already in the game).

The game is good and I certainly had some fun, the pitting and rules are incredibly frustrating and poorly explained. So 30 laps in and youre in the lead, come in to the pits and overshoot by 2foot and all the team just stand there with no indication of whether you are too far forward or backwards. Oh and yea when youre entire career is wiped the thought of starting again is so awful thats the last time you ever open the game.

Cons:

Update 24/05/2022:
Boy oh boy... After logging in 200+ hours and started doing it competitively, I have to say, this is indeed the most realistic thing you can play. Yes, I know, the FFB is not the best out there, but the simulation is insane. The physics are also on the not-so-sane side.

After patch 1.8, the game became even more realistic by the change of the tyre physics.

10/10 would still recommend, if you want a sim experience like no other, and if you are into GT3 and GT4 racing. If you don't care for these disciplines, then I'm afraid you have to avoid this title.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

It is one of (if not the) greatest sims of all time. The handling model is really similar to the "vanila" Assetto Corsa, but the physics, the textures and the environment are tremendously improved.

Also, NIGHT-TIME AND RAIN ARE HERE, BABES! It is really scary driving with your lights off in a rainy night.

I started sim racing in the summer of 2020. ACC was one of the first sims that I purchased. Since then they have continually updated and improved this title. Each update and DLC brings you high quality additions and improvements. For GT racing there is no better sim than ACC it for now has asserted itself and the king of GT sim titles. iRacing, RF2, AMS2, etc. all have their perks but for the best GT driving experience ACC is a must. No other title competes when it come to driving feel. There are a few negatives. You will see people complain about how this titles runs in VR all of those complaints are valid it is awful for VR. Another chief complaint will be about the online ranking system or lack there of. These complaints are also valid. iRacing takes the crown as far as structured ranked racing goes. However with a little time investment ACC and Simracing.gp are slowly getting there. Competitive door to door racing is out there just takes a little more time to find and with the right community could make it better than iRacing in some cases. 
    If you are new to sim or have not given this title a shot in some time I would highly recommend ACC. IMO this is the Best bang for your buck sim title out there. Just understand if you want to get the most out of this title joining a League is a must. But there are leagues for EVERY skill level weather you have never simmed before or if you are a veteran. Leagues are the best part of the ACC experience. For all the NA driver's who may be concerned about the amount of drivers on in our time zones I am on mountain time and over the last two years the NA player base has gotten SO much better. Even later at night there are active servers now.  To me ACC is hands down the best sim available on the market right now.
If youre looking for some of the best sim racing all-time, then this game is the best one. great cars and tracks to choose from. 10/10 recommended

Kunos Simulazioni made huge strides in the sim racing genre with Assetto Corsa. While the vanilla AC content was high quality as is, the extensive modding community prolonged its popularity for quite a long time. If you find the right repositories you can have just about any car and track combination imaginable, and if you can't find it for free chances are high you can pop a few bucks on a modder's Patreon page to get it.

ACC loses its moddability in favor of achieving excellence in just one discipline of motorsports, GT racing. I didn't dump many hours into the game after initially purchasing it, but I recently joined an amateur racing league for the game and ended up falling in love with this game. The baseline setups are pretty terrible on almost every car in the game, but if you're willing to learn how to tune the cars you drive, you can get them feeling truly incredible. If you love watching 24 Hour endurance races and wish you could drive those cars yourself, this is as close as you'll virtually get to the real thing.

I have RTX 3080ti and core-i7 11700, playing in VR with Vive Pro2. I have many times tried to get this title to run smootly and looking reasonably good at the same time. I'm unable to do that, and there seem to be many others like many. That's too bad. Why the hell graphics settings are so hard to get right...? Some other titles are also very hard to set correctly, while others run 90 fps easily. Really annoying.

The game itself is quite good - assuming you can get it to run. It is however VERY poorly optimised. The internet forums are full of people with above average hardware looking for solutions to their optimisation problems. The ACC recommended specs should actually be regarded as the absolute minimum PC specs. Unless you have extremely high-end hardware, you're going to struggle with this game. I have 16GB RAM and a 6GB GPU and the game freezes solid even with everything set to Low or Off. 

On a side note, don't even think about playing it with a G29 wheel. There has been a continuous scrolling bug for years now that Logitech either can't or won't address.

Pretty much one of the easiest ways to get into sim racing.
If you like GT3 cars then you won't be disappointed here.
And I don't know why it took so long for a racing game to have a feature to save mid-race so you can continue the race from the same point later. So I was finally able to finish a 24-hour race.

Once everything is going well and you have a decent pace, you can get involved in multiplayer. From what I have experienced, there is sometimes a big gap between the different skill levels in the races, but you can still race wonderfully together. Ramming, poor driving behavior etc. is actually rather rare here. It doesn't matter if you're fighting for a podium at the front or battling for midfield further back, you will have fun regardless.

If you're coming from Assetto Corsa and expect the same level of sandbox and modability then you will get dissappointed. The only thing you can mod are paintjobs/liveries. Assetto Corsa Competizione is a more streamlined and focused experience compared to Assetto Corsa. Of course you can still adjust weather, track, classes etc. to your liking but you won't be able to race trough a city with an F1 car for example. But if you are looking for the GT3 experience though, go for Competizione.

Just to preface that this review will be covering the ACC experience on the Steam Deck, in case anyone else is the kind of dingus to play a racing sim on a handheld PC.

The game itself if, of course, excellent. The driving experience is sublime, the AI put up a good fight, there's a good selection of cars and tracks, and the DLC is relatively cheap and is on sale fairly often. You'll know all this from the rest of the reviews, really. Playing on a Steam Deck is largely a worthwhile experience as well, which is surprising given that racing sims are frankly not the best candidate for playing while on the toilet. Will it be a locked 60fps, high resolution experience? No, no it will not. I've found that for time trials, 800p Mid graphics preset will give you largely 60fps, while a race with a packed field requires you to drop down to the Basic preset to get somewhere between 30 and 60fps (depending on how many cars in your vision are bouncing off each other at T1 on the Monza public lobbies). Locking the Deck to 40fps is a fairly good compromise here.

As for controls, this is a more mixed bag. I've found the default settings for the gamepad are very twitchy and need a lot of work to dial into something workable. I would advise swallowing your pride and turning on Steer Assist at least, it does make the experience a lot more manageable. Using a wheel, on the other hand, is surprisingly easy - I had the Deck plugged into my USB-C dock, and tried using my G29, and it worked without having to monkey about in the OS settings. Result! The game admittedly looks a bit naff at 800p Basic settings on a bigger monitor, but the driving experience definitely makes up for shortcomings.

To summarise, is ACC viable on the Steam Deck? I would say yes, even to the extent that you can use a wheel. When playing portable, it's great to do a few laps while lounging on the sofa. If you're really into your sim racing then obviously this will not be the ideal way to play the game, the compromises on graphics and performance are too great to be truly competitive. This does work online, by the way - I managed to fool someone just now that my racing was "good", in fact.

I am new to sim racing but I heard ACC was the best so I decided to start with it. This review is from a brand new sim racer/player. I am sure this game is amazing for experienced players.

TLDR: Great game for experienced racers, but if you're new to sim racing maybe start somewhere a bit more newb friendly.

I watched a few videos about getting started and set up my wheel and then went on my way learning my wheel and some of the cars the beginner videos recommended. So i was doing laps around some of the tracks with different cars finally find a car I enjoy and then think ok time to start to career mode to work on my driving against AI instead of trashing online lobbies. The tutorial and skill challenge is on a lambo, which I had no idea how to drive it, especially at monza so I suck it up but get through the test and get a bad rating whatever I am new, then I am thrown into a team selection with a bunch of cars I have never driven, with no options of cars I had gotten used to already. So I pick a team and of course what you expect happens, a new sim racer, at a new track, in a car they've never driven, I can't keep it on the track, it's also only the second time I have had traffic and the first time I have had real traffic. This is probably a fine transition for experienced racers but for a new player I felt pretty dejected. This should be changed, I don't need to be placing first, but I went from doing some laps around silverstone in a 720 to warm up to a lambo at monza, and then a mclaren 650 at a new track. Maybe find a way to make it a more linear path with cars if in the first test they are trash like me or something.

Like other people in the reviews, I, too, fell for the "play for free" trap and... well, I had to buy it.

Assetto Corsa Competizione is great. It's a more focused version of the sandbox that is the original Assetto Corsa, with more convenient ways of getting a balanced race up and running. It's also very comfy on account of the ability to control menus and open up the pause menu without the need for a keyboard and mouse, that is a godsend. ACC's focus on GT3 and tracks from a single licensed racing competition may be interpreted as a lack of content. To be honest, I really wanted to be able to drive in the Nordschleife in this one, and I REALLY miss that. But I also appreciate the small install size (as of writing this, with the game taking up about 13 GB apparently).

One thing that really upsets me and which verges on dealbreaker territory (were it not for me having just bought the game with a sale price, I guess) is that, when playing online, the game has occasional, sudden "sync" type lag spikes that freeze the game and then teleport you up ahead with total loss of control of your car for a good entire second or two. This usually results in crashes and completely ruins races and lap times alike. It also seems to happen when playing single player for some reason, but the spikes are shorter and more rare.

Still, ACC is a great, fun experience, and trying to improve your lap times is kind of addictive. While playing, I highly recommend you listen to some Eurobeat mixes or some Need for Speed music by Rom Di Prisco, it'll really add to the experience.

~Only read if you're a VR sim racer~

When a driving sim with VR comes out, I go full Digital Foundry try-hard and test every possible settings combo for 10 hours before even enjoying the game. This game is a joke for VR and the DLSS option somehow managed to be more taxing/blurrier than simply editing a config file/being smart with settings. I owned this game back in the day with an RTX 2070 and now with an RTX 3070 and it's always been 80/90fps stable (whatever your headset does refresh-rate wise). The problem is how low the settings need to be to achieve stable fps and how bad the game looks compared to even the older Assetto Corsa or PC2/AMS2. Sadly this game is an AMAZING GT sim, has great multiplayer communities, and some of the best audio I've ever heard. This means if you're a VR guy you have to just shutup and deal with it performance wise. Please make sure you have an understanding of how your headset is doing super sampling and how the game itself is and setup/benchmark things. This game is NOT plug and play with VR like iRacing/Mad engine games but it can be made to look decent while keeping the performance headroom at 10-20%.

Great sim overall and probably the best GT3 simulation with rFactor 2 being a close second.

A simracer through and through. For GT3 racing, it's one of the best, possibly second only to iRacing. As such, know what you're getting into. This game is not forgiving, offers no tutorial, and is inadvisable to play on a controller or keyboard. Get a racing wheel if you want to enjoy this game. There's not really a story, just a series of races playable in singleplayer against AI with the vague setting of a racing season. The meat of the game is going to be played online against other players. The small details that are accounted for in this game are insane. One of the devs even has a "did you know" series on youtube dedicated to just talking about all of the nerdy details, from traction control simulation to marbles, and everything in between.

While it is a bit of a nuisance, it does highlight the realism of the handling each car has, and how you cannot just directly transfer your driving between them. You need to learn the differences.

A superb GT sim with a relatively steep learning curve. The cars handle like their live counterparts so every single one of them behave like they would in real life. Many things to tune for your liking on each car. This is not a drfiting or smashing corners 250km/h type of game so if you like that arcade style, don't bother with this one. Of course with any other racing sim the wheel setup is highly recommended for precise feel for the car and road effects.

Multiplayer casual servers are nicely available for starters, but you can't avoid occasional random trolls or just "bad drivers" to ruin you fun if you're trying to keep it serious. Most of the time it's just racing and it's all gucci.

This is the best and most rounded car racing simulator on the market and that tells you something about the genre, because it's mostly a boring game. Physics, cars, liveries and tracks are on point. Visuals are good, though not impressive. Sound is considered the best on the market or second best. And that's about it. It really shows what simracing is in 2022 when in this game the most fun car is a low powered BMW and driving a Ferrari is a snorefest. At some point one wishes to say just get the first Assetto for dirt cheap, mod the hell out of it and do togue or wangan-style highway races in crazy modified JDMs, but that's like saying your car of choice should be an early 2000s hatchback with an engine swap and 4 turbos. At some point physics alone can't carry these games when the content is just boring. Yet devs and fans still insist on mimicing real world racing series down to the cringe cigarette adds on liveries, while real racing has become boring hi-tech garbage.
Yes, I recommend this game, because out of all the competition, it's at least competent at what id does and consistent while at it. 
Online? If you don't mind not being able to host your own game and invite friends without googling for a soution and thus be forced to interact with the most insufferable community next to people who play Dark Souls, yeah, I guess it's great. Just remember to turn off the ranking system for offline play, otherwise you'll screw yourself during your first AI race when they bump into you dumping your rating into the abbys and then no server will let you in. Great game desing.
Anyway, hotlaps at Bathurst in a Porsche at night, during rain is the best driving experience in any modern game of the sort to date and it doesn't have the Nordschleife too, so if you insist on simracing, this game is a must-buy. If you want actual competitive online racing, sell your wheel and buy BallisticNG.

Hey, new sim racers please read before playing on multiplayer...

I've seen some drivers doing a 0.2-second gap between a car in front of them, down a straight, and think that it is perfectly fine to continue to stop at their normal braking point they used the lap before... 

Conclusion: IT'S NOT!

Why?

Because doing a 0.2-second gap from the car in front down a straight, lets say Blanchimont, Spa at ~255km/h, both cars are travelling around 70 meters per second. 

That 0.2s gap at 70 meters per second is a 14-meter gap nose to nose from the cars

14-meter = 3 car lengths (average car length in-game is about [b]4.7-meter[/b])


[i](kmh x 5) / 18 = speed in meters per second
(255 x 5) / 18 = 70.8 m/s

m/s x gap in seconds = gap in meter
70.8 x 0.2 = 14.16 meters[/i]


So, If you were to brake at 0.2-second gap on your normal braking point into a tight corner such as a bus stop chicken (chicane) or a hairpin down to ~80 Km/h.

At that ~80Km/h, both cars will slow to ~22.2 m/s... Your distance from nose to nose will now be about [b]4.44 meters[/b]... (a number less than that average car length mentioned earlier)


If you were driving behind a guy in a Bentley with his [b]5-meter[/b] car length... your nose will now be [b]22 inches deep[/b] in Mr Bentley's backside! ([i]That's 56cm![/i])


Mr Bentley surely will not appreciate you penetrating him like that, and taking a sniff... As both of you's will now spill your SA everywhere due to those [b]22[/b] inches of action!


This wouldn't happen if you backed off just before braking to a much safer ~0.3s gap ([i]6.6m nose to nose, with 1.6m social distancing between the cars at braking[/i])
or even better is to brake earlier, and then modulate the brakes to keep close to him after the braking zone, and into the turn in.

[b]Brake modulation[/b] = Brake early, then let off very slightly to come closer to the car in front again, and brake again to slow the car down to appropriate speed for the corner.


Remember,
[list]
[*] - Don't penetrate, tap or grind people unless they consent to it.
[*] - If you're unsure about the gap and/or car distances at certain speeds, back off.
[*] - If you do know the gap, always brake earlier in situations when you're close to the car ahead.
[/list]

Itâ€™s much better to focus on the corner exit and get alongside your competitor before the next corner
Only ever brake normally (in this case 'later') if you are side by side and your car has an overlap, and you are on the correct side of the track.

Do not listen to people who say braking late is the way to overtake, there is no such thing as [i]"braking late"[/i], it's ether [b]Braking on your optimal braking point[/b] or [b]Braking earlier[/b].

Because [i]"Braking late"[/i] = you doing an [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZL3MtMLMW8g]EXTREME-ULTRA-SUPER-LATE-BRAKING![/url] and going off [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wycf3sbxPNk]into a ditch in front of some old grandmas house[/url] or [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=D8Vrtpr4CWI]The Lord of No Consent: Return of the Penetration.[/url]

This sim is barred from entry by high GPU and CPU requirements; budget builds barely make the cut, but it won't be smooth. If you got good enough PC though, you can have the best GT3 / GT4 / Cup experience with excellent quality tracks. ACC is the pinnacle of simracing Esports just below iRacing, so if you take the time to learn the ins and outs with your chosen car, it'll benefit you in the long run. 

Don't let the "few" number of tracks fool you, each are a lot deeper than you might think if you want to be competitive. Plus, there's night, rain, and endurance too. The driver rating will surely help you on the path of self-improvement as well.

Multiplayer wise, public lobbies and leagues are plenty. You just need a stable connection, and ping won't matter that much. I encourage you to participate in leagues if you can drive clean.

With all the DLC, it's a phenomenal package. The lack of some iconic circuits like the Nordschleife, Hockenheim, Sarthe and the classic American circuits besides Laguna is real. Considering they put in two years of work laser-scanning the Nordschleife for the prior game, I have no idea why they would omit it here. Also all of the alternative layouts that were present in the original AC are gone - it's just the main circuit now, and I think a lot of that is due to the licensing restrictions they had with SRO/Blancpain.
Besides those points, the circuits you do get are all top-notch, the cars are all phenomenal (I've only dug into the GT4 cars because I'm slow) and the driving experience is a blast. You can relive some of the past championships, or you can create your own championships. You can even have multiclass championships going even if you don't own the GT4 DLC - they can still be included in the grid.
Overall it's a fantastic sim, the physics are top-notch, but the overall product is just slightly stifled by how strict they follow the SRO calendars. It's a video game, let your hair down a little bit Kunos.
Still highly recommended.

Coming from Gran Turismo, then to Forza on PC with a controller, now to this with a wheel is fantastic.  I'm sure that there may be better sims out there, but one thing I always found lacking in any other racing game was audio and ACC has nailed it here.  Graphics are great at 1440p75 on a R5-3600 / RX580 8GB, enough frames to be smooth with no noticeable glitches.

Yes, the car selection may not have the breadth of other games/sims, but it's enough variety to make each track a learning experience each time.  Also, getting multiplayer is a lot more involved than creating a lobby in Horizon.  You'll be forwarding ports on your router and editing JSON files or paying for an ACC hosted server.

Really, no complaints, love this game.

My recommendation to new players is to try a cars at first and then pick one you like and spend time trying to master it. Every car behaves differently and can't be driven in the exact same way so there's bound to be one that fits your style.

400 hours edit: I still stand by my review. This sim offers a lot more than meets the eye at first. The time and weather simulations bring a whole new level of strategy and behaviours. This is quite a game...
I was only a Assetto Corsa sim racer, but I wanted more competitive racing. So, I had to decide between Assetto Corsa Competizione or iRacing. I chose ACC.
This game caught my eye because I already knew the developers, I love GT3 and above all, it was cheaper than iRacing.
Let's start with the good stuff:~
As this game is licensed by SRO Motorsports Group, the content presented is from SRO's championships. At the time of this review, it has GT Europe, GT World, and British GT with the GT3, GT4, Porche Cup and Super Trofeo classes. The quality of the content is quite good as well as the realisticness. Many people get angry because of the bad power balance between cars, which also happens in the real world championship. Drivers also complain about bad BoP. Tracks like Le Mans or Nordschleife will never be implemented unless SRO races there IRL. Kunos is trying to keep up to date with the new tracks that SRO races every year.
Talking about up to date: DLC's. You might think that the game + DLC price is quite high. I must agree, but the quality of the content is amazing. Besides, you can get the game+all DLC at 50â‚¬ during steam sales! It is much less expensive than iRacing subscription policy plus the track and car content.
People might think iRacing has better online racing. While ACC doesn't seem to have MP races every half hour, it has CP races every hour where you can get or lose rating (although rating on ACC isn't that important). There is daily racing on other websites and various communities on Simgrid and on Simracing. gp where you can enter every type of race. Basically, ACC has everything that iRacing has in terms of online racing, the only thing is that you have to search for it :D

The bad stuff:
"No Singleplayer career".
Although AI isn't that bad, SP races can be a bit boring. There is a career mode, but it isn't very good.

Rating is non-important
There is a rating system but no one cares about it mostly because there isn't much conected to it.

Bugs
There is a lot of bugs, especially on MP team racing, For Example: When changing driver, the virtual mirror disappears. Most of the bugs arent that bad and you get accustomed to it.

I drove the same car, on the same track, in rFactor 2 (which I also really like) and the audio was noticeably 'fuller' in ACC.  I can;t say whether the audio is more realistic, but it was more engrossing.  Really good game - just wish they'd release more sims for other classes of cars.  Driving GT3 and GT4 only does narrow the experience.  But at least we have Assetto Corsa for the rest.

How it started:
- You mastered arcade racers like Forza Horizon and Dirt.
- You mastered simcades like F1 and Forza Motorsport.
- You saw some streamers playing ACC, and it looked pretty cool.

How it's going:
- You try playing ACC with a controller, only to spin at every turn on your first lap.
- You get good enough with a controller to know that you need a wheel to do a proper lap.
- You get good enough with an entry level wheel to know that you need a sim rig, load cell pedals, a direct drive wheelbase, an authentic formula wheel, butt kickers, and a VR headset to truly feel immersed and squeeze every tenth out of each lap.
- You spend all of your free time and most of your time in the office on sim racing forums and browsing gear sites.
- Your wife and kids become strangers, but you don't mind because you just set a PR at Spa.

Don't fight it.

Assetto Corsa Competizione - is this GT-only sequel good or bad?

What's good:
+ Graphics: they look AMAZING on the right hardware, which mine is not.
+ Physics and gameplay: the realism you'd expect from a PC simulator. It's also done the implementation of GT rules very well.
+ Online and SR: This game actually requires you to be good at it to play online. F1 2021, take note.

What's average:
= Mediocre menus, but they're at least better than the AC ones.
= Controller/wheel support - there's no setting to set every car to the amount of lock you like, as in rFactor 2. Controllers are also heavily delayed.

What's bad:
- There is quite literally next to zero base content. IN A 50 DOLLAR GAME. You have to pay hundreds for extra content. 
- There REALLY isn't much to do except race, as there's no fun modes or anything. I understand it's a full sim but at least add a couple of fun modes that someone can play after the game gets boring.
- Driver swaps are kinda shit

Verdict: As good as ACC handles and plays, its embarrassing lack of content hinders it significantly.
Rating: 43% (Poor. Needs major improvements.)

No other sim gets close to the feeling ACC gives. By keeping the car selection restrict to GT3's and GT4's, you can feel every details and difference between the cars, which makes up for the variety of options you can choose. Graphics, sounds, physics, everything in this game speaks volume to the passion and care Kunos have with motorsport in general. 

This is a SIM, not your average arcade/simcade. It's hard, it's frustrating, it needs a proper wheel to be enjoyed fully. But if you keep your mind open to learn the craft, it's incredibly satisfying. 

Watch out VR buyers, the  performance for VR is subpar to say the least. You are going to need a beast of a PC to run it and you can still not be entirely satisfied. Be warned.

Apart from that, 10/10, best racing simulator I've played.
best GT sim I have played thus far in my 48 years of life here.

Regardless of what you think of ACC on the PS4, that's how I started and have since bought a PC and put 2000 hours into this so far in just over a year. The graphics are immersive, it's fun trying to push to be a faster racer and the streaming/online community, which I'm glad to be a part of, is so welcoming and helpful. You'll never struggle for a race whether it's lobbies, CP, independent leagues or services like SimGrid or LFM.

Kunos also clearly care about the longevity of the title with constant free updates alongside the DLC. Well worth it on every level for anybody thinking of getting into sim racing.

iRacing and rFactor2 snob here.
I was very skeptical about the ACC experience, even though I had driven Kunos's stuff from way back and know how good it can be.
A buddy of mine was driving ACC and saying positive stuff and seemed to be somewhat addicted to it...so I thought I'd have a peek.
  I bought it and starting driving.  First I thought the cars felt stiff compared to the previously mentioned titles but the more I pushed the more I thought 'this feels really good!'  I can get a great sense of what the tires are up to and push accordingly.  The more I pushed the better it felt.
I went back to my favs and drove them and decided after all, the ACC actual physical driving experience is AT LEAST as good if not better.  Plus the sound and graphics add up to a very strongly immersive experience.
Yes it's limited in scope but the subject it covers is not small and has a great capacity for variety within the somewhat confined limits.  There are several cars that I haven't even heard the engines for much less driven...potential fun!!
The single player work-up is really good.  A full campaign to be Mr. Awesome Driver and really good practice oriented stuff to play with.
Also there is a deep ratings system that requires the driver to prove he/she is serious about actually RACING and is just a lot of fun to learn and develope your own personal ratings.
I really can't think of anything bad to say about the sim.  It drives great, sounds amazing and is thoroughly fun!
Hats off to Kunos. thanks buddy, great stuff, I love it!!

GT CARS

Awesome sim. Very technical. Not a get in the car and open throttle. Setup screen is very simple. If you struggle with the intricacies of setting up a car, or you don't understand the engineering aspect of it, this game will be frustrating for you.

V1.8 Edit:
When the V1.8 was released I saw several positive reviews of the update. I started practicing using the aggressive set ups, with different cars. Before the update, the thing that frustrated me so much was that if you got off the racing line you would lose every bit of grip you had and just slide or spin off the track. After the update, the cars feel so much better, you can actually leave the racing line and still have enough grip to make a move, and my lap times are significantly lower than they were before the update. I still race on IRacing, but ACC is once again my main simulator. In my opinion ACC is the best simulator on the market. The multiplayer still needs work, but you can definitely find races, join servers, join communities for league racing, and have a ton of fun. It's not nearly at the level IRacing is for multiplayer. IRacing will probably always be the standard bearer for organized multiplayer sim racing, but I think Kunos and ACC are going to be the standard bearers for physics, audio, graphics, and immersion. I've logged hundreds of hours on this game in the past year. I'm sure since the update, I'll be logging even more this year. If you're on the fence about this game and you enjoy sim racing, you will not be disappointed with this purchase.

This is not a beginner simulator. While there are very good default set ups that are really quick, you still have to know how to race and use a wheel and pedals. A Logitech or Thrustmaster will work just fine. I used both of them when I first started playing this game. I guess you could use a controller, but this isn't one of those games like Forza or Gran Turismo. Even if you have experience with other simulators, this simulator takes patience and practice to learn the physics of the game. You will not be setting record lap times or winning podiums within the first few times of playing. 

And please practice overtaking in single player. If you're racing on line and you don't know how to overtake, please don't. You'll gain more safety rating and trust by following and learning from the person in front. If you are faster and better than the person in front of you, then they'll make a mistake. Forcing you're way and pushing people off the track is not overtaking. It's a game. P15 pays the same amount as the race winner, $00.00.

- Buy Assetto Corsa Competizione for your Xbox
- Buy Assetto Corsa Competizione for PC to get 1.8 version

- Get Fanatec wheel and spend five days playing about 10 hours/day + learn things from YouTube with (spare time)

- Plan to buy 2020 GT World Challenge Pack
- Plan to buy British GT Pack
- Plan stage 1 upgrade for PC with first stage including about 1000â‚¬ worth of parts around old graphic card for march
- Plan to buy new desk for Fanatec wheel ( currently its bolted to our dinner table )

Arguably the best GT3 sim racing experience to date. Which is also it's only real downfall. Being a series licensed game the car and track selection is limited to GT3, GT4, Porsche Cup, Lambo Super Trofeo and the tracks those cars race on. That said you do tend to forget about all of that when on track. Whilst all of the cars are very similar in terms of performace, each has its own characteristics and nuances... a personality if you will. All of the tracks are laser scanned and with the overall graphics quality, you really can feel like you're driving a real GT3. The only other issue with the game is the hardware required to run the sim. DLSS has certainly helped improve performance but you will need a medium-high end PC to run the game smoothly.

Overall, the game is certainly worth it and I would recommend picking up the DLCs too. Usually goes on sale on Steam for a good discount.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
[i]Updated review for version 1.8.x[/i]

A racing simulator mainly focused on GT3 cars and online multiplayer. A lot of people love this game and you might too if you like racing GT3 online and don't use VR. You won't like it as much if you want a wider range of content, need a good single player experience or race mostly in VR.

This game does some things really well, I enjoy it sometimes and understand its addictive qualitites. But overall I keep my thumbs down conclusion, because it has a poor VR implementation, poor career mode and a limited content to offer.


[h1]Positive[/h1]
[b]Driving feel[/b] - is good and gives a believable feeling of GT3 cars, handling and road or kerb surfaces. The GT3 tire model feels a bit different to other games, the tires can slide easily and the cars are quite sensitive to steering and slip angle, relative to other games.

[b]Sounds[/b] - the sound scape in the cockpit is raw and immersive, engine sounds and the bumps and knocks on the chassis. One of the best sounding games currently.

[b]Popular multiplayer scene[/b] - organized and casual players can easily find sessions with a lot of players. You can spend a lot of time online.


[h1]Negative[/h1]
[b]Just GT3 online[/b] - the multiplayer is almost exclusively GT3 cars. Nobody is racing the GT4 or cup cars. If you pick those and join a mixed race or official competition servers you will be the only car in that class on track. Expect to drive GT3 all the time if this is your main game.

[b]Poor career mode[/b] - this mode is opaque and dull, it schedules a sequence of testing or race events you enter. You earn points and medals that seem to have no context or visualization of progress, just a percentage completion of the mode. Also if you are not familiar with SRO rules the career mode will disqualify you a few times becaue your pit stop was outside the window or you did not select a driver swap. Also in 1.8 loading an old saved career mode crashes the game.

[b]Heavy graphics engine[/b] - ACC uses Unreal Engine and needs a powerful GPU to hold steady 60fps on monitors.  Expect to dial down graphics options [i]a lot[/i] unless you have a flagship GPU.

[b]Poor VR[/b] - in VR the heavy graphics rendering problems get bad, even with powerful GPUs. It renders blurry or oversharpened images. The images look bad at the mid distance where your eyes are usually focused. There hasn't been significant improvement; version 1.8 has added DLSS and FSR, these can help a little but with mid-range GPUs it looks then "less bad", still a blurry, messy result. ACC VR is still way behind the results possible from other racing titles (AC, PC2, AMS2, RF2, even R3E) despite using the most advanced game engine and upsampling technology.

Not recommended unless you have a high end wheel. The force feedback Logitech wheels is non existent most of the time. I tried various complicated solutions to fix this but was unsuccessful in making those work. You have no idea what the tires are doing like in rfactor2 and automobilista or pretty much every other racing game I have played. Other things like the cluttered controller set up screens and obscure button assignments not easily configured due to layout. The overzealous track limits that go off even when time was not gained or even lost is made worse by the 1970's cadillac overboosted numb power steering. If you like the feeling of hurtling around a race track when your in the passenger seat this game is for you. Positives are the great graphics & sounds, physics seem realistic but you just dont feel much of them with a G27 like all the other games. Until I am able to fix this steering problem ACC will remain parked in my racing game garage.

Update: The force feedback that has been missing for my G27 Wheel has now been added and I am very thankful To finally get some use out of this game. Im still trying to fine tune the steering though as the steering rate is too fast and twitchy. Initial impressions are much more positive so far.

Top marks Kunos! This is how you make a modern sim!

Even in it's early access stage (2nd build as I type this) ACC shows so much promise. It looks incredible, even beating out Grand Turismo in term of visual fidelity, and the replays in rain and dark conditions look so real you have to blink!

Bear in mind that this game includes one car available to drive, on a single track each month. Each month we'll get a different Blancpain car and track to use. At the moment the weather conditions do not cycle as you drive - so a wet track won't become dry. But tbh, that's not a restriction, as it's such a pleasure to drive a physics engine that tops Assetto Corsa, with graphics that look so nice. I'm running a 7700K and a GTX1080 and it looks awesome, even though I've not maxed my settings.

Older games like RFACTOR2, RRE and PCARS all seem to stutter and drop frames when their respective game engines supply gameplay to my TFT (144Hz) when they drop below the setting I have chosen. So, 100hz, 120hz, or 144hz. But amazingly ACC does not suffer this same problem. The action is much smoother.

I can watch a race replay (with 21 cars(20 AI and me)) and even in rain I'll get 100fps, but it'll look smooth compared to that same framerate on RRE or PC2 for example. So, I don't know what Kunos are doing, but at this stage it's awesome and I'm really impressed. Never did I imagine that a PC sim would get visuals like Polyphony's gfx engine. By the way, if a replay is running at 100fps, it's doing 30% more than that whilst driving. They've done an amazing job of optimising UE so far. 

There are plenty of settings you can tweak too. So even if you have a slower gfx card, you can nudge the settings down and it'll look nice. I did note that for the UE, I was forced to set AA to high, and set the method from FXAA to temporal - this was the only way I got jaggied lines to almost complete go away. It looks much better with these options on IMHO.

I've never had the game crash. I can drive fine without altering settings with zero assists on the pad (aside from the factory ABS and TC settings enabled). If you purchase ACC anytime in the next 2 months you'll get ACC for Â£22.49 - and this will include 2019 liveries for free - post launch next year. If you can cope with one car and track then don't sit on the fence, there's so much to fall in love with.

There are blogs on assettocorsa.com in the forums that explain what new work has gone into the physics engine. This is not a port. The feeling you get when the cars drop off a curb is great, and as I say, I say that as a pad user. This has already exceeded my expectations tbh.

There may only be one track and car per month, but just getting chance to drive with a more detailed physics engine at night and in the rain is amazing. This sim is going to force others (hopefully) to up their game. Going back to RF2 now, is going to seem like playing RF1 in terms of visuals.

After using ACC, I'm not sure I can stomach the stale graphics in RF2 and RRE. This one title will likely force the others to gather dust!

Buy it, it's a complete steal at under Â£23. Just be aware you are getting a developing game, with lots of new features that are yet to be completed. We've already had a game update to address a few bugs. A brilliant start to the early access program.

The title hasn't even crashed once, so Kudos to Kunos.

Still get crazy CPU spikes, very sad, love this game.

UPDATE: I think it has been resolved now, perhaps the latest update helped but what I also did was:

* Set FPS limit to my monitor refresh rate which is 60
* Turned VSYNC ON
* Disabled "High precision event timer" in device manager on my PC
* Locate the file ac2-win64-shipping.exe (which in located in your ACC game folder 
  SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Assetto Corsa Competizione\AC2\Binaries\Win64) - Right 
  click on it, select Properties, select the compatibility tab and click on Disable Full Screen 
  Optimisations. Also used the same option on the acc.exe file (which in located in your 
  ACC game folder SteamLibrary\steamapps\common\Assetto Corsa Competizione\AC2) just 
  in case.
* Windows Game Bar Mode also needs to be disabled for this to work.
* Also confirm these settings in the Nvidia Control Panel where applicable. 

Also lowered some general graphics settings, like shadows and so on, but I was even able to bump textures back up to High and my FPS stays locked at 60FPS. :D

The SA system massively penalises ANY contact, intentional or not, from you or anyone else, you are blamed, JUST like the God awful system in Iracing too.  So it basically forces you to race in gay, law abiding only leagues where you will usually find very few people at your level, they are either pathetically no life fast or very slow in my experience. 

And the best bit is, the ONLY way you can increase your SA rating is to race very close to other cars, so you can cheat it by racing AI, but online is fraught.

But get this, one yes ONE damn incident will drop you a whole point, but does it take only a few seconds to build it back?  No way, it takes lap after lap within .3 of a second to do so and then usually only by 1 point. I did 15 minutes as close as I could earlier and got only 1 point, yet in an online race was hit three times and lost two, it is not fit for purpose at all. 

It is flawed, and totally ruins an otherwise very good game.

More things to watch, quit games with aliens in, they will just annoy you, let them jerk each other off together, there are a lot of them sadly.

Highly recommend Assetto Corsa Competizione (ACC) for those looking for realism.

Having played a good amount of racing titles I decided to jump into ACC because I was looking for more realism. I started out ACC with my Logitech G920 but was immediately hooked by the realism and immersion. After a couple of months I upgraded my setup to a Fanatec CSL Elite with pedals and was enjoying it even more, even before the "big" updates were rolling out.
The money value is extremely high compared to other simracing titles but can still feel pricey for those starting off in the big world of online racing.
Long story short, the developers at Kunos have but so much love and passion into this title and therefor I highly recommend it! And if you can spend it, the combination of ACC and the Fanatec CSL DD is truely amazing, I promise ;)

Pro's
- Money value extremely high
- Unreal visuals (pun intended)
- Sounds are insanely good (neighbors love my revving skills)
- Force Feed Back (FFB) keeps getting better (were in my opinion already the best)
- There is always a race to your liking (track/car/time combination)

Cons
- Steep learning curve
- Ranking system/Multiplayer not as developed as its competitor (but https://lowfuelmotorsport.com/ does exactly that, so...)
- No custom liveries
- The rolling start with an online race (you'll need some practice and time to get used to the system)
- Car list exists only of GT3/GT4 cars, for now :) (And for it doesn't matter because I always enjoyed the GT3 series the most)

Hope this helps with your decision whether you want ACC or not, I know I do ;)

[h1]Review: Assetto Corsa Competizione â€“ The pinnacle of simulation?[/h1]
2019 | played time: 132 hours | 10/10

The racing simulator Assetto Corsa Competizione developed by Kunos Simulazioni allows to have a very immersive GT3 driving and thus racing experience.

First off, this simulation cannot be compared to its predecessor due to the different focus on certain aspects and the evolution of racing simulations over the years. Kunos Simulazioni provides us with one of the most detailed simulations on the market along with a huge attained player base for even more enjoyment. The selection of cars seems smaller than it is. As of November 2021, we are provided a total of 29 different GT3 cars including cars from DLCs and 11 GT4 cars also obtainable through the GT4 DLC. These cars can be used on a total of 19 different tracks including NÃ¼rburgring and Brands Hatch however 8 of them such as Imola or Suzuka are only accessible through DLCs.
The graphics in this game are thoroughly detailed on the cars as well as on the laser-scanned tracks. This is meant for both the models and the textures in the game. The cars have a rather vast selection of different liveries depicting their real-life equivalents almost perfectly. Throughout a race, there are also wear and dust marks visible. Over the duration of time on track, an increasing amount of wear and dirt marks are getting visible showing the usage of the car. The tracks oftentimes show tire marks in braking zones, turns and curbs. Tire marks because of cars spinning on the track will also stay for quite a while. The buildings and the environment are just as well modelled and textured as the track itself. 
Something very noticeable is the behaviour of the sounds in this game. The carsâ€™ engine sounds are portrayed realistically and do not feel artificial at all. The tracks themselves do not have any environmental sound such as cheering or birds twittering. However, depending on the events with the cars on-track, the sounds are very detailed such the rumbling upon driving over curbs or the echoing of the engine sound on the walls of the paddock buildings upon driving on the pit straight. 
Each car, even though from the same racing class, behaves differently depending on the amount of fuel loaded, position of the fuel tank, position of the engine and the setup. This results in having stronger cars on certain tracks compared to others. The laser-scanned tracks ensure the detail in the immersion through bumps on the tarmac and differences of grip on certain spots.
This simulation provides a highly comprehensive and detailed experience especially for players using a steering wheel. The force feedback is very customizable for different amount of detail on certain aspects of the driving experience. The single player mode offers a career mode where you can skip certain sessions and custom race weekends. The beauty of this simulation lies in the multiplayer mode where you can join one of the many open lobbies, which although have specific requirements to join or join a private lobby with a password for example the server of a racing league. The mentioned requirements ensure you are matched with online opponents on your skill level who know their race craft. Private lobbies are also easy to host via the steam app â€˜Assetto Corsa Competizione Dedicated Serverâ€™.

This game is recommended to every user especially with a wheel for realism in the simulation. The online mode is best experienced with friends or in a league where you can race and learn from each other.

Performance issues got kind of adressed in patch 1.8. With VR pixeldensity 70% and FSR the game is playable for me to be fair.






130 hours in I am pretty disappointed.

It is a SIM, yes and a pretty good one. I am sure it looks beautiful, when your nuclear reactor doesnt overheat running it.

My problem is, that is sais it is VR compatible when it actually barely is. My PC is not a big thing, R5 2600 with rx 5600 XT, but still can run AC with Shaders, RF2, Elite Dangerous very nicely. No epic settings, but everything is more than playable and actually looking pretty nice in my old Vive.

With this game i can't tune the thing down enough to get a steady 40 fps, but the more annoying thing is the latency. It is unplayable at some points even alone on the track.

I bought this game before i had VR to play it later in VR, and now i'm just stuck with it, and can't really play it. Waste of money i could say. And all of it could have been spared if the title wouldn't say "VR compatible".

I feel really betrayed, but I didn't want to write a negativ review first, because i was hoping for some updates/patches that may fix the VR experience at least a little. I don't need a photorealistic picture in VR, but I don't think, that my PC should not be able to a run title like this at least 60 fps on minimum graphics in VR.

ACC has grown to become one of my go to Simulators for online racing. Kunos have done a fantastic job with this game. The attention to detail, the level of immersion, the ambience all captured with great fidelity. There's nothing more satisfying that doing long form endurance races featuring pitstops and tactical battles with other competitors. Very few games deliver the same level of enjoyment. 

It's not perfect by any means, rubber banding while racing online, the out of the blue server maintenance, the ranked servers could do with some work to get to the gold standard of iRacing's multiplayer system, but all in all, a very well rounded Sim Racing title with a focus on GT3 cars. 

What I hope to see from the devs going forward is tackling content fatigue, new cars and track every so often will help keep this game successful for many years to come.

Cheers Kunos, you have a fan in me.

Assetto Corsa Competizione looks to be one of the best racing simulator games. While you need to spend ample time to master the skills required for the game, it will definitely give you a very rewarding experience. There are definitely some areas that need to be worked on (e.g. inconsistent frame rates), but I loved the graphics on display given it has the most realistic GT3 cars and race tracks. It has an extremely realistic look and is really immersive. The endurance racing demands sharp focus over a long period and really good reflexes, but is a fantastic challenge. The game is very enjoyable once you've gotten used to it, but people who are not really into racing games may find it difficult at the beginning.

â€œDude, where are the mods?â€. The sim racing community didnâ€™t take it very well when Assetto Corsa Competizione came out in Early Access, back in 2018. Unlike the spiritual predecessor, Assetto Corsa, there was no mod support, and the game would rock the Unreal Engine instead of Kunos Simulazioniâ€™s proprietary engine that used to power Assetto Corsa and NetKar Pro. And it wouldnâ€™t be a jack of all trades either: Blancpain GT3 content only, which meant that the car and track list would be limited to the ones that are used in real life. From a brand that consolidated itself thanks to being the peopleâ€™s favorite moddable platform, one could say it was a bold move. Would it still be able to stay relevant and stand out from the competitors that also offered GT3 content? 

One of the advantages of narrowing down the content variety is that it allows for extra care and attention to detail, which Kunos took full advantage of. Every one of the 32 (!) GT3 cars handle differently, with realistic performance figures taken directly from the manufacturers, along with unique engine sounds that make real-life sound dull in comparison. By far the best sound effects out there, making the competition sound like bumper cars. The modeling is also impeccable, both internally and externally, with fantastic texturing that looks just like the real thing. When they meant an authentic GT3 simulation, they werenâ€™t kidding.

But we all know that a racing simulator isnâ€™t just made of cars. Tracks are important, too. Kunos knows that very well and doesnâ€™t disappoint. Each one of the 11 base game tracks is masterfully replicated through laser-scanning, which means they are just like the real thing in every sense of the word. Every bump, crack, elevation change, weathering, and so on is carried over to the simulator so that both cars and surfaces can offer unparalleled accuracy. The other 8 DLC tracks are equally as good. 

As far as game modes are concerned, ACC delivers the usual stuff: career mode, multiplayer, hot lap, practice, and free race. Unfortunately, it doesnâ€™t sport a full-fledged career mode like the F1 franchise, for example, but itâ€™s good enough. From humble beginnings to the top of the category, with an excruciatingly slow introduction in Monza, which takes away from the experience a little bit but doesnâ€™t fully compromise it. If you want to buy it just for the career mode, donâ€™t. With that being said, the single-player races within and outside the career mode are very engaging, thanks to a very good AI that can either be very fast or very forgiving, depending on difficulty. You can customize the length (10, 20, 30 minutes, and so on), weather, time of day, grid size, mandatory or optional pit stops, qualifying length (or just disable it altogether), just like most modern sims would. Races are very engaging, and the rating system is a stimulus to keep you going. Oh yes, the rating system. It goes up if you race cleanly, goes down if you crash into other drivers. It might be strange at first, but it certainly helps to transform you into a clean racer, making you drive like the gentleman driver the sport expects you to.

The multiplayer mode is decent, thanks to the rating system. There are official races (where you get competition points for winning that improve your driver rating) and non-official, where only the safety rating gets deducted or increased and, the track and car control related ratings. Server owners can set a minimum amount of safety rating points so that people with low SA canâ€™t join and ruin the race by crashing into everyone, making it so most races are trouble-free. This doesnâ€™t mean that incidents donâ€™t happen, they are just less encouraged because the perpetrators get punished.

As far as additional content goes, thereâ€™s a DLC that brings the International GT series and 4 new tracks, another one with GT4 cars (11 of them!), and a British GT DLC that replicates the 2019 BGT season as accurately as it can be, along with three new tracks. For their respective price tags, one could say itâ€™s a whole lotta bang for the buck, transforming a very complete GT experience into an even more refined product.

Assetto Corsa Competizione, like fine wine, got better over time. From a troubled early access start with people questioning its physics and lack of content to hands down one of the most complete and authentic simulators on the market.

ACC 1.18.2, Definitely is a finished product, after almost two years and a half since the "official released", Kunos Simulazione has managed to deliver what they promised: The Best Driving Sim by far.

Finally, Kunos Simulazioni has done an amazing job. This is the best driving sim at the moment. It has everything: realistic driving, incredible feeling, superb sound, amazing tracks, astonishing graphics, plenty of FPS, and, for me and my needs, more than expected VR quality. Moreover, the competition, either online and offline, has been developed perfectly, including the rating system. Now letâ€™s hope the servers fill their grids with racing drivers because now the game deserves it.
My review was negative from the very moment they lied to us because they delivered a beta product as an â€œofficial releaseâ€, abandon VR completely, and set at the back of the to-fix list many features that were promoted from the very beginning. Their commitment was there, I cannot lie, they kept delivering updates after updates, yet none of them was aimed at improving the disastrous VR, which, as I mentioned before, is a must-have feature in any sim-racing game. So, I have kept my negative review until today. After 9 hours of racing the new BMW GT3 2022 on a TV and on VR over two days, I am satisfied with the result of the latest 1.18.2 update which is a breakthrough in terms of quality and FPS.
Thanks to the implementation of DX12 and nVidia DLSS, now the game is amazing.
I can race a full grid view, epic-level graphic settings (using the recommended GForce Experience settings) on a Samsung 52in TV screen at 100+ FPS and a resolution of 3840x2160.
Furthermore, I can race viewing 18 cars, most graphic setting at mid-level and some and high-level graphic settings on my Vive Pro VR headset at 70+ FPS.
My PC is not anymore the top of the brass, but decent enough to let me enjoy my racing passion:
Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-8700 CPU @ 3.20GHz   3.19 GHz
32.0 GB RAM, Z370 Aourus Ultra Gaming WiFi
nVidia GeForce RTX 2080 Ti
Windows 11 21H2

I should mention that for me Kunos Simulazioni deserves a special mentioned for their relentlessness; they kept working on ACC, heard all the enthusiast like me complaining about many things and fix them, and more importantly finished the game (well, I guess we will have more updates, but now there is a solid game base).
Sadly they did not do the same with AC, which was completely abandon in order to create and develop ACC. Hopefully they will return to AC and finish it or, as I have heard, create an AC2 using the knowledge acquired through the painful development of ACC.
Congratulations to Kunos Simulazioni and all the sim-racing fans, we have an outstanding game to race, and a benchmark for the competition.

Playing in VR is the weak point of this game, especially compared to other experiences (notably Automobilsta 2 and iRacing, whose VR runs pretty flawlessly while looking great). Older systems will struggle (I use an i7-8700K and 1080ti), and it will take some settings tweaks to find a balance between visuals and performance. Despite that, I still find it enjoyable in VR, and its shortcomings are well forgotten after a good battle online or a single player race.

If you are on the fence, this is a great game and worth the purchase, both for online and offline racing.

The long awaited (unofficial) sequel to [i]GTR 2[/i] that everyone has been asking for is now hereâ€” [i]Assetto Corsa Competizione[/i]. Featuring the complete rulebook of the SRO Blancpain GT series and two seasons worth of cars, teams, and tracks. Not to mention features such as wet weather, seamless day/night transitions, in-depth suspension tuning, live statistics, and more. The concentrated car and track library plays to the simulationâ€™s strengths by allowing for a further focused gameplay experience that extends to the driving and physics. The physics are superbly detailed, aided by an â€˜aeroâ€™ simulation rare to find outside a dedicated flight-sim. Since release, the tire contact model has been updated and animated pitstops re-introduced, thus aligning itself with other competitors in its category such as the all popular [i]iRacing[/i]. That said, [i]Competizione[/i]â€™s tire simulation is objectively farther along, in addition to the braking feel, chassis flex, force feedback, the like, are all equally comparable if not even more (technically) impressive against the aforementioned. All-in-all if your desire is to tame a GT racing car, look no further, [i]Assetto Corsa Competizione[/i] currently offers the most in-depth, detailed simulation to date of what it is like to drive a modern GT3 spec racing car. The game is not flawless and currently lacks a 'fleshed out' career mode which I hope to see improved in the near future. Furthermore, the longevity of the gameâ€™s current multiplayer is questionable, though the foundations exist to back both a spectacular online and offline driving experience.

Great sim. Great physics. Only thing needing improvement (still after several years) is the multiplayer functionality.. it simply isn't up to par with more accessible racing titles such as F1 or PCARS, or even GT. And for such a package, it's a massive shame that the most eminent feature of community racing is sorely lacking.

Picked up Assetto Corsa Competizione after my friend recommended I try it out, I was feeling like Project Cars 2 was starting to feel stale both in terms of physics and general car feel. I always hated how easy it was to skid out in Project Cars 2.

I'm 13 hours into Assetto Corsa Competizione, having played a few endurance races, and a majority with the Audi R8 LMS Evo on Nurburgring, and I enjoy this game much more.
The physics feel so much nicer, braking, steering, and even ABS and TC feel much more authentic. Tire pressure and temperatures also feel vastly superior to Project Cars 2's model.
I know in this game, that if I happen to make a mistake, it's entirely my own fault that forced it.

My only complaint (and I'm not entirely sure if it's my roughness/aggressiveness in racing sims or it's an AI issue) is that the AI tend to be overly-aggressive/ ignorant of where you are. There are times I take an alternate racing line to accommodate the AI's racing line and respect their space, but they overstep their own line, and either take me out, or force me to emergency brake. I feel like I know enough about racing lines and racing safety that this isn't entirely my fault when these incidents occur. These AI are on 0% aggression setting.

Nonetheless, I still enjoy the game for what it is, and can forgive the setbacks for the amazing physics and gameplay that it offers over other racing sims.

As a fan of GT World Challenge series and GT3 cars in general, this game is awesome, and is my main racing game from now on. It's everything I want in a racing simulator especially used with my Logitech G920 racing wheel.
