It's a different type of racing game. The physics definitely don't feel like Mario Kart or Sonic and Sega All Star Racing Transformed, which are the racing games I was most familiar before that. I also played F1 2018 and 2021 after I bought a racing wheel,  but those games didn't feel similar either. When I started out this game, I thought the way to win was going into corners with full speed, crashing into the other cars since there are no power ups to take the competition down and also getting an exit at near full speed but somehow it didn't work as well. In fact, crashing into other cars is no good at all! 

There's also a morale meter called the safety rating, if you are a good guy, it gets higher, if you are too clingy aka touchy (which is a criminal offense) it gets lower. Why does it matter? If your safety rating is low, you get put in with other bad guys in online races, who crash into you with no remorse. So in a way, it's like being put in a prison of convicts if your SR is below 60. Right now, I'm doing mostly community service in single player mode as of now to get to that acceptable member of the racing society status to get out of prison. It's a long grind. 100+ hours and I finally got to around 50. I was never incarcerated, but it still feels like a realistic depiction of the state prison system. 

So, as of now, I matured, and I realised that winning in ACC  is basically all about surviving corner 1. You also have to keep track of your tires and brakes to keep consistent track times, so there's definitely a survival aspect to it. There's also pit-stops. which are definitely the most nerve-wrecking, horror-influenced aspect of the game next to corner 1. Think of Silent Hill when the world turns foul. I'm a big fan of Silent Hill, so I appreciate this homage. If you don't get into the pit correctly, the mechanics bump your car into position. I guess that counts as a bumpscare. 

The handiling is amazing once you get used to it. This part of the game is basically a dating simulator. Dating with pieces of metal. Oh and I'm definitely into metal.  I like the Ferrari GT 488 because it doesn't make me feel like I'm walking on egg shells. The Porsche 911 is good too, but a bit more sassy, but also speedier in the straights to compensate for its temperament, basically a hot-blooded Italian. My first car was the Reiter R-ex in career mode which I choose purely based on looks and it wasn't very nice at all. Felt like one of those abusive super-attractive girlfriends that you stick with for far too long. "Oh, it will work out somehow!!! It has to."  We all had a relationship like that at one point. I was about to give up on the game and give it a bad review around 20 hours into the game because of it. Well, I dumped the Reiter R-Ex for the aforementioned cars which have more inner beauty and the game became really fun. The Lamborghini sucks as well, moves like a tank. Curves are beautiful? Yes, but not with this car, cause it has no curves. The Aston Martin is quite awesome! A bit like a mix between the 488 and 911. I haven't tried the others yet. 

The sounds are good. I wish there was more of a wind feedback though. I feel that's missing in every racing game I checked out so far.

Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10. I never give out 10s because they don't exist so that's pretty close to perfection. I wish it had a more colorful and engaging story mode. Otherwise, it's pretty good, very fun to play. A mix of survival Horror, dating Sim and a racing game all in one.
Good but controls take like 20 minutes to figure out every time u play

ACC's base game is decent overall. If you have a powerful PC it's got great graphics and audio. On mid/lower end PCs the game doesn't look so hot. Driving and FFB feels decent enough on most cars. Unfortunately, the devs messed up in two very important places, multiplayer and VR support, which lead most in the sim community to spend their time racing on other platforms.

[b]TL;DR -[/b] If you like racing against real people and/or racing in VR is important to you it's a no brainer to go for iRacing over ACC. iRacing is leagues ahead of ACC in both those key areas. If you're the type that only likes to race AI and you don't mind being limited to only racing on 2D flat panels ACC may be a better fit for you. 


[b]MULTIPLAYER ISSUES -[/b]
Personally, I find that racing against AI gets pretty boring very fast. They become very predictable and it's pretty easy to cheese your way past them. Racing against AI causes many people to form all types of bad habits which can be very dangerous if they ever end up racing vs real people (in the real world or in sims). Racing real people just adds so much more depth and complexity to races that it's a night and day difference when it comes to replayability and enjoyment. Winning a race against peers who tried everything to stay ahead of you is much more rewarding than winning against the same old AI that lets you dive up the inside on every corner.

Very few people play multiplayer on ACC. So it becomes very hard to find a server with decent ping, more than 5 or 6 racers, and on a track you want to play. There is usually only one or two servers that are populated enough to play on at a time. They are almost always racing at either Monza or Spa (because those are the most popular tracks) but being forced to run the same two tracks with the same cars gets boring very fast. There is also a huge variance in both the skill and safety levels of the drivers in these servers. So for the vast majority of races you will be crashed into on the first few turns but if you manage to avoid this you'll likely be all by yourself for the rest of the race as the few people left will either be doing dramatically faster or slower laps than you.

The only way to get decent MP races on ACC is to spend a bunch of time on discord and reddit looking for racing leagues that fit your skill level and schedule. Even then you'll only get one or two decent races a week. To put things into perspective on iRacing (ACC's biggest competitor), you can hop on 24/7 and find dozens of great races with people at your skill and safety level. People take sim racing much more seriously on iRacing which leads to much closer and fun racing. Not to mention the platform has a much bigger selection of cars and race types than ACC. 


[b]VR ISSUES -[/b]
The devs have put little to no effort into VR despite marketing that this game supports it. If you have gotten used to racing with a proper VR set-up you know its almost impossible to got back to racing on flat 2D monitors. When ACC released, there was pretty large backlash over how awful VR was on the game. Devs said they would continue to optimize it for better performance (which was the one reason I did not refund the game) but here we are 2.5 years after the game's initial release and the devs have still done basically nothing to improve the game's terrible VR experience. I have and Valve Index (which has a relatively low pixel count compared to most modern VR headsets) and even with a 3090 and a Ryzen 9 3900x I can only get a choppy 70 fps with all the graphics settings on low/med - it's a very choppy, pixelated mess that is literally unplayable.

[b]COMPARED TO IRACING -[/b]
To put things into perspective, I can play iRacing at a buttery smooth 120 fps in VR with graphics pretty much maxed out. It provides a much more immersive experience and better races with real people. So it's hard for me to find a reason to ever play ACC again. Yeah, iRacing can get pricey but I bought both iRacing and ACC around the same time ~2.5 years ago. Since that time, I have played ACC for 37 hours (Over 10 of those hours were spent testing different graphics and FFB settings. Trying to get to get VR to not stutter and/or checking if things had improved after updates. Actual playtime closer to 25 hrs) and in the same period, I have almost played 3000 hours of iRacing. So while I have spent about 5x-6x more money on iRacing over the years than ACC, I've also played iRacing about 100x more than ACC. Meaning iRacing's cost per hour of entertainment is at least an order of magnitude less expensive than ACC. So for me, iRacing provides a much better experience for less money.

If racing real people and/or racing in VR is important to you its a no brainer to go for iRacing over ACC. If you prefer to race AI on flat panels ACC may be a better fit for you.

For someone who just got their first wheel this game provides a really steep learning curve and the all the setting around the wheel functions, car setting and all can be pretty confusing. But after collecting some experience in other games and watching some instructional videos I finally made some progress in my play style and ability to actually do some good and consistent laps. But it can be really frustrating at the beginning. I'd almost say rather try a different sim, like RaceRoom which you can play for free and get some experience and to mess with your cat settings to get a feeling for it. It certainly helped me on my way to be a little bit relevant in ACC.
That said, however, ACC is certainly worth getting and trying out. The cars are brilliantly made. Each one is different, feels different, handles different and more. I went through the cars to find those that suit my and my driving style, and there are quite a few cars to choose from. It really takes a lot of trial and error, but is very rewarding when you finally start to do well and understand your car. It's also a pleasure to listen to the car's soundtrack. Great tracks as well. Just a real pleasure.

ACC is an outstanding sim. I don't yet have years of sim racing experience to judge how good one sim is over another but as a creative pro, I can definitely appreciate how well made this software feels. I'm a huge fan of companies that sweat all the details and there's so much detail throughout ACC. With only 700 hours of racing time, so far, across all the titles I have tried, and 200+ hours in the last few months in ACC, I'm still learning so much each time I use it. I had to do a lot of new things to discover this software. I had buy a gaming PC to try a lot of other sim titles and keep an open mind about what I liked. I wanted realism, and I didn't want something that made it feel like it was a video game. So far, there's so much for me to love about Assetto Corsa Competizione. I enjoy driving it a lot. I also love that I can easily make my own custom livery, and enjoy that when I am not racing.  To the dev team, this is simply superb work.

The graphics in this game are some of the best for racing simulation games, coming close to Project Cars 2 in some aspects (like water droplets on windshield, water spray and reflections) and beating it in overall texture quality and track geometry. The weather effects and lighting are slightly superior in Project Cars 2.

The tracks in ACC are very similar to the iRacing versions since both use laser scanning, but the kerbs are generally more detailed and accurate in ACC. For example, turn 6 at Hungaroring is missing the orange sausage kerb in iRacing but it is present in ACC.

The force feedback is greatly improved compared to the initial release and it gives me enough confidence to try to learn trail braking without fearing I'll crash on every occasion. Also, it's much easier to recover control when pushing a bit too hard compared to iRacing, where only the smallest mistakes can be corrected.

One thing I can criticize about this game is the quality of AI, compared to iRacing it is quite dumb, doesn't take much action to avoid hitting the player and has strange pace fluctuations over a full lap.

Negative features:
- It doesn't teach you how to calibrate your wheel and pedals properly.
- It has inconsistent braking points, most of which are too early.
- The traction control doesn't really work properly. I tried it on all the variations and even on the highest settings it still spins you out on some corners and unnecessarily stops you accelerating on others.
- It randomly decides how many clean laps you do on the tutorial. Sometimes it says 1/3, and then suddenly, halfway through a lap, it says 0/3 or 2/3. They also have to be consecutive, even thought the game doesn't tell you that. Without leaving the track, you can go from having 2/3 clean laps to 0/3, for no apparent reason.
- The game doesn't tell you if your lap is invalidated, should you leave the track.

Positives:
- Good graphics and car noises.
- Aside from the traction control and the other random bs, the driving within the game is as realistic as possible.

Yes - I'm sure this game is great with a full on rig with a wheel and pedals and screens all around and dolby digital all-round surround sound. But with a controller, (with steering assist enabled - don't email me), you can have a blast racing against a full field of bots, that can be made as challenging as you desire.

Realism can be dialled up, pit stops, weather, etc (would recommend), but racing crucially remains close and aggressive. As everyone says this is a great racing SIM. But with a few controlled tweaks, it's as easy to drive as F1 202*, challenging but forgiving. Worth getting.

Note that, per above - you'll need to take a minute to set up the controls but is 100% worth it. My biggest criticism is this game needs fiddling (graphics/controllers) before it does what you want.

My big question before purchasing ACC was how would it perform in VR? The answer is an emphatic 'not great'. I'm getting good frame rates on a 3070ti with a reasonably high settings but, never the less, it feels off. The image is blurry when compared to AC with the same rendering resolution on my Quest 2 and the car feels badly scaled, it isn't playable in VR. Good VR implementation is essential for racing sims and for this reason I can't recommend ACC and I'll go back to AC despite its inferior physics engine. In pancake view, however, it is the superior title and if that's how you're going to play then it's worth buying, but sadly, not for me.

Rolled into this title some time back and was amazed how good this in car feel etc. Used to be more in F1 racing, but CM and EA are doing their mess up thing again. Other SIMs have very high ingame addon prices too.

This game saves me from all that other nonsense and hope the next DLC will be great too like a Zandvoort 2021 season update and perhaps the Nordschleife one day with the DTM league and a Safety Car with a more realistic yellow flag procedure. Not to forget Le Mans!! Too much great things to add right.

In terms of vehicle feel and track behavior it feels very detailed and every little adjustment does something. Also the track details like bumps and detailed track features that make a certain track special can be found ingame due to the laser scanning project done on the real locations. F1 does not have that in this detail for instance. Day/night temperature and even tire air temperature has noticeable effect in how it feels and handles, where your optimums are.
Some tracks are very specific and might not see them elsewhere like Bathurst for instance.

Visually great too with too many nerd options to tweak it just right for your taste. Many great cars with some specials in the DLC like the Reiter or the KTM. Love the liveries in this game.

With a lot of AI in single player mode the game can become stuttery and feels like that has a lot to do with optimization perhaps. Hope that is in the pipeline for improvement on the PC port. It becomes less or goes away with less AI, but damn a full field with GT3 and GT4 mixed and a shitload of cars on the track is a lot of fun even flashing high beams at AI for lolz. Bet they can hear you when you make fun of them. The AI is very pragmatic though like I miss the unexpected things humans do unless you trigger them to react. AI on AI with updates who is kicking some bum when elsewhere on the track would be nice for immersion.

This title has no flashback features as some other games. When you are used to having that you could cheat your dumb mistakes by going back in time 10 seconds, but this game no. No more cheating muppets! You can still evaluate the race recording after the race.
At first you miss it maybe, but it also forces you to become better or just always lose like Mario in the 80's with 3 lives and no game saves. Turning off damage in single player mode is something to get around it, but you will still fall behind due to human stupidity. Love it.

Before going online the game wants you to learn tracks and techniques first too by a scoring system, before you have a minimum score level at knowing what the yoink you are doing before joining a multi-player server.

Different years and classes, short races, 24 hour races, 2 hours, whatever rocks your socks.

It does not have a campaign with a story line, but that is fine. This is pure racing with realism.
Solo play has a lot of features and sponsored events like LogitechG challenge competition and other things.

The sound design in and around the vehicles between the different brands seem to be as realistic as possible. That Aston Martin V12, Reiter and Maserati as well as all others give you a sound that might be very real.

All cars have their own specific settings with a few presets programmed for u, but beware not all presets might do what they do what they promise due to your own driving style like forgiving stability or unforgiving advanced setting that could get better lap times.
After some derping around with all the individual adjustments you can get handy at it when you know the a car and tracks a little bit with preset saving so once you found what feels right that's it.
It also has things like fuel load so you need to keep an eye on how much fuel you bring. 80 liters for a qualy hot lap is bs of course when you need to perform within 3 laps. Some things are not documented ingame like the specific engine mode settings for each car. The vehicle setup screen can have some more specific explanation, however exploring it all for science without a manual is great too. You lap times will not lie.

Fantastic game i really enjoy it. Good graphics it's so much fun.

What makes ACC standout ?

- Changes to TC/ABS/BB show up on your dashboard in real time. 
- Each car has it's own MAP settings.
- Each car has it's own TC settings. Some cars have TC Cut along with  your standard TC.
- Your driver's hands reach out to the actual respective buttons on the steering or side panel, whenever you change something (like TC/ABS/BB/Lights).
- There are multiple dash pages to cycle through to suit your needs.
- You can configure the RACELOGIC as per your requirement during the session.
- You can feel even the smallest changes that  you make to your car's setup.
- Tyre temperatures and Brake Temperatures are very well simulated. Brake temperature can leak onto the tyre temperature and heat them up.
- The weather engine is fleshed out and everything looks spectacle. 
- The windshield VFX are pretty darn good. 
- Every track is laser scanned.
- The sound design is phenomenal (you can even hear the chassis flex sometimes)

I can keep going but I think you get the idea. Out of all the sims that I've driven, ACC has been the best one yet. Physics is good, just like some other sims out there but little things that I've mentioned above make it stand out more than anything that is available in the market.

This is by far the most realistic sim racer out there. Period.
The little pings and cracks you can hear in the cockpit are insanely good, and it's one of the only sim games you feel like you can actually improve in. 10/10.

Can't fault the physics engine in this game, fantastically rewarding and addictive. The GT experience is captured authentically, if that's what you're after then it's a great game and encourage you to buy it. For me though it's let down by lack of features that would bring the game together into something more cohesive. 

For example... Want to jump on a track with a friend and have a blast one on one? to do this, you'll end up running game servers yourself, running your own chat app and trying to bring it all together. It's a lot of faff and you end up spending more time in setup than you do enjoying it's fruits. 

Other major call-out would be the lack of ghost support. It's very rewarding to drill a track in time practice mode, but you're left with little clue of how you might compare to others or how you might compare to prior laps. Also means you end up on youtube to discover new lines etc.

I'm being critical here though, the core of the game is fantastic and iv'e not hit a single bug.

I had wanted this game for a while, and I finally got around to purchasing it during its "free to try out" discount deal. Just as preface, I'm on the newer side when it comes to realistic racing games, so that'll probably influence my review.

This game has been a masterclass in GT racing, and racing in general. My "sim racing career" thus far has been limited to the F1 games, so it was neat to expand my library. In the beginning of my ACC experience, I figured I should customize the settings, of which there were quite a lot. I guess this is because the game is realistic, so this is expected, but I was impressed with the amount of settings and preferences available. In other words, no matter what kind of set-up, computer, or play-style you have, you can make it work in ACC. Furthermore, regarding the settings for each race session, there are many, from hot-laps, to quick 15 minute races, to full 24 hour endurance races, and everything in between. As far as the cars go, the variety available is nice, as one can find a car that works for them. The liveries are plentiful as well, and if you aren't able to settle on one, you can make your own. It is rather limited in terms of what you can do, but I won't complain about my glossy purple Huracan GT3 that I use almost exclusively (at the time of writing). Along with cars, you can also customize your 3 drivers, so that your entire GT team can be of your own design. To touch on my racing experiences in this game, I must say it has been spectacular. It has been both a fun time and learning experience. At the time of writing, let's say I've exceeded track limits more times than I'm willing to mention in my quest to build consistency, but that is okay. I have had to hit the ground running in this game, but in some cases, like this one, that's the best way to learn. Full immersion. I have found myself frequenting multiplayer servers, as I enjoy online interactions, but more-so because I want to dive right in. I've encountered fellow novice drivers, but also advanced drivers, whom I like to try to keep up with during practice and qualifying. After maybe a few turns, I end up skidding out, but I don't let that stop me. I get back on the track and keep going, and perhaps I will find another professional to attempt to tail, but, I digress. Pretty much, ACC has given me both an engaging racing atmosphere as well as a drive (no pun intended) to improve. Speaking of online experiences, I must mention the community. In my several hours of online driving, I've only been hit by a dirty driver once. In one lobby, I recall talking with the other players, making remarks on each other's lap times and such. Additionally, the game's subreddit (and player-base in general) seems to be really great. Many more experienced drivers are willing to help those who are less experienced. In a sense, they will help you in individual practice to get you going, and they will help you with anything you need right up until the green flag, where they will then stop helping you to focus on the race. But they will be there for you afterwards.

If you're a fan of racing and haven't played ACC yet, I recommend this to you. It is likely that you'll have to devote some time to this game though, for practicing and for racing itself. My favorite part out of my current 20.2 hour playtime has been the several cases of close-quarters racing. Driving in close proximity around a circuit while trying to overtake but not go off the track or collide with others is truly awesome. The adrenaline of racing, really, is the best part about ACC.

Great sounds, graphics and driving model. Rating system similar to iRacing that reinforces consistency and clean driving in both on and offline racing. Definitely a hardcore sim, but that's what I was looking for.

It's a hardcore simulator, the best one I ever played and I often hear that is praised by real life racing drivers. Every car feels different as it should. Game has effects of wind, dirty air, flat spots, more grip on the racing line. It is unforgiving, one mistake can ruin tires with flat spots and damage. I recommend to play with very good racing wheel with force-feedback. To be competive you will probably need deticated setup on the most cars and tracks and a lot of practise. Rain has the best effects I have ever seen in racing games. Only downside that this game lacks singaplayer modes. You can race with AI and do one season of the championship but thats it. AI is ok to race with. Game is focused on multiplayer which  can by frustrating because you could get crashed by others in the first corner beacuse somebody did stupid mistake. But in most cases you can get very good racing. There is a competitive servers in which to participate you need to have a good safety rating. System for safety rating could be better but is ok and it prevents someone who does crashes on purpose to race in races with "more skilled" drivers.

I would highly recommend this game for more expirience drivers, but wouldn't  for begginers.

Fantastic racing simulator. Probably most realistic of racing sim out there.

Simulation Hardware: Thrustmaster T300RS

In terms of graphics, and UI/UX experience, having played AC, ACC is a much, much more smoother and polished experience than AC. It even has a Career, which makes this a game, rather than just a simulation like AC. The UI is finally good it looks like a modern game. The setup customization is so much more polished and it gives you so much more details. When AC looks like a game from 2012, this looks and feels like a modern game from 2019+.

In terms of simulation, I've never been a simulation expert, so you'll have to look other comments from people who feel more comfortable speaking about it.

Overall, this feels so much more as a step up for actually becoming a game, rather than staying just a simulation. This looks as if the developers actually had hired designers to design the GUI, rather than the AWS team.

One of the last titles I bought when getting into Sim Racing, and it should have been one of the first. It is simply awesome in what it delivers, the cars and tracks all look fantastic, the handling feels incredible, the close racing is intense and so much fun. Yes there are things it could do better (looking at you SA) but when youre racing hard with people of a similar skill none of it matters, the experience is so immersive and is worth every damn penny. A few more cars and tracks would go down well (Mustang and Supra and some of the US tracks), but even with the few cars and tracks there are, it provides more than enough. Heres to the next 1000 hours of racing!

Overall, this sim is very good! The sim features a variety of tracks and GT3/GT4 cars. The physics model in this game is very good. In this sim, you have to look after the tire pressures, tire temperatures, and brake temperatures, which add that element of realism to the sim. The GT3 cars aren't hard to drive in this sim, but a lot of hours are required in order to be fast in a GT3 car. The weather model is very good, since you can definitely feel the weather changes in the track surface/ track ambient while driving. The setup page is a bit confusing for people who don't know much about setups like me, but if you can master it, you will have a very quick car. Personally, I think that all of the DLCs this sim has to offer are worth buying. This sim has become one of my all-time favorite sims, and I can't wait to play more hours in order to get quicker.

There are many aspects of this game that I love... the realism of tire wear, break wear, fuel consumption, damage, full control while in pit lane, being able to control lights, wipers, degrees of ABS and TCL ect... Sadly though, I race with a Xbox controller and have been for years with no problem on games like Forza, even Grand Turismo on Play Station... I've always been able to look around the car with the right joystick... in this game you cant do that apparently. But the worst thing is the clutch... for some reason I really cannot explain there is no way to have a clutch button mapped to your controller... for something so important and fundamental to driving how is it that cannot have a clutch button? For this reason I am giving this a thumbs down... if you have a wheel and pedal this game may be for you... if your using a Xbox controller.... well, I'll be looking for another game.

I picked up sim racing about a month ago with Gran Turismo Sport. After a couple of days playing I was pretty much hooked. It's been a lot of fun learning about the racing world, driving techniques and trying to improve myself. I started racing online and while I'm definitely still a noob, I was enjoying it immensely. After the latest update to GTS though, the online penalty system broke and has become a total wreck-fest in my driver ranking group. So, I figured I'd pick up something for the PC and after doing some research I ended up with AC & ACC.

First off, the driving simulation itself is great and I highly recommend it. I'm liking the realism and I can clearly see why AC is the creme-de-la-creme of racing sims. My problems with the game really start to stem out of how the game itself is set up and the problems it's giving me before I can even start racing.

1. Every time I boot up the game, my driving wheel is off. The game seems to have a bad habit of throwing off my wheel's calibration. I open up the game, go to race only to find my wheel's off center. I have to back out of the game, spend 20 minutes calibrating the wheel before I can even get going. It's immensely frustrating. 

2. You have to know to set your wheel up properly. If your wheel/pedals aren't set up appropriately you're going to have a bad time. When I first booted up the game and started career mode, I was clocking about 2:06 in the Monza tests compared to the AI's 1:56. At first I contributed to the fact that I must have really just sucked at the game, but come to find out that the wheel/pedals just weren't set properly. After doing some research, I finally got it set up and almost instantly shaved 6 seconds off that time. The problem here is that I had to spend time outside of the game to even come to that realization. 

3. Career mode just seems awful. I'm not expecting some grand and immersive career mode, but there just doesn't seem to be any progress. After you finish the first tests that set the AI level, etc, you get to select a car to use during the course of your career, but you can't seem to change it after you've selected it. If you're like me and totally new to this, you need to be able to experiment, go back and try things differently, but that option just doesn't seem to be available. If you select the wrong car and want to change it, you have to start career mode all over.

4. Sometimes it seems too realistic. Maybe it's just me, but sometimes it just sounds like the engines in these cars are about to fall out of the underside, or like there's just gravel all up in the engine. It's incredibly distracting when you feel like the engine is about to break out of every turn you come out of.

5. The track competency system doesn't seem to make a whole lot of sense and my laps seems to get invalidated for the tiniest mistakes. In the early career mode tests at Monza my laps kept being invalidated coming out of turn one and I just could not figure out why, even if I felt like I took the turns perfectly.

6. The game doesn't seem to be too keen on explaining the basics to you. During the first race at Zurburing, after spending a number of hours even getting through free practice and qualifying, I was doing pretty well, but I almost missed my pit window. I had 0 idea that I needed to pit. Pitting's fine, I just wasn't aware and it cost me my position in the race and I finished in last. At that point I was at least happy I had actually finished a race, but now it's like ok, I'd like maybe a course on pitting or something. I don't want to have to get out of the game and search youtube videos or something to learn how to do this stuff.

Overall, I really want to like the game, it just feels like there's a mountain to climb to even get there. I guess they expect you to have a basic working knowledge of racing sims before you even get the game. I think it would really benefit from a plug-n-play style like Gran Turismo while also having the capability of being a full blown sim racer.
